name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the reflection paper Towards a Sustainable Europe by 2030 (2019/2570(RSP)).

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the European Commission. – Madam President, also on behalf of Jyrki I want to thank you and the Members for offering us the possibility to present our reflection paper on the European Union’s road to sustainability from now until 2030 and beyond. Sustainable development starts and ends with people. It is about upholding our way of life and upgrading the well-being of our children and grandchildren. It’s about equality, a healthy natural environment and a thriving green and inclusive economy. Our starting point in moving towards a sustainable European future has to be the 17 comprehensive and interdependent sustainable development goals the world agreed upon and committed to in the United Nations in 2015. These goals offer the most comprehensive and universally accepted framework to guide our work for the years to come. Our core challenge for the next decade is to find a way to develop economically, continuously improving our living standards and well-being for the benefit of all, without depleting our natural resources, destroying and poisoning our environment and spurring climate change. What we need is an economy that grows within the limits of our planet and delivers prosperity to the many, not the few. To achieve these goals and to get there requires some fundamental changes in our production and consumption patterns. There are certain key game changing policy areas we in the EU have already started to deliver on and need to continue to prioritise. We need to move from a linear to a circular economy. We need to put our food system onto a fully sustainable path. We need to future proof our energy, buildings and mobility. But we will only truly be successful if we make these changes in a socially fair manner, putting strong social policies in place and making sure we leave no one behind. That’s the only way you can get everyone behind this policy. To do all that we also need to gear the so-called horizontal enablers towards a green and inclusive economic transition. These include education, science, research, innovation and digitisation, as well as finance, taxation, pricing, so that sustainable products and services become the most affordable ones, including responsible business conduct and fair trade policies. Good governance is key as the very foundations we build on are the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. This is of course a global issue, especially now when others are questioning their commitment. We need to continue to be the strongest advocate for sustainable development in a multi-polar world, in a world based on multilateralism. This is also in our own competitive interest. The EU is at the origin of many of the most innovative and comprehensive sustainability solutions. We are best placed to be a first mover, blaze a trail for the rest of the world and reap the social and economic benefits of the sustainable transition while helping to shape global standards. (Applause)

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, we all know that there is no planet B, thus there is no plan B, and we have to take the sustainability challenge seriously. But the positive thing is that sustainability is anchored in the EU treaties. It’s part of our DNA. Delivering on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is not just a necessity, it is also a huge opportunity. It is about modernising our societies, about new forms of doing business and consuming, about reaping the benefits of new technologies and innovation. It’s about our future competitiveness. We already see that it is possible. The past years have shown that GDP growth is compatible with the reduction of CO2 emissions. It is not about lowering our living standards but about being smarter about our resources. Of course this requires a significant amount of investment. Here, the investment plan can play an important role in bringing the private sector on board. The action plan on sustainable finance will provide investors with comprehensive information on what is sustainable investment and create a new market for it. The circular economy is another area where we can create a new market. We have started to do so with plastic waste, other sectors should follow. To be successful, the transition needs to fulfil some conditions. First, we need to invest more in education and training to ensure equal opportunities and fairer societies. Second, we need to invest more in research, development and innovation, and also digitalisation, in particular in artificial intelligence. This has a huge potential, for example, in health or agriculture and Europe cannot lag behind in this field. Third, the rule of law and respect for fundamental values. We have recently seen worrying signs of leaders calling the very foundation of our democracies into question. The reflection paper is also a call to the rest of the world not to get tempted by easy solutions that may solve symptoms in the short term but that do not address the causes of our problems. We will continue contributing solutions, together with the rest of the world, in multilateral forums and through development cooperation, the external investment plan, as well as through open and rules-based trade. I am convinced that good cooperation between the Commission, Member States and the honourable Members of this House can provide and strengthen the leadership of Europe in sustainability.

name: Francesc Gambús
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank the Vice-President of the Commission for attending the joint meeting of the Development and Environment Committees last Thursday to present the reflection paper entitled 'Towards a Sustainable Europe in 2030'. A document that comes to us significantly late, since we expected it at the end of last year and that we believe does not finish meeting the expectations that we had set in it because, in order to achieve the objectives, apart from reflection, we need action. In this sense, there are two options, and I want to give two clear examples. One, related to target number 6, over water. The Framework Directive lays down an obligation for the Commission to submit an evaluation report for the Directive by 20 December 2018. It's February 13, 2019 and we're still not news about it. The best regulation also goes so far as to comply with the Directives, both the Member States and the Commission. Another path, however, is that followed by Commissioner Arias Cañete, who put us in a leading position of Objective 4, to combat climate change, before, during and after COP 21 in Paris. And, more than ever, this leadership of the Union must be the world benchmark as the way forward for all countries on this planet, which, it is true, has no plan B. Rhetoric and aesthetics or action and commitment. It's two different paths. One gives headlines, the other gives results. Our institutions, which citizens choose in the May elections, will depend on the Union's path to comply with Horizon 2030.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, even if the picture this morning doesn’t fully mirror the importance of the issue, yes this debate will be the dominant debate during the next five years. Even if perhaps not all sides have fully understood, this will be the decisive leadership debate for the next five years. Our group, the Socialists and Democrats, have understood. We are spearheading this discussion and we come forward with our own proposals and we are pretty much convinced that we will also be able to explain that to our partners and friends here in the House during the campaign and, finally, at the beginning of our next mandate. Yes, we recently saw thousands of people taking to the streets all over Europe calling on governments to act against climate change. Our planet is rapidly reaching its limits. The way we produce and consume depletes our fish stocks, pollutes our air, destroys our soil and damages our health. Among our citizens, particularly among the young, there is a broad awareness of the urgency to act now. At the same time, social uprisings like the yellow vests in France articulate a deep-seated frustration with the status quo and anger at social injustice. Something is fundamentally wrong with a system when, after 40 years of hard work, pensioners have to choose between paying their heating or buying food. Something is fundamentally wrong when workers slave away for 40 or more hours per week and still can’t make ends meet. And something is fundamentally wrong when young people, at a time when the future should lie wide open, to them become entrapped in a vicious circle of unemployment, unpaid traineeships and short-term contracts. How can we expect these people now to pick up the bill for transforming the ways we produce and consume to more sustainable patterns while digital giants pay almost zero taxes and the super-rich hide billions in tax havens? This system is broken. Our societies are in a deep crisis. Liebe Kolleginnen und Kollegen, wir Sozialdemokratinnen und Sozialdemokraten denken deswegen, dass man diese beiden Krisen entschieden zusammen anpacken muss, die soziale wie die ökologische.  Wir kämpfen für einen gerechten Übergang zu einem nachhaltigen Wirtschaftsmodell, das Wohlstand für alle schafft, mit den Zielen der Vereinten Nationen für nachhaltige Entwicklung als unsere Wegweiser, weil wir wissen, dass unser Planet nicht überleben wird, wenn soziale Ungerechtigkeiten fortbestehen, und weil soziale Ungerechtigkeiten nicht auszurotten sind, ohne die Umweltkrise entschieden anzupacken. Deswegen, sehr verehrte Vizepräsidenten der Kommission: Es ist Zeit zu handeln! Ihr Papier macht einen Vorschlag, ein ambitioniertes Szenario 1 zu verfolgen. Wir unterstützen das. Wir wollen nicht mehr darüber diskutieren, welches Szenario das Richtige ist, wir wollen es umsetzen. Weil wir glauben, dass wir keine Zeit mehr haben, müssen wir jetzt die Konzepte setzen, Konzepte entschiedenen Handelns für das neue Mandat.  Alle unsere Bereiche in der Politik – ob wir über Regionalpolitik reden, ob wir über Forschungsförderung reden, ob wir über die Art und Weise der Handelsverträge reden, die wir abschließen – müssen sich an diesen Zielen orientieren. Wir müssen sie endlich in die Realität bringen, messen, Erfolge feiern und weiter vorangehen. Das sind wir dieser Erde schuldig und unseren Kindern.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Madam President. I too would like to thank the Commission for this excellent document and for its excellent contribution to this debate. This is one of the first documents in which the Commission indicates that urgent action is needed to address the multifaceted ecological crisis we are facing. Climate, biodiversity, raw materials and air quality: it all occurs in it. I really thank the Commission for that. Fortunately, as Mr Bullmann said, social inequality is also being addressed, because the two are indeed very much together. But then we come to the big question, the same question I also asked after the presentation of the long-term climate strategy. How are we going to turn this into concrete action, not only tomorrow, but also today? When I look at the proposal for the multiannual budget and see that we are setting out policy and money in it until 2027, it is seriously dated. That is old politics, if I compare it to these two excellent documents from the European Commission. Let's be, 2030 seems far away, but it's tomorrow. And we have very little time left to turn the tide. So, my specific question to the Commission is: when can we expect concrete proposals? And can we expect adjustments to the multiannual budget? Agricultural policy as it stands does not meet the criteria set out in this document. Why do we not green all public procurement so that we create a market of more than EUR 2 000 billion a year? The same applies to the Structural Funds as to agricultural policy: they do not meet the criteria we are now setting. And it is very nice that Commissioner Katainen referred to 'sustainable financing', but now it is almost just about transparency. The crucial question will ultimately be: how do we encourage green and socially just investment? And how do we discourage investments that are not? The Economist also says that the market cannot do this alone. That's why we desperately need your help, not tomorrow, but today.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, with this reflection paper the European Commission is trying to sell us again a green bike, a hoax. It explains that the European Union — and I quote verbatim — is well placed to be a world leader in the transition to sustainability, or that it has pioneered this field. But if we look at the proposal in more detail, we realize that the European Commission's first concern is economic growth, but understood as the benefits that transnationals will be able to draw from this economic reorientation. For example, let's talk about agriculture, the first thing the Commission says is that a new economic value of more than EUR 1.8 trillion can be created by 2030 and, if anything, contribute to the recovery of natural resources; but at no time is the use of large-scale pesticides being debated in this House questioned, for example, or the fact that the common agricultural policy favours large farms more than local and organic agriculture. Nor are insufficient energy targets questioned. In fact, with the data that Eurostat has recently put in hand, it does not seem so clear that we will reach the common target of 20% renewables by 2020. I do not know. As the Commission said at the beginning, either sells us a green motorbike or is selling us smoke. But the truth is that the root of the problem is not being attacked: a voracious and unsustainable economic system. The solution is to put the ecological transition under the umbrella of the interests of the people and the planet, and not the sacrosanct economic growth. You can't fight climate change without your leaders losing your privileges.

name: Tilly Metz
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr Timmermans proposes a discussion paper on the European Union's sustainable development objectives, in which he presents three scenarios. In fact, one of the scenarios is to do nothing more. Now we continue to analyse and consider strategies for the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals, which the United Nations has already set in 2015. But isn't it time to react? To quote Greta Thunberg: "I would like you to panic as if your house was burning". Do we? We weigh the throes and cons, we meditate. Is this really what you do when your house burns down? Wouldn't you be running left and right to look for water, blankets, in short, reacting to put out the fire? So, unlike many policy makers, European youth have taken the measure of the issue. Today, we have the technical solutions to reduce our ecological footprint. Of course, we must continue to perfect it, we must have a fair approach: just at European level: it is not for the disadvantaged social classes to pay the cost of the ecological transition; and just on a global level: we can't make others suffer to have more clean air here. Now we need to set the right political priorities, we need to coordinate our actions for the climate, we need to establish an ambitious roadmap, with deadlines, with clearly defined objectives in the fields of energy, industry, mobility, agriculture. The ecological and solidarity transition can no longer wait. We managed to bring down the Berlin Wall, to go to the moon. That's why achieving our climate goals is possible, we can do it too. And, as Jeffrey Sachs said last week in the European Parliament: "If the EU will not succeed to do so, nobody will, and nobody will save this planet". If the EU does not succeed in doing so, nobody will, and nobody will save this planet.

name: Bill Etheridge
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, you cannot buck the market. Now, we all want to live in a better world. We all want good air quality. We all want to see ecologically sound moves. Everyone wants that. Nobody wants to live in a situation like the area that I came from originally, the Black Country in the UK, which around the 19th century, during the industrial revolution, was known as the Black Country because during the day it was black from the soot and smoke from the furnaces and at night it was red because of the foundries. People died because their lungs were being clogged up by this stuff. So we all would like to see a better environment to live in. But my suggestion, my proposal, my input into all this is that you can’t do it, and certainly not by 2030, which is, in terms of these kind of changes, tomorrow. You can’t do this from the top down, imposing and forcing. You’re ignoring human nature: the desire to create wealth to better their souls through trade. What needs to be done is to facilitate an environment where science develops better – maybe – tax breaks on these kind of things. So the actual products and services that go towards sustainability are attractive to the consumer and market forces will create the situation that we all want. We all want a better world. it is just how we go about it. Not top—down, bottom—up.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have just heard my colleague saying ‘you can’t do it, that’s against human nature’. I would say it’s even more against human nature to destroy our planet and living conditions quite deliberately. That you can’t do but sustainable development – yes – you can do and you can do it profitably. So it is just a matter of taking the initiative, so thank you to the Commission for the sustainable finance and circular economy packages. Yes, we need to line up the future, set out what are going to be the next steps, because we are seeing the exponential growth of the challenges. That means that we need to act now, and we need to act with the right level of ambition. I would have five suggestions.  Firstly, the monitoring platform. That is linked to sustainable finance, put it to work and harmonise the indicators and lifecycle analyses. Secondly, the renewable eco-design directives, so that it is horizontal. Thirdly, specific programmes on food, sustainable food, so this concerns the whole lifecycle, buildings – they are a major element – and textiles, there is going to be a growing challenge in the area. And then on sustainable finance we need to review the existing financial regulation to include the sustainability principles. I would say yes, it’s pretty much there where we can gain the sustainable elements if we can make the Commission deliver and then Parliament and the Council to deliver in turn.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Thank you, Chairman. Let me thank you for submitting this document, at the end of this parliamentary term. This is very important because we must now have the debate and lay the foundations for the next parliamentary term. We in Europe often have the complacency to consider ourselves world leaders on climate and sustainable development goals. Let's be humble. Let me take climate. We have done a great deal this term. We should be proud of that. But it's not enough to get the Paris agreement. With the same modesty, we must look at the sustainable development goals and implement them here with us. This is extremely important: not only in the rest of the world but here with us. And that, as far as we are concerned, represents a radical reversal of policy in Europe and of our economic model. And then I'm going to go to the three proposed scenarios. For our group, there is only one scenario. I want to be very clear about that. The other two can help, but they are insufficient, because either they are refocusing on the rest of the world, or they are focusing on adapting some legislation here and there. Madam President, we only see the first scenario in which we turn the Economic Governance story of the European Union upside down and turn it into a pact for sustainable development. Thank you, Chairman and Vice-Presidents.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Much has been said that young people in particular are very concerned about the future of our planet at the moment. Mr Katainen said: 'We only have one planet', Mr Timmermans recalled the sustainable development goals. That is absolutely right; we have to take care of it. I would now like to focus in particular on something that is usually not so much in focus in this debate, namely marine protection and the oceans. Oceans are hugely important for our climate. They produce oxygen, they bind CO2, but they are also very much destroyed by the climate, by climate change with in detriment or disadvantaged and disturbed, partially destroyed. It is essential that we do something to prevent this and to improve it. We have already achieved a great deal through the plastics strategy, through the appropriate single-use plastic legislation, through marine waste disposal in ports. But there must be much more, because seas are also very important for the sustainable future of our planet. They are very important as someone who supplies raw materials and can bring blue biotechnology, a lot of blue economy. But this can only be done if we protect the seas. That is why this is absolutely part of this debate.

name: Maria Heubuch (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, you have a very urgent tone in this reflection paper, but the tone does not fit with the slow deeds. Firstly, why does the paper come three and a half years after we discussed the 2030 Agenda at United Nations level? And now we lack the concrete implementation plan. I am also annoyed at what we are discussing here in Scenarios 2 and 3. They are absolutely not forward-looking. Scenario 3 takes us back to the year 2000, to the Millennium Goals. It cannot be! Only Scenario 1 fulfils this transformation al'a-year claim that we have in the 2030 Agenda.  But now, for example, we are discussing agricultural policy, which does not correspond to this at all, but which will apply until 2027, and then we have exactly three years left to implement. Let us implement it now! Let us take this very scenario 1 and incorporate it into current policy so that we can do justice to what we have set ourselves as our goal.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I also very much welcome this report, although it comes at the end of the parliamentary term, but let us therefore take it as a very good starting material for the next administration, for the next Commission and for the next Parliament. Personally, I would also be a little more ambitious in describing the specific objectives and the specific layout of their achievement. Personally, I am in the lead-up to the first scenario of a Pan-European strategy. I could talk about individual parts here: air, waste, water, etc., but my colleagues have already done so.  I would add one more topic, which has not been raised here and which I subjectively consider important and which relates to sustainable development and human relationship to the environment. And this is the topic of the status of animals. I am a member of the intergroup here, in the European Parliament, which is now supporting the initiative 'Banning cage time' to improve animal welfare in the EU and to ban cage farming. I think that when we talk about the environment, about how to ensure a decent environment for people, we should not forget that the issue of animal status is also related to this – albeit indirectly – and we should also mention this subject and not just talk selfishly about our environment. So please, Commissioner, also see this initiative, 350 000 signatures have already been collected across Europe. In the autumn, the necessary million should already be collected, and certainly the topic not only of the environment of people, but also of animals should be addressed.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I also welcome this report at the end of my mandate. This report should be the guide to our policy and the programme of the future Commission from the beginning of next year. Indeed, we are coming to the end of an economic, neoliberal model that today shows its limits. 'All profit', 'all growth' and GDP as the only indicator show that things need to change and that this model is not up to the ambitions of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals voted in 2015. And our public policies should be conditioned by a number of elements. Today, 40% of insects are disappearing on our planet: this is a major indicator. We can no longer continue our public policies as we have done in the past and we must take into account, who in cohesion with the 30% climate target, who in the CAP, our main public policy, to put food and human health back at the heart of the political debate. We can no longer pursue this kind of public policy as we have done in the past. Yes, this is a major issue: we must collectively take the measure of our responsibility for the future of Europe and the planet as a whole.

name: Bogusław Sonik (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Over the past three years, The Member States of the European Union have taken the lead in overcoming the challenges of achieving the SDGs, such as ensuring coherence with other international commitments, working on establishing indicators and monitoring mechanisms, or supporting developing countries. The publication of the Commission's analytical document 'Towards a sustainable Europe by 2030' is therefore to be welcomed, which sets out three scenarios on how the European Union can continue to achieve the SDGs. Unfortunately, the relatively late release of the analytical document, initially scheduled for 2018, will prevent the current Commission from providing the necessary political time for the implementation of the strategy in this area, in line with the October recommendations of the European Council. In my opinion, only the first scenario presented in the document on a cross-cutting strategy would represent progress in the current situation.  This is an ambitious and complex scenario that will require a coherent position of the Countries of the European Union on the achievement of the objectives. I therefore hope that the analytical document and strategy, which the committee is expected to be ready for in April this year, will be taken as an important signal to the new College of Commissioners and Parliament.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner Katainen is right to say first of all that, if we really want to move towards the objectives of sustainable development, we need a lot of training, a lot of training. Perhaps a course could be offered to our Transport Minister, who just yesterday presented an environmental impact assessment in which he seems to show that it is much better to send goods and people on TIRs and cars than on trains, as we believe is better here in Europe, but we can also demonstrate this with the data. Secondly, I would like to thank the Commission for this report. I believe that this is a good basis, as many of my fellow Members have said, for the future. In the next term of office, I believe that we must transform this relationship into concrete working instruments, taking together, as many of my fellow Members have said, the social aspects ...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: President. –
text: If you’re wondering why I’m particularly strict this morning, it’s because all of us were here until ten minutes past midnight last night, as debates overran significantly, and I don’t want to see that happen today. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Progress in achieving the SDGs in the European Union has been good, especially in the fight against poverty or the promotion of health. Against the background of other parts of our world, it looks pretty good. However, the fact that we are a leader should not complacency, but commit us to setting the next steps towards full achievement of our objectives. In the years to come, we will face huge challenges in terms of prudent management of natural resources, the transition to a circular economy or efficient energy. In order to develop and implement good solutions, we need cooperation at both international and local level, namely the involvement of the Commission, governments, but also NGOs and companies. The new Strategic Plan for the European Union should set out the lines of action and identify tools for their implementation by these actors.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, I will not talk about whether the document is delayed or that it is not good. I agree with what the Commissioners have put forward here, but I will stop at the fact that we need to put everything we say better. We are issuing a lot of documents here, but there is a very big difference between reflection and action and, Mr Timmermans and Commissioner, a sustainable economy means people's lives and it means citizens' confidence in the European project.  We all want to resist this European project and, for this, I think we need to think about how we can define concepts the same for everyone, how we can apply them transparently to everyone, because it was said here that there have been crises in various states - in France, in Italy, in the Netherlands, in Romania, my country - , but, you see, these crises have been treated differently and this does not give confidence for a sustainable European Union. I agree with Scenario 1, as my colleagues have said, but I think we need to define our concepts correctly.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, sustainable development will either be human-centred or will not exist at all. This means, therefore, that we should be interested in the well-being of the many, not the few. There must certainly also be intervention in terms of production and consumption, as Mr Timmermans rightly observed. But we also need to look at the issue of allocation, because the distribution must be fair. A great wealth is produced in the European Union and worldwide, but unfortunately it is not distributed correctly, it is not distributed fairly. There are layers of society that are left behind, and that is why our interventions must support those who actually live in poverty, in unemployment. This means interventions at the level of the economy, supporting the circular economy, supporting education, training, research and technology. It means a different model and it also means fair trade policies; that is where we need to work.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this material, although I also think that it may have come a little earlier. A sustainable approach is indeed a key demand for our future. It should be reflected in all our policies and we have to recognise that we still have large reserves, it is also a matter of implementation. We are actually "burning" the ground under our feet, many pretend that nothing is happening yet, they still feel that the party is continuing. But that's not really the case. Climate change, biodiversity, emissions, plastics, ocean infestation, these are all huge challenges. I firmly believe that the EU, as a community of states, is ready to face these challenges, and I think that the young generation, as has already been mentioned here, knows very fundamentally that its future is in jeopardy. They're calling for us to do more. And I agree with the Commissioner, we only have one planet to sit on, but other planets, let's try to save ours.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Frans, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Europe, with its 17 2030 development goals, has an outstanding opportunity to bring together social, environmental and economic justice issues. This applies to Europe, but also to the whole world. These objectives must become the catalyst and engine of our European policy.  I am grateful that you said at last week's hearing that if you were to become President of the Commission, you would make it a matter of the boss and put that in every Commissioner's portfolio. You said that we have to adjust our consumption and production behaviour accordingly. That is precisely what is important. We have started with this on the subject of conflict minerals. We must move on. The Germans and the Dutch have launched a textile initiative to this end, which is now co-conditional in legally binding due diligence obligations. This is an important step, and it is a clear policy, including social democratic ones, that we stand for. Udo Bullmann said: We must now not only talk about scenarios, but act and implement them. I call on all of us to do so, and I invite us all to do so. This is an exciting new way of making policy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, any policy that does not point to sustainability is the past, and in this respect the European Union's policies are at the forefront of the world. Over the years, Europe has become a pioneer in the field of sustainability, with one of the highest social and environmental standards in the world. But the challenges to be faced are complex, changeable and urgent: from ecological debt to climate change, from democratic changes to migration, from inequality to economic and social convergence.  The reflection paper on a sustainable Europe by 2030 pushes forward the policies already set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, and in particular in the UN 2030 agenda. Potentially, the circular economy is capable of creating more than a million new jobs across the Union, and clean energy can create as many. In my opinion, however, the document lacks the critical part, namely a reflection and an analysis of what has slowed down and made it impossible to achieve the Europe 2020 objectives.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in meeting the sustainable development objectives there is much work to be done. The failure to achieve in the objective of sustainable production and consumption or in sustainability of the oceans, seas and their resources is inadmissible. Even in the energy field, where we can proudly say that the European Union has managed to decouple emissions and economic growth, it must be admitted that emissions have grown again in 2017. You can't fool yourself. The only path to development is social and environmental sustainability. And meeting the goals of sustainable development is a moral imperative. The conservation of the planet requires decisive action, without pauses. This is urgently needed to avoid the worst consequences of climate change.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work on I hope that you will be the future President, because I am sure that you will be represented in the Commission in future in scenario 1 and that we will have the best starting point. But we must not make it too easy for ourselves. This Parliament here is an equal player. We need to show – not only now in the election campaign, but also in the constant debate – who the forces are, who are the individual Members of this House who are working to ensure that this sustainable policy in Europe, whether on climate issues, whether on agricultural issues or on social issues, is not being implemented. Because we have heard it again today: these are the Members of this House who are spreading fake news, who make unjustified, scientifically unsustainable claims that climate policy puts jobs at risk, that a sustainable agricultural policy without pesticides endangers our agriculture. These are the fake news that we must fight – now in the election campaign and in the debate every day. I believe that the Commission has presented something good. It will be up to us to implement it.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for the ideas expressed in this lively debate on sustainability. First, I want to say it would be a mistake to think nothing has been done during this Commission’s term of office, and to see this just as a starting point, when we start doing something. I would like to give you a couple of examples, namely the Paris Agreement and our climate legislation, the circular economy package, the plastics strategy, the social dimension and the investment plan for Europe, to mention just a few concrete examples of measures already adopted which will have a significant impact on sustainability in the future. I have tried to take two different ways of looking at sustainability in Europe. The first concerns social sustainability. I have visited many of our Member States, and I have seen that there are those which are advanced in social dialogue between employees and employers about how to reskill people already in jobs; and there are those which, basically, have not done anything. I am afraid this issue may become a new dividing line in Europe. There are countries which understand that we have to pay more attention than before to re-skilling. There are also countries that pay more attention than others to the quality of teacher training and education internally. If Member States – our governments and the social partners – don’t take more seriously the challenge of skills and the quality of basic education, then we cannot be successful. This is my first message. I believe that education – training and reskilling people – is the most important social factor in relation to sustainability. Then, looking at the economic angle, I would like to mention the circular economy, including product-design policies and sustainable finance – those three concrete issues. They are the issues which, I believe, matter most with regard to improving sustainability. I had a discussion with several representatives of financial institutions, who are pleading with us to create a clear taxonomy and a classification of sustainable finance. They are saying that their clients are asking for more sustainable assets. And this is exactly what the Commission is working on at the moment. We have to let the financial sector act to change the world. They are willing to do it, because their clients, us, and consumers are asking them to do it. So, if we manage to create sustainable finance criteria and a taxonomy, I’m sure that hundreds of billions of euro will shift direction and this, honourable Members, will change the world, including through the circular economy. The private sector is leading the show here at moment, and this House has been extremely supportive and innovative, supporting too the developments in product-design policy because we, as consumers, are asking for more sustainable business models, more sustainable ways to consume and more durable and repairable products. So I am not worried at all about whether we can achieve the sustainable development goals, if we just manage to pick the right things to change and also, especially, if we keep the private sector onboard – because it’s not only us, as legislators or regulators, who can change the world. It’s also private operators. Our role is to create a better playing field, a more sustainable regulatory environment, which will enables us and other stakeholders to do the trick.  I believe we can combine social equality, social sustainability, environmental sustainability and sustainable economic growth in the future, and it should not be rocket science!

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today, our economic system, the way we produce and consume, is leading to a serious environmental crisis. Social and environmental problems are connected and cause injustices that always affect the most vulnerable. The Socialists are proposing profound economic, social and ecological change, part of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals 2030. We understand that this change must focus on five areas: empowering people as citizens in democracy, not just consumers, from the local to European levels, and as members of trade unions and civil society organisations; change and limit capitalism to ensure that private economic activity considers the social and environmental impact and contributes to a better distribution of wealth and income; achieve social justice without anyone being left behind; generate ecological and social progress; facilitate change in EU governance and working methods to achieve a sustainable and egalitarian Europe, with a new governance framework for Sustainable Development, which sets out a set of binding policy objectives that go beyond the strict fiscal objectives of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Andrey Novakov and Constanze Krehl, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund Plus, the Cohesion Fund, and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and financial rules for those (COM(2018)0375 – C8-0230/2018 – 2018/0196(COD)) (A8-0043/2019).

name: Andrey Novakov
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I prefer to deliver my speech in Bulgarian. First of all, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur, Mrs Krell, for the cooperation, all the colleagues on the Committee on Regional Development and its Chair, all the colleagues from budgets, transport who have joined this work. This was cooperation in the name of cohesion policy. This was cooperation in the name of all regions of the European Union – for the sake of the poorest, for the sake of the more developed, in the name of the mountainous, in the name of the coastal, for the sake of the outermost, for the sake of rural regions, for the sake of all. For too long, cohesion policy has been used as a bargaining chip. It was taken for granted by one and by others as a gift. Of course, neither is true. With its more than 30 years of history, cohesion policy has become a value, it has long gone beyond just programmes, funds, initiatives and instruments. She lined up alongside everything else that holds this Union together. Cohesion policy is the glue that holds Member States together in this European Union. That's why he needs our support.  And yes, that means more funding. And yes, that means we're going to push for $47 billion more. And yes, this means that the poorest regions have to pay less co-financing for this policy. And yes, that means we have to get behind it for very traditional investments. There are still regions in the European Union that need better roads, faster trains, larger ports and more airports. This is the world we live in. From now on, something very important lies ahead. I hear colleagues say "This is going to be a clash between populism and traditional parties, between extremism and the more moderate ones." From now on, there are only two paths – up and down. This report means upwards. This report means a stronger European Union because it is a slap in the face to populism. It means Europe is visible. It means Europe gets to everyone. It means that Europe is measurable, that it is understandable. If there are people here who love the European Union, it means they must also love the farthest village in this European Union. If they care about him, it means they're holding on to the last person who lives worse than everyone else. And as long as there is such a village, as long as there is such a person, there must also be a cohesion policy.  From now on, dear colleagues, there is a huge challenge ahead. We were only able to get to this stage after ten months of work. It was extremely important because we have shown that this European Parliament thinks of the people who elected it from the outside. Because in just 100 days we will be judged on how well we have done, what we have done and what we have not been able to do. And we'il have answers. What and how much will the regions in the European Union receive, how much farmers will receive, how much will be received by rural regions, how much there will be for ecology, how much there will be for infrastructure, how much there will be for students, how much there will be for agriculture. Most of all, what will be the rules to which they will have to obey, what will be the conditions they must meet. Our central task was to get this job done and get it done in due course. That's why I'm glad we were able to do it. From now on, there is only one thing left – to communicate the end of this work in an understandable human language, because all these funds, all these initiatives exist for the sake of people. They exist for people, for business, for students, for farmers, for everyone else. That's why we have to tell it in their language, because Europe works for them, contrary to everything populists say.

name: Constanze Krehl
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The rapporteurs presented a report on future cohesion policy in September. We worked on more than two and a half thousand amendments together with the shadow rapporteurs and the committee and voted on them on 22 January. Why have we put forward such a pace? We want to start negotiations on the future cohesion policy with the Council quickly, because I believe that we owe it to the citizens, the regions, the cities and the municipalities, that they have planning certainty, for which they can spend their money after 2020, and that they can start to implement their ideas. I think we are proposing a good compromise to the House to decide on this today. We are asking for EUR 378 billion for cohesion policy for all the regions in the European Union. And it is precisely after the previous debate on sustainability that I am pleased to say that we are proposing to you that 30% of regional policy's resources be used against climate change. I believe that this is a very important signal that we are sending out. We want the regions to continue to be divided into three categories: the less developed, the more developed and the transitional regions. I believe that this meets the needs of the regions. We want – and here we support the Commission – that the European Union should become smarter – which is always good – to become more social and greener, but also to be closer to the citizens and for us to be better connected, so that both the communication and digital infrastructure swell. We are following the Commission in the proposals for massive simplification of procedures. We support that. But we are also again committed to a very strong partnership principle: the involvement of the economic and social partners on the one hand, but also of local committed Members in county councils, in the city councils, and in the NGOs, which are actively active in the regions. We want the child guarantee to be included in the European Social Fund. We want the social pillar and national energy and climate plans to be included in the strategic planning of future operational programmes. The European Parliament has raised the co-financing rates of the European funds to the current level for the regions, and even a little more for the transitional categories, so that there are also sufficient opportunities to be able to provide the co-financing that must be made at national level. It is also important to say at this point that we do not forget the outermost regions, which sometimes seem so far away, but which are important for our European Union and which hope that the European Union will continue to support them in the future. Just as we demand that we have a safety net for regions that unexpectedly find their way into strange situations. Let me give you an example: a region is better divided in the current funding period, comes into a lower status of economic development and will receive even less money in the future. It cannot be! I believe that we must do something about this. I am very pleased that we are introducing an article that focuses on general horizontal conditions and criteria such as respect for human rights, gender equality, anti-discrimination, sustainability objectives and much more, including future cohesion policy. And I am very pleased that, with the European Social Fund (ESF+), we are taking up the fight against youth unemployment, the fight against poverty and social inclusion, and are making significantly more money available for it. For my group, two things are still particularly important: we do not want there to be a link between European regional policy and macroeconomic conditionality in the future. We do not think that is appropriate. And a second important point: I am very pleased that we can propose to the House that the rural development fund should be brought back a little more under the umbrella of cohesion policy. For us, the development of rural areas is more than just the promotion of farmers. We must make much greater efforts to take these regions with us and develop them further.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think today is a very important moment. We are talking about common provisions, regulation of the European Regional Development Fund and other European funds for seven years, from 2021-2027. It is a key milestone in our preparation for post-2020. I would like to thank all of you for your contribution. It’s very important that we are going to have a new regulation based on the lessons we have learned over the last years.  For simplification purposes, for the first time there is just one regulation to cover all shared seven management funds. You know very well that everywhere I have been since becoming Commissioner I have heard the same complaints, and I really was very sad to meet young people who had given up using our funds because of bureaucracy, because of complications and lending regulations. So now we have a handbook. We have this one regulation to cover all seven shared management funds and it is a milestone in terms of the quality of Parliament’s report. I would like to thank both Ms Krehl and Mr Novakov, all Members of the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) – Ms Mihaylova, the Chair, and the others – and all those who contributed to this report. You really deserve a high prize for the efficiency and quality of the work done in such a short time. I warmly welcome your support for key elements of the Commission proposal, and of course, I rely on you, I ask for your continued support to ensure that these elements are maintained and they are not watered down during the negotiations. For us, these elements include, very importantly, first a partnership agreement for all 27 Member States and for all seven funds. You know that in the COREPER there is this idea to have different standards for different countries and your report rightly placed great emphasis on strategies and coordination. We cannot accept double standards. We cannot accept coordination for some Member States but not others and we cannot accept coordination of some funds but not others. I really hope that I can count on your support on this.  The second key element is about new policy objectives. Here again, I wish to thank you for your support. We all want, as Ms Krehl said, a Europe that is smarter, greener, more connected, more social and closer to the citizens. Our five new policy objectives are a step in the right direction and, for us, it is very important to remain like this during the negotiations. A third key element is a meaningful midterm review. Here, of course, I know that this is not a unanimous approach but I would ask you to keep an open mind. I believe that five plus two programming is necessary for a meaningful review. Our experience shows that when funding is all programmed at the beginning, it is less flexible. During this programming period there were so many unexpected events – like migrants, like Caterpillar in Belgium, like earthquakes in Italy. So we need to be flexible. We have tried to respond to these new challenges. Deleting five plus two programming represents, in our view, a step backwards, a step away from flexibility. Our first key element is simplification. I started with this and I want to close with this. Thank you for your support on this. Thank you for the belief in our common efforts for simplification, because the many simplifications in our proposals are based on suggestions and ideas from all Member States and all families. In fact, as you know, we have a Simplification Handbook. We have simplified and streamlined programmes that have been set up. We have simplified payment claims. We have simplified the audit process. Your continued support here is crucial in both the short and long terms, ensuring that simplifications are not watered down, that they continue to strike the right balance. In conclusion, it is now time to open discussions from the trilogue. Beginning with this vote today we can start the trilogue. I want to thank you, because Parliament has already showed its readiness in terms of this report. Of course I also asked the Council to maintain the momentum into the trilogues, because we must maintain the momentum, and we must also maintain the quality of the proposals for an effective, dynamic, modern and cohesive policy. Time is short and we really need to work hard and fast. You know very well that our estimation is that if we don’t start the implementation from the first day of the next programming period – 1 January 2021 – more than 100 000 projects in all 28 Member States will be at risk of not being completed with European money. It’s in our power to do the best we can.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, I think it is safe to say this morning that this regulation that we are voting on today is one of the most important pieces of legislation that we have voted on in this mandate and I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs for all of the work which they have done. Why do I say this is important? It is important because it lays down the founding principles of how EU Structural Funds will be spent in the seven years after 2021. We might not yet have concrete amounts of money, and this is particularly due to the delays in the Council – I would like to understand – but our position, the vote in Parliament, will define how money is spent, to whom it goes and under which circumstances. From the Committee on Budget’s point of view, my mission was to make sure that Parliament’s position on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) is also part of this regulation and we demand two things. Firstly, that the amounts for cohesion policy stay at the same level or increase, because people in Europe expect more growth, more competitiveness, better infrastructure, and we cannot do more with less. And our second demand is simplification, certainty for our beneficiaries, and this is why I call on the Council to stop dragging their feet, to enter into trilogue so that we give certainty to EU beneficiaries as soon as possible.

name: Iris Hoffmann
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done It is important to strengthen the visibility and commitment of the European Union in local and local communities, so that people can turn more towards the EU and have a positive perception of European policies. European cohesion policy is more important than ever in times of right-wing populism and Euroscepticism and one of the crucial instruments for building bridges and ensuring economic, social and territorial cohesion in all regions. After all, even beyond the centres and capitals, people must feel that the European Union can be experienced on the ground. An important part of the reform we are discussing here is the reduction of bureaucracy. The deficits are clearly noticeable here. This is reported to us time and again in our constituencies. But the budget is also crucial. Even in the new funding period of the multiannual financial framework and despite difficult circumstances with Brexit, we must maintain and even expand support for all communities and regions in perspective.

name: Ivana Maletić
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the ECON Committee. – Madam Chairman, Madam Commissioner, I am pleased that today we all agreed that it is very important to increase funding for cohesion policy, which colleague Mureşan said in front of the Budget Committee, that it is also very important to increase co-financing, that it is important to simplify implementation procedures and that it is important to say "no" to slowing down programming.  What is important from the point of view of the ECON Committee is that European funds are an important source of funding, but that they cannot deliver results unless they are part of the overall policy in the Member States related to reforms that will improve business conditions, speed up decision-making processes, speed up judgments and judicial efficiency, efficiency and the work of public administration and local self-government. Without this, we cannot have real and real results in practice, which are economic growth, development and improving the living standards of our people. That's what we've been pushing for.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: rapporteur for empl opinion. – Thank you, Chairman. In 2014, President Juncker promised that people could count on a social union. The so-called social AAA status is the cherished desire of many. It is my belief that the proposal contributes to this. Because red tape for the regions is being cut and the flexibility between the funds is increasing. This benefits all Europeans, especially those in regions that are struggling. Nevertheless, I believe that social AAA status cannot be achieved if we do not make the link with the European Pillar of Social Rights more concrete. That is why I support the amendments from Parliament that will ensure the anchoring of the child guarantee to eliminate child poverty. I support the ADJUSTMENTS made by the EP for higher co-financing and the removal of macroeconomic conditionality. These changes are also taking social Europe one step closer. Thank you very much.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: draftsman of the TRAN opinion. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The Committee on Transport agreed with the main objective of this project, which is to reduce the bureaucracy involved in issuing and accounting for European funds. However, we have sent a clear signal that we do not agree with the large cuts in cohesion policy proposed by the Commission, particularly in the area of infrastructure investment. The Committee on Transport has also been unequivocal in favour of maintaining the principle of the national envelope allocation of all the funds transferred from the Cohesion Fund to the Connecting Europe Facility. This is an additional incentive for countries that use the funds allocated effectively and quickly. One such primate here is undoubtedly Poland, which has used the entire pool of funds allocated in this way for the period 2014-2020. It is efficiency in achieving cohesion policy objectives – not current political sympathies or ideology – that should be the most important criterion for the distribution of European funds. I regret that this report does not maintain the right proportions in this area.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: libe committee rapporteur. – Madam President, I always support all initiatives that lead to simplification. I think that we all know that, unfortunately, the use of European money is a very complex process, often cluttered, opaque in many Member States, which is why I think it is a good thing that we have tried to correct the mistakes that have repeatedly appeared in the past in relation to the use of money. The emphasis is mainly on the uniformity of the rules, harmonisation in the process of drawing from all funds, I also welcome the introduction of synergies between funds. At the same time, however, I draw attention to the risk of double funding. As a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have repeatedly pointed out here that sometimes these programmes are duplicated. That is why, at the beginning of this debate, I would also like to say that we must not underestimate the control mechanisms. But I certainly welcome all the rules contained in this regulation and the common provision.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, rapporteurs, Commissioner, with this general regulation, we are taking an important step towards eight funds, including the Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. This policy is carried out close to the people by the Member States, regions and cities, always in partnership, as Mrs Krehl also mentioned. We work everywhere, including more visibility of greenery, growth and jobs. It's good that we're stopping the plethora of logos that are on all those signs, and that we're putting a lot more emphasis on what people achieve in those projects. Let the star shine. They are proud people in social projects, economic projects, etc. Let's give them the strength. Fortunately, we also set aside pennies for that. It is also good that we are increasing the synergy between different Union funds, such as Horizon Europe, and, where necessary, making transfers possible. An important point for the EPP is that it is not right for parts of Europe to depopulate. You just see a population flight in rural areas, while other parts of Europe are booming and developing rapidly. That's not good. That is not the image we have in mind with cohesion. We want a permanently balanced, forward-looking, solidarity and competitive Europe that activates people. The use of a third of the EU budget requires good rules of the game and good economic management. The rapporteurs Krehl and Novakov have reached a compromise to give substance to this macro-conditionality in a very acceptable way, not by deleting payments, but by not making new commitments. I call on you to support that compromise in the future. Two more comments. First, Amendment 429. This is about regions that fall into a different category and then go backwards at once. I ask for support for this. Finally, I would like to ask the Commissioner to take action for the regions affected by Brexit and which are in additional costs.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for their excellent work and the Commissioner for her initial proposal. Firstly, as Mr van Nistelrooij has already mentioned, I believe that we should manage the funds so that no one is left behind – nor the people, and that means targeting urban policies, peripheral areas, areas in greatest difficulty – but not even the territories, and therefore we really need to build that agenda for mountain, rural and outermost areas, which we have repeatedly called for to be implemented and drafted by our Commissioner. The third point I wanted to reflect on is that I do not agree that macroeconomic conditionality should remain, albeit with changes. We must know that this only serves to make the citizens and countries hate the European Union. Rather, we use policies to encourage us to do well, not punitive policies.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Madam Chairman, as shadow rapporteur on behalf of the ECR Club, I have participated in the drafting of this important legislative proposal and I can say that I am satisfied with the work done. I would like to thank the rapporteurs and other shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and congratulate them on a quality final text that I am sure will be adopted. I am particularly pleased that through the amendments I have been able to add important items to the final text for less developed members who are still quite dependent on cohesion policy.  In particular, I would like to highlight the higher pre-financing rate of EU projects, greater flexibility and retention of N+3 rules. It is especially important to maintain the N+3 rule as it allows for a longer absorption period so that they are fully used where they are needed most.  When making such important decisions, we should take into account the context. There are still large differences in development between Member States, and within each of them we have inequality between different regions. This has always been and will be because we are not all the same, nor have we had the same development path, but it is our responsibility to mitigate these differences so that the Union develops evenly. Cohesion policy is extremely valuable in this regard and we must work to strengthen it, taking into account that the conditions for application, especially for centrally managed funds, are adapted to those most in need. Thus, less developed members with less administrative capacity and a lack of experience in absorption of European funds.  Brexit creates a financial hole that will not be easy to patch up, but solidarity is not something to be spared on. It is one of the main values of this community and without it, membership of the Union to less developed countries becomes much less tempting.

name: Искра Михайлова
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – First, I would like to start by thanking the two rapporteurs and what they did in preparation for the report, together with all my colleagues from the Committee on Regional Development in the European Parliament. For the Group of Liberals and Democrats in this Parliament, there are several key elements of the Common Provisions Regulation that give the face of the reformed cohesion policy and are in the context of the philosophy of the post-2020 multiannual financial framework. , but also with the challenges facing the European Union and regions, the possibility of transferring resources between programmes, funds and instruments of European aid.  Secondly, it is crucial for us at ALDE to build a clear and predictable link between the European Semester and the European Structural and Investment Funds that can deliver effectiveness. The effectiveness of reforms and reformed policies is key to increasing the effectiveness of cohesion policy. In this sense, macroeconomic conditionalities are an important tool for improving cohesion policy. Last but not least, the link of cohesion policy with instruments such as InvestEU or Connecting Europe Facility is crucial for increasing the effectiveness of the Common European Investment Policy. Only in this way could we achieve modernisation, reforms and a clear policy that would give clear signs to European citizens.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, I think I can say that with this proposal, the European Parliament is positioning itself as the best defender of a strong and ambitious cohesion policy, as we need a great policy of solidarity to reduce territorial divides in a European Union that has been disfigured by austerity policies. Our Committee on Regional Development is almost unanimous in considering that a reduction in the budget cannot be accepted and the ball will be, after the vote of this report, in the Council's camp; I call on him not to sacrifice traditional policies of solidarity in support of our territories. I would like to thank all my colleagues and rapporteurs for proposing to maintain budgets for the outermost regions and for increasing co-financing for all the regions that are lagging behind in development and the RUPs (ultra-peripheral regions) in particular, and I would also like to thank the European Commission for putting forward a number of proposals in its initial proposal, which I put forward in my report. There are still macroeconomic conditionalities, which we reject. We call for a vote on the amendment that we have tabled to remove them.

name: Monika Vana
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking the two rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation.  This umbrella regulation is certainly one of the most important dossiers of the expiring period and sets the course for regional policy from 2021 to 2027. I think the result is really a success for the strength and quality of cohesion policy. With this umbrella regulation, as a Parliament, we are securing a strong position of cohesion policy for the future and, as Constanze Krehl has already said, we want to enter into negotiations with the Council soon. We Greens, too, see cohesion policy as a visible sign of European solidarity. In some regions, the only public investment is the money spent on this. They are used to combat climate change, to combat poverty, and they create jobs. They are important for investment in research and development and for cross-border projects.  It was very important to us Greens in the negotiations that all regions continue to benefit from cohesion policy and that the partnership principle and the involvement of local and regional stakeholders, the social partners, but especially civil society, be strengthened.  We have paid particular attention to the preservation and also the development of horizontal principles. This means equality, not discrimination, sustainable development and respect for human rights. Climate protection will also be strengthened, which was of course a particular concern for us Greens; climate proofing and the 30% target are certainly important milestones in the further development of regional policy. From a green point of view, we are very critical of the transfer possibilities to other EU funds. I am therefore pleased that we have found a compromise that limits it very much. We too, of course, reject the macroeconomic conditions in regional policy. We think it is wrong for regions to be cut because the budgetary and deficit criteria are not to be met at national level.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in this regulation on common provisions on European funds, the European Parliament has significantly improved the Commission's proposal. We have an increase in global resources, a greater focus on environmental and social issues, an increase in the cofinancing rate. There are, however, two fundamental issues that are lacking, and on which we have tabled four amendments: the revision of the investment clause, in order to allow regional and national investments cofinanced through the European Structural and Investment Funds to be excluded from the calculation of national public deficits within the framework of the European Semester, and above all the cancellation of macro-condition. We are talking about a truly absurd, unfair and penalising mechanism, which provides for the suspension of funds for states that do not respect the absurd diktats of austerity coming from Brussels.  We talk so much about Europe to change, we have been talking about it here since 2014, and now many political groups and parties seem to be waking up and debating it. But it is from here, from the clear votes on these issues that are fundamental to the citizens and to our territories, that change passes. A different Europe is achieved through work, through the construction of real mechanisms of solidarity and social cohesion, certainly not with a pseudo-European façade that bends to the logic, which, moreover, logically has very little, of economic governance.

name: President. –
text: I will speak at length to allow our next speaker, Mr Briois, to catch his breath. Shall I give you the floor now?

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I draw your attention to Article 15 of this regulation with common provisions. Regulations that will set the terms of use of EU funds for the period 2021-2027. This article thus offers the Commission the possibility of suspending the European funds of a state that does not respect the budgetary policy dictated to it by Brussels. Tomorrow, in concrete terms, the European Commission will be able to tell a Member State... (the President interrupts the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Excuse me, Mr Briois. I am going to give the floor to Mr Balczó for one minute for you to catch your breath, so that might be helpful.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The union's fundamental objective is to reduce social and economic development differences between Member States. The proposal put forward by the Commission for a seven-year budget does not meet this expectation. Cohesion funds would be reduced by 10%. Parliament does not accept this and intends to restore it to its current level of resources. In order to achieve this objective, the most efficient use of resources must be made, in particular to prevent EU funds from flowing and leaking through the channels of corruption. The European Public Prosecutor's Office could be a means of doing this. Unfortunately, several countries have not joined this, and in their case meaningful cooperation with OLAF must be expected. It is unacceptable that, when the EU Anti-Fraud Office has uncovered documented, factually serious abuses, no meaningful action is taken by the law enforcement authorities of the Member States.

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I draw your attention to Article 15 of this regulation with common provisions, which will set the conditions for the use of European funds for the period 2021-2027. This article thus offers the Commission the possibility of suspending the European funds of a state that does not respect the budget line dictated to it by Brussels. Tomorrow, in concrete terms, the European Commission will be able to tell a country that it is spending too much, that it does not have an economic vision to the taste of Brussels. So, of course, I'll tell you right away, there will be on one side the privileged and on the other the plagued. There will be friendly governments that are a bit of the darlings of the Commission, like Mr Macron's - since it can already exceed the 3% deficit without being worried by the European Commission - and then there will be the others, that is, the plagued, the bad, the populists. Those who, as in Italy with Salvini, can exceed 3% but who will be punished. It is a strange conception of democracy, a strange conception of respect for the rule of law. Therefore, to accept this scandalous blackmail to European funds on the part of the Commission is to entrust it with the keys to our public finances and when I see the results of austerity policies in Greece, Portugal and Spain, it does not make us want at all. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: 'blue card' question. Mr President, we are once again seeing a Europe that is divided between the successful Member States and those that will have to catch up. This is partly because of austerity policies, which penalise some Member States whose economies are fragile. It is to this gap that is growing by the day that our cohesion policy aims to tackle. A policy that has the primary objective of converging and harmonizing our regions. However, the proposed regulation on which we will vote is accompanied by an article which enshrines austerity through macroeconomic conditionality. Article 15, which I think is counterproductive and contrary to our ideal of harmony and European unity. Article 15 that would impose a double penalty on the regions by making them responsible for government-led policies. Ladies and gentlemen, I therefore call on you to vote for the abolition of Article 15 and to honour our mandate by defending our ideal of cohesion and European unity.

name: El presidente.
text: – Mr Manscour, you had thirty seconds; consumed more than a minute and did not end up asking questions in the end. Therefore, I imagine that Mr Briois will have little to answer to him. However, it would be entitled to the floor. Would you like to speak, Mr. Briois? No? All right, then, Mr. Joulaud, your turn.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, cohesion policy is a European policy which is unfortunately too little talked about but which, as we know, is nevertheless essential for our territories and which embodies the Europe of proximity. It would of course be wrong to claim that this policy is perfect, but the text before us this morning is moving in the right direction. I would like to very quickly stress three points which I think are essential in the text we are considering. First, simplification. It cannot be said enough, but it is no longer acceptable for project owners to give up European funds because of a complexity that sometimes turns absurd. Second, cohesion policy needs to pay more attention to peripheral territories. The evolution of the category of regions in transition is good news for these territories, which are often caught between the major metropolises and the sometimes unfair competition from the least developed European regions. The situation in France is a reminder that these territories need to be better considered. Thirdly, a point that we have made with several colleagues about Brexit: several European regions are on the front line, they will soon become borders of the European Union. With the uncertainties that loom, with the risks that we know, Europe cannot remain wait-and-see, it must provide as soon as possible mechanisms and instruments of support on this crucial issue. I therefore call on the negotiators to keep these elements in mind in the discussions that will continue so that we work for a concrete, useful Europe and at the service of the citizens and our regions.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, for more than 20 years now, the Conservatives and Liberals in this House have been constantly trying to change this cohesion policy, which is a policy of solidarity, towards a policy of competitiveness. We see the result: Europe is in an environmental, social, economic and political crisis.
