So thank you to the two co-reporters who, through their amendments and their effective transformation of the Commission's proposal, have tried to give a sense of solidarity to this cohesion policy. Thank you for addressing the issue of simplification, for putting the "children's" guarantee in this project, for keeping all three types of regions and thus for strengthening the co-financing rates and the 30% on the climate issue that we all have. Today, the major issue is economic macro-conditionality. We cannot accept - and this has been said by several speakers - that the Commission of the European Union intervenes at the regional level if a Member State does not respect the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact. This is a notable inconsistency that will go against the development of our territories, at the european union level.

name: Sławomir Kłosowski (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent The impact of cohesion policy so far on the development of the European Union, including my country and the Opole-Lower Silesia region, has been unequivocally positive. European funds have had an impact on economic growth and the labour market. I appreciate the report's commitment to pragmatic clean-up of funds. The Polish delegation will therefore support the report. However, I strongly emphasise that I do not agree with attempts to politicise the allocation criteria, which, unfortunately, is very clear in the report. Cohesion policy must not be an attempt to influence the sovereign decisions of national authorities. Its aim should be to reduce developmental disparities, not to exert pressure. I therefore take a negative view of the provisions on attempts to impose social, migration, energy and undefined rule of law principles on countries in the document.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg (ALDE).
text: Mr President, cohesion policy is the most important investment policy of the European Union with the European Structural and Investment Funds. With hundreds of billions in these funds, we want to achieve results towards a smarter, greener and more social Europe, a Europe that connects leaders and laggards. However, it is essential that we renew the rules for the use of funds, by giving Member States the voluntary choice to use some of the money differently, for example through InvestEU, by expecting Member States to abide by budget agreements, by establishing a strong link between the funds and the European Semester, but also by allowing the Cohesion Fund to contribute to the realisation of the trans-European transport networks. Only under this condition, with a more modern cohesion policy, can we really make the investments we make with these funds in the future. Thank you.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. However, with all the necessary willingness to compromise and many commendable things, with which we agree, I would like to make two criticisms very clear. Firstly, the EU Structural Funds are not suitable as a criminal and coercive instrument for complying with debt brakes. They should encourage public investment, not choke it off or even punish it. Macroeconomic conditioning must therefore be abolished, as this House has repeatedly called for. There is absolutely no reason to buckle in anticipation of obedience to the Council and the Commission. Secondly, the possibility of transfer funds from the regional funds to InvestEU is, in our view, a gross mistake and runs counter to the objectives of cohesion policy, namely the approximation of living conditions. Limiting the transferable funds to 2.5% of structural funds is inconsistent, because it is absurd to cut off the ever-decreasing cohesion funds for the bloated InvestEU fund.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I would like to thank both the rapporteurs and everyone else for the great work they have done to reach an agreement. I am very pleased that, thanks to my initiative, the next financial period proposes not to reduce cohesion funding and not to reduce The European Union's support for co-financing individual projects. It is essential that, in determining the level of regional development at Union level, not only historical but also the new regional classification system adopted by the Commission in 2016 will be used to reduce disparities in the level of development of regional municipalities, as well as in countries such as Lithuania and the Czech Republic. It is also good news that Parliament's report includes and sets out support for community-led local development. I hope that the majority in Parliament will support these amendments.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the EU always proudly pontificates on how it’s chasing greater efficiency in how it spends money. Apart from the glaring fact that this is utter poppycock and you play a game of ‘what is the dumbest project we can fund this week?’, this is not the EU’s money. It’s taken from the pockets of the taxpayers from the individual nations to fund your insane and dangerous vanity project to create a modern Napoleonic empire. At what level did the EUR 400 000 you set aside in this budget for a Cheese Experience Centre in the Netherlands look like a smart way to burn taxpayers’ cash? There are lots more ways the EU has found to creatively destroy ordinary people’s money. Your much—lauded House of European History, a trip through your ideological looking glass, where you’ve applied a Marxist-style theory of historical inevitability to justify your empire, cost over EUR 55 million to build. I have an idea to chase greater financial efficiency. Let the other 27 nations follow the UK’s lead and leave this place, and let the individual nations and their peoples decide how and whether to spend their money.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: Mr President, I recently visited a regional development project in Bulgaria. A medieval fortress has been converted into a plastic castle with a nine million euro grant. The aim was to make it a tourist attraction. Anyway, you get it. There's not going to be a dog. I got there on Saturday afternoon at three o'clock and then an entrance ticket was hand-written and I had visitor number one. The biggest blow actually came in the evening. Then I had a conversation with Professor Gradev. He is professor of culture and religion at the University of Sofia. He told me that the 10th-century foundations of that fort were demolished, and then filled with concrete so that the plastic elements could be put on them. That's a sad but striking metaphor. The EU subsidizes the demolition of national historical foundations, not only in a physical sense, but also in a transferable sense, in a social sense, in a sociological sense. The only precondition for this is that it has to cost a lot of money. And who pays for that? The taxpayer.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, let us therefore expose the myths about financing regional development in the European Union. No Cohesion Fund or other fund brings convergence. Divergence only and inequality of states and regions, which is an iron law of capitalism and its unregulated development on the basis of profit. No program has stopped any crisis, nor will it catch up with the next one. Funding is linked to the European Semester and economic governance, blackmailing compliance with unpopular political reforms and lasting memoranda. The main thing is not the absorption of funds that governments, ministers, regional leaders and mayors pride themselves on, but where the money goes: to support large companies based on the Union's priorities. Popular needs for seismic, flood defence, fire-fighting, health, schools, popular housing and compensation for those affected are considered costs, degraded and excluded. Only the JRC claims this. Finally, the great myth: funding is not a gift from any European Union. They come out of the heavy taxation of the people, while businesses are exempt. This wealth, then, must be claimed by the people to satisfy their needs.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate the two rapporteurs, Constanze Krehl and Andrey Novakov, on their excellent work on this cohesion policy report.  This common regulation of funds, as it is today, succeeds in being an essential instrument enabling the eight European policies in areas of major importance to have a positive impact on the lives of the citizens of the European Union. We note further the need for real simplification in the process of absorbing European funds, as it is equally important, Commissioner, and I stress this, that the Member States do not add additional conditionalities beyond the Brussels rules, which makes the absorption process very difficult. I welcome, at the same time, the agreement at European Parliament level on the N+3 rule on the spending of European money, known as delays in this area, caused by various reasons, which are not, however, attributable to the beneficiaries. I hope that this will be maintained after the discussions in the trialogue. At the same time, I stress the need for greater synergy between European funds in various fields, which certainly increases the efficiency of the use of European money and has a major impact on increasing the quality of citizens' lives. Last but not least, success stories, such as those in the Leader programme, namely those of local action groups, need to be multiplied and moved to a higher stage of their exploitation by increasing their funding. Micro-regions need to gain greater powers in the process of absorbing European funds and in relation to the European Commission, reducing their dependence on national governments, which, paradoxically, can sometimes be hostile to them. They must be able to address the European Commission directly in order to obtain the European funding necessary for their development. One last point I would like to make is the one relating to visibility. Ladies and gentlemen, European citizens need to be informed and aware of the importance of European funds and the positive impact it has on their daily lives.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Cretu, this report is fundamental to the future of cohesion policy and I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on their efforts and results. What they have achieved seems almost miraculous in view of the time when preparations have begun to present the final formula to Parliament. At the same time, I would like to note that they have considerably improved the version proposed by the Commission.  A strong, effective, well-funded and solidarity-based cohesion policy is essential not only for poor regions, but for the development of the whole of the European Union. At the same time, however, let me stress my strong opposition to macroeconomic conditionality. It has nothing to do with cohesion policy and I hope that Parliament will reject it, as it has done in the past.  With regard to the timing of the adoption of this regulation, I would like to ask all colleagues and institutions to make every effort to conclude as much of the chapters agreed for the common regulation as possible. At the same time, I formally call on the Council and the Romanian Rotating Presidency to formally assure Parliament that, in the future, the chapters already closed will not be reopened for negotiations.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I support the report's position that it is important for the future of the citizens of the European Union that cohesion policy remains the Union's main investment policy and that its funding for the period 2021-2027 is maintained at least at the level of the 2014-2020 programming period. However, new funding for other union activities or programmes should not, as set out in one of the amendments, be at the expense of the European Regional Development Fund or the Cohesion Fund. In my opinion, this is unacceptable. The commission's proposal to transfer €10 billion from the Cohesion Fund to the Connecting Europe Facility is absolutely unacceptable. This will affect the poorest regions of the Union. It is therefore crucial to adopt an amendment reducing this amount to EUR 4 billion. I strongly oppose raising climate targets and adapting energy, transport and social policies to this. This may, in my view, lead to a cooling of the economies of the Member States of the Union and, consequently, of the Economic Crisis of the Community.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Dear Chairman, respected Commissioners, respected rapporteurs, although I also have some objections to this report, in a way I partly express the skepticism regarding the pooling of funds, however, of course, I support this report because the fact is that we anticipate the fight against climate change, the fact is that we want more social Europe, the fact is that we want more investment in the environment and of course we want more employment. These are all very important elements that need to support this report.  However, I want to put emphasis on something that is in fact the most important for me, which is the continuation of the strong cohesion policy of the European Union. That is why the European Union is the most recognizable, in this way it is best understood by the citizens and I have to express great satisfaction here and I want to convey to you the happiness and satisfaction of people who got švald ten days ago, because Valkarin got a scab, came asphalt, paid 100% with european union funds. This satisfaction and happiness of these people should be repeated and that is why I want to keep cohesion policy to the end in European Union policy.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, last year I was part of a fact-finding mission by the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) to the north of Ireland to assess the impact of cohesion funding. MEPs saw the vital importance of EU funding for women’s groups, small businesses and for persons with disability. European regional development funding, European social funding, and peace and Interreg funding have helped to build peace and advance reconciliation in areas damaged by an awful conflict. It bulldozed the biggest British army barracks in north Belfast and built the Girdwood Community Hub, and it invested millions in Derry to build a Peace Bridge which joined the two traditions, usually living apart, together. Britain’s resistance of the backstop in the withdrawal agreement is an absolute disgrace. The backstop would prevent physical infrastructure on the border partitioning Ireland. It doesn’t, however, include access to the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund, the common agricultural policy or the maritime and fisheries funds. A place emerging from conflict is being economically tore apart by Brexit. Whether it’s a crash Brexit or not, the north of Ireland will be hit hardest and a solution for all is the reunification of Ireland, and it’s long past the time for the Irish Government to advance this legitimate Good Friday Agreement provision.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Mr President, for those who were still deluding themselves about the true nature of the European Union, this financial regulation will be enough to tear the veil. Already, in May 2008, the Commission had set the tone: by a simple line of the financial framework, it added a new criterion for the allocation of cohesion funds, that of the integration of immigrants, thus waving the red rag of financial retaliation. This new condition is part of a set of diktats, whose recommendations to France in 2018 gave a taste: pension reform or even an increase in the SMIC. In this widespread social breakdown, only those whom the Commission modestly calls 'disadvantaged groups', particularly migrants, stand out. But, exhisered by a sense of omnipotence, the European Union is showing a fatal presumption. For France or Italy, ordered to consent to a migratory surge or yet another austerity cure, remain a net contributor to its budget. On the eve of crucial elections, Brussels is playing to its legitimacy and, ultimately, its survival.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Mr President, the justification and transparency of the acts being promoted are inadequate. The sound and non-discriminatory management of available resources on the basis of value added criteria and support for actions supporting member states' priorities is not served. Amendments to these funds are supposed to ease the administrative burden by facilitating the relevant management services. Personally, I am interested in serving citizens and, above all, in eradicating poverty, economic inequalities and existing distortions. Words such as 'synergies' and 'simplification' and 'rationalisation' are used to conceal political crises and unrealistic capital allocation discrimination for cohesion and support for disadvantaged or disadvantaged areas. Guarantees are needed to maintain the actual support costs. The Financial Resources of the Union, being subscriptions, belong to the States and must be returned to them. In fact, the report promotes the selective management of state funds for the directed waste of this public money on industries, businesses and specific interests, undermining institutions and authorities, for the benefit of a few powerful economic centres.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cohesion policy is an extremely important policy for Europe and has worked, in my opinion, well enough in the years in which it has been implemented, from the time of the crisis of 2009 to 2010. Unfortunately, this policy has been under constant pressure, especially from net contributors. It is also clear in the Commission's proposal to propose projects only in the framework of the country's recommendations, which I do not think is normal, plus macro-economic conditionality.  In fact, it is also seen in the budget, because I do not understand, Commissioner, how could you accept the budget for the Cohesion Fund to be cut to such an extent? That's what I think is not normal for a Commissioner who is in charge of that area. So we can also see it in the budget, and we need to support the European Parliament's proposal, which at least raises the budget to the level it is now, because, I repeat, this policy is still needed. As far as co-financing is concerned, co-financing is an artificial discussion, in my opinion. More co-financing is needed for countries that do not have the financial means to propose projects based on European funds. After all, the amount given by the European funds is the same. It depends on how many projects you do: with more funding you do fewer projects, with smaller projects you do more, so I think it needs to be left at a higher value to allow Member States to submit projects. Transfer to SEF: after all, cohesion money must be used for transport. I believe that the best solution would be for very clear rules to be introduced in this regulation: where to go in transport policy.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a good job has been done by the two rapporteurs and in the committee's overall vote. It is a step towards citizens and local communities, the most important European policy in recent years and years. We must therefore be absolutely proud of this. But, as today's debate shows, with the speeches of so many Members, let us not penalise this work.  That is why I insist, in these hours between now and the vote: let us reflect again on this issue, which has been the subject of discussion between us, again in this debate on the subject of macro-conditions. I appeal to all Members, and I am addressing those who have worked in these hours to determine the most advanced balances: there is a package of amendments, from 448 to 499, to 553, to 426: cancellation of macro-traditionality, or exclusion of the Social Fund, or the introduction of flexibility, or the golden rule.  It would be enough to give a signal on one of these amendments in order to keep the political families together, but also the protagonists of cohesion policy in recent years, and to pursue a fundamental policy for Europe and for our citizens.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, can I pay tribute to the rapporteurs and say that it’s now almost 30 years since I first became a member of the Committee on Regional Affairs in this Parliament and it has done tremendous work during that time. And can I put it on record that it has been a source of good in the assistance it has given to Northern Ireland through the regional funds, through the Peace funds, now at over EUR 2 billion, and that is something that I am proud of and the people of Northern Ireland can be proud of as well.  There’s even talk of a Peace Plus fund, and if the Commissioner is listening maybe I could say to her that I am extremely concerned if that Peace Plus – and the Commissioner is still not listening – but I am extremely concerned about how after Brexit this fund will likely be commissioned, how it will be distributed and how it will be controlled.  And I have to say that I find it rather odd when I look back, when I saw the support that Jacques Delors gave to Northern Ireland, and when I see the support that Jean-Claude Juncker has given, and Mr Barnier has given – with his acolytes from this Parliament who don’t even talk to the people of Northern Ireland. They are giving to Northern Ireland. I certainly have very main concerns about that.  And I also have concerns, let me say, when the Secretary of State tries to threaten and bribe the people of Northern Ireland and say that the funds will not be in existence afterwards if we don’t support her Brexit policy. That would be unacceptable to anyone.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, that famous article we are talking about, Article 15, says, inter alia, that the Commission may suspend programme payments in whole or in part when the Council decides that a Member State has not taken effective measures to correct its excessive deficit, or where the Council decides that a Member State does not comply with the macroeconomic adjustment programme. It's unacceptable. This article and similar ones have no possible correction, you can only delete them. And the proposal it submits to Parliament remains strong, and that bluntness means cuts to citizens, once again always in the pockets of the weakest. And it means strengthening the council's and the Commission's control over regions and municipalities. Unacceptable. We have just seen what the European Union has done with Greece. They are then apologised with a small mouth, and now a new Regulation is put on the table which increases the power of the Council and the Commission to sanction us. Let us vote to make it easier for European funds to reach citizenship, not to make it easier for you to force them to tighten their belts and punish them.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, regional development and cohesion funds are a very important part of EU policy and budget. Up to a third of our resources are earmarked for this purpose and it is, of course, important that we are able to support peripheral and less developed regions, then also promote their investment and future. However, in the future, when funding is declining somewhat, what is essential is which priorities we will choose for this policy. I think it is very good that innovation, investment in clean energy, the circular economy, the promotion of digitalisation and, above all, of course, modern, intelligent infrastructure have now been chosen as the key. I welcome the Commission's proposal to allocate EUR 10 billion of cohesion funds to the Connecting Europe project, which could specifically support large cross-border transport projects. It is very important for the development of the European internal market that people, goods and services can move from one country to another. This is worth supporting and a good proposal and I regret that the Committee on Regional Development is now dropping that amount. It is also a very good proposal to try to reduce governance and bureaucracy in this programme, because we know that this is a major obstacle to the effective implementation of these financial projects. Similarly, I think it is important that we are able to promote the regulation so that, in future, funding is tied to the rule of law. Even now, we have EU Member States that receive very significant regional development and cohesion funds, but they do not comply and no longer respect the rule of law. This is a very worrying development and, in future, there must be an opportunity for these countries to be frozen with funding.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, cohesion policy has been, is and will be one of the fundamental policies for the European Union. Territorial cohesion: achieving equal opportunities for Europeans and Europeans, regardless of the territory in which they live. And that policy must be adapted to new challenges, it cannot be static. And that is the work we have done in this Parliament: a cohesion that is capable of adapting to the demographic challenges that Europe is suffering today. Because in Europe there are regions that lose population. Castile and León, for example; one of the regions that loses the most population in all of Europe, one of the sheepiest. We need a cohesion policy that is capable of promoting the setting of the population, of giving opportunities for women, young people, of creating alternatives for the future and of employment. And do not resign ourselves to creating deserts of population in Europe, because we sincerely need cohesion policy to be able to give opportunities to our territories to ensure the future of the rural environment and the regions that need Europe's support today.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the rapporteurs, because an excellent piece of work was done in committee, greatly improving the measure. The results achieved, to which reference has been made, those relating to the concentration of resources, the simplification of procedures, the increase in the budget, together with tenders and investment plans and the principle of territoriality, are very positive elements.  At the same time, I think it is important, as has also been said by a number of colleagues, to refer to two fundamental aspects. The first is that of additional national resources. It is unimaginable that on this issue there may be an idea of the non-additionality of these resources and therefore of the treatment of these resources as resources apart. We must have the capacity to release them financially and allow them to be genuinely additional resources.  Furthermore, there is the issue of macro-secondality, which represents absolute opposition from the point of view of Europe's political message to its citizens. We shall vote against this, because I think we need a clear and clear answer from this Parliament.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work in bringing this report forward. I welcome Parliament's bet on greater funding for something as important as cohesion. I also welcome the increase in co-financing rates in line with the amendments I had tabled together with my colleague, who is currently chairing us, Mr Ramón Luis Valcárcel. I want to focus my intervention on the special case of a small number of regions, including Galicia. These regions, due to the economic crisis of recent years, fall out of class for the purposes of the new financial framework, but, in our estimates, they would also suffer a significant reduction in funds if the criteria in Annex XXII were applied exclusively. By the way, in this annex, Commissioner, I would have liked the demographic criterion to have been more present, as I have been claiming in this House over the last few years. And I return to the exceptional case of this set of regions to which I referred earlier. In the specific case of Galicia, it would descend from more developed region to region in transition, and yet would seriously lower its European funding. This is contrary to the principle of cohesion and to any principle of equity. That is why, by Amendment No 429, the People's Group wanted to establish a safety net to prevent these crisis-penalized regions from being also punished in funding. The aim is to guarantee them an allocation equivalent to that of the period 2014-2020. I thank Mr Novakov and Mr Van Nistelrooij and Ramón Luis Valcárcel for their efforts to ensure that this amendment is supported by my group. It's about avoiding an unfair situation. And I would also like to thank you for the support of other groups which I know will support this amendment.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work. It was, in fact, an amazing job.  Secondly, I would like to highlight the increase in the co-financing rate of 85% for the outermost regions and the less developed regions. Thirdly, I would like to touch on the issue of macroeconomic conditionality which appears in this regulation, the well-known Article 15. We should not sanction, through European funds, Member States that do not meet the deficit targets. Such a penalty means subverting cohesion policy, making it a sanctioning instrument, when in its genesis it is an investment instrument, means mortifying the development of the regions and also means voting the outermost regions to double austerity. We also need to be consistent, in 2016 this Parliament spoke with one voice against the sanctions that would be imposed on Portugal and Spain for not meeting the deficit.  Finally, to say that these measures are a terrible sign to European citizens, assuming that austerity can be partial or total. We have a political obligation and have a moral duty to end austerity.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU's cohesion policy shows light and shadow. Of course, cohesion policy supports the regions, that is quite clear. On the other hand, we keep getting indications that nonsensical projects are being realised, that we also see distortions of competition. That is why we must rigorously examine all projects to see whether they really make sense. Above all, they must also sustainably promote these regions and make them fit for the future. In addition, cohesion policy should be limited to areas that have so far developed below average, that is, not to regions that have already developed above average. Because in the less developed areas, we need to promote infrastructure projects, such as transport projects, digitalisation, but also in education. To achieve this, we need to define clear and measurable objectives. We must then also examine whether these objectives are really being achieved, because if they are not achieved, then we must stop these measures. Otherwise, we will ultimately waste taxpayers' money, because we should not pretend that this money that the EU spends is falling from the sky. It must be generated by the citizens beforehand, and that is why we must spend this money sparingly. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I wanted to ask Mr Kölmel whether he thinks it is right that we should continue to make research and scientific expenditure available for research infrastructure with the Structural Funds, so that science and research infrastructure is also available for the population and for those involved in rural areas. Do you think that would make sense?

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for this question, sir. Naturally. As I have just said, we must use cohesion policy and the means to make these regions fit for the future. And what is more obvious than spending money on research, on education, so that these regions can invest in their human capital? That is why these are even the best investments we can make. We must focus on this: digitisation of education, research and development.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, your proposal is bad, it is really bad. It is a good thing that there is Parliament, the Parliament which is a co-legislator and is in a position of equality with the Council. With our proposal we can continue to call cohesion policy cohesion policy, with its proposal we could not call it cohesion policy. How could we accept a 45% cut in the Cohesion Fund, that fund which is intended precisely for the poorest Member States, those with less than 90% of gross national income? Cohesion, solidarity in the European Union is a matrix that we cannot lose, which we must at least maintain in terms of the amounts. And with our proposal, with the maintenance of the amounts, with the maintenance of the co-financing rates, which are essential for the poorest regions, we can tell the citizens of the European Union that social, economic and territorial cohesion will continue and thanks to Parliament which will now negotiate with the Member States. And here is a question for the Commissioner, after all which Member States want to cut back on cohesion policy? It is that Parliament has already mentioned here, and will vote, does not accept cuts in this policy.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the UK might be leaving the European Union and that would mean that Wales, unfortunately, won’t get structural funds in the future and that’s a great shame. I’ve been involved with structural funds for a long time and I wanted to make three points, which I think are important. First of all, it is important that we agree the EU budget and the regulations as soon as possible, because if we don’t there will be gaps between the projects, projects will stop, people will lose their jobs. I wanted to thank the two co-rapporteurs for bringing these regulations forward as soon as they possibly could. Secondly, the regulations need to be simplified. If the rules aren’t simple people don’t apply for the project funds, and that brings structural funds into disrepute. Therefore, once again, I’m pleased that the co-rapporteurs have brought forward proposals which will allow the regulations to be simplified. And thirdly, we need to make structural funds more visible. Too often we’ve gone right across the European Union, visited projects and the project beneficiaries didn’t realise their project was funded by the European Union. That must stop. That must change. We must make the European Union much more visible in the future. That’s one lesson I’ve learnt from Brexit.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! As a preliminary point, I would like to emphasise that I am pleased that the draft framework regulation on cohesion policy funds includes issues that we have regularly requested in the Committee on Regional Development, such as increasing flexibility or reducing unnecessary burdens on beneficiaries and managers. I also consider it important to introduce closer links between cohesion policy and the European Semester. I am also pleased that the envelope for European Territorial Cooperation, which has already proved its effectiveness in increasing cohesion and stimulating cooperation between regions, has been increased to 3%. However, I do not agree with the proposal to transfer EUR 10 billion from the Cohesion Fund to the Connecting Europe Facility. I am of the opinion that this transfer should be proportionate to the cuts made to the Cohesion Fund and therefore amount to EUR 4 billion proposed by the Committee on Regional Development.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, if there is a debate that gives meaning to the Europe of solidarity, it is precisely the debate of cohesion, of cohesion funds. Because there is no more political priority than that embodied in budgets. And when we have to deal with growing demands, climate change or demographics, as important in a community as Galician, it is necessary for Parliament to defend a policy of strong regional development, without cuts and to help heal the wounds of a time of crisis. That is why it is very important for my region, for Galicia, that this be adopted with the amendment introduced by the People's Party, Amendment No 429, which our group supports. I would like to say to Mr Millán Mon that, when it comes to defending the interests of Galicia, Mr Millán Mon, we are at hand here.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to point out that we must fight as a whole so that there is no reduction in Community funds in the new budget, and that is very important. Secondly, we should point out that the Cohesion Fund plays a key role, especially for regions that are not so developed. At this point I would like to place great emphasis on strengthening the islands and remote areas, especially the Aegean islands and the mountainous regions of Greece.  The next issue is, of course, good administration and management and transparency in the funds. Simplification of procedures should serve these principles. It should also be pointed out that emphasis should be placed on local added value, because community funds are usually received by large multinational companies, which, despite taking funds for example in Greece, do not pay taxes in Greece. I think we should find a way for local added value to play a role, that is to say to support local small and medium-sized enterprises, so that we can have a significant impact on the operation of the funds.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the presidents of the Balearic Islands, Corsica and Sardinia have sent you a letter outing you the need for these Mediterranean islands to receive treatment and funding comparable to the outermost territories. The Balearic Islands are located just 200 kilometers off the coast of the continent, but its citizens, its economy, its companies, suffer from the geographical drawbacks linked to the island fact. However, the allocation of European funds, cohesion policy, does not take into account this cost of insularity or its consequences on sustainable development and social cohesion on these islands. Indeed, in recent years the Balearic Islands have not converged with the European average in terms of cohesion and competitiveness, but quite the opposite, they have moved away. It is therefore essential that cohesion policy takes into account the special situation of the Mediterranean islands in the next budgetary period and helps to mitigate the effects of insularity.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Commission's proposal to simplify cohesion policy procedures in the next multiannual financial year, helping the managers and beneficiaries of cohesion funds. It is important that through this regulation we succeed in drastically reducing the unnecessary administrative burdens under the previous programmes.  I would like to express my support for an increase of up to EUR 378 billion for economic-social-territorial cohesion, at least up to the same level as in this financial year. Also, by increasing the co-financing rate from 70 to 85% for less developed European regions, we are ensuring that the real beneficiaries of cohesion are the very ones who need it most.  Please consider that more decentralisation and a direct relationship and a direct financing decision are needed between Brussels and micro-regions or local governments because, in many Member States, national governments are a brake on the timely spending of cohesion funds.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Creu, in this joint debate on the new European legislation of the Regional and Cohesion Funds 2021-2027, the European Parliament has done its job. For starters, increasing the Commission's proposal by 14% to EUR 380 billion. Secondly, ensuring at least 30% for climate targets, also introducing equality, non-discrimination, gender equality, and even a Child Guarantee fund of up to EUR 6 billion. But I am particularly pleased that the financing of the outermost regions, including the Canary Islands – the community in which I reside – has been maintained, with a co-financing rate of up to 85%, not by reducing the previous heading of 2014-2020, and by increasing the Interreg Programme by 3%, which is of enormous importance in the outermost regions. There is only a need for this Parliament to vote against the maintenance of macro-conditionality, which means in practice punishing those countries with the most difficulties in their regional policy rather than incentivising them. May we succeed in defeating macro-conditionality in the vote on this Regulation!

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Creţu, there are three key elements in this cohesion debate: the demographic criterion, precariousness at work and the recentralisation of funds. My country, Galicia, loses, loses by the demographic issue. The Ghastly youth immigrate because there is no work. It is not just a crisis problem, it is a problem of ineffective governments that do not respond to the supply of employment. My country has lost EUR 3 billion in this period of cohesion funds. In addition, there is the problem of depopulation and the cost of services, for example in rural areas, with an ageing population. Precariousness at work is already the norm, and, of course, the recentralisation of funds, as is the case with the European Social Fund. On the other hand, the ERDF, as has also happened with the serious problem of water sanitation. This is, Commissioner, the right time to decentralise European funds, not to conditional on European funds with macroeconomic criteria that crush us. This is the opportune time not to talk about triumphalism, but rather equality.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a reinforced, simpler and more focused cohesion policy that takes into account the investment needs of all regions is the best answer the EU can give both to historical development disparities and to the new challenges of our changing world. It was never an easy task to reconcile all the constraints and needs related to this file, starting from Brexit-induced budgetary constraints, stakeholder calls for simplification or the identification of those ex-ante conditionalities which are essential for the good implementation of the funds, but I think that ultimately we obtained a good result.  I especially welcome that we managed to agree on diverting as few resources as possible from the Cohesion Fund to other objectives. It is important to equip ourselves with innovative financial instruments, but let’s not forget that there are still countries in the EU that lack the basic environmental, transport or energy infrastructure that is indispensable for their future development.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Cretu, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating a regulation that will establish common rules for seven funds, for what will be linked to cohesion in the future, and I am dismayed by the Commission's proposal, which puts absurd conditionalities.  I would like to thank my colleagues coordinated by two extraordinary rapporteurs, who have tabled thousands of amendments here, and I hope very much that they will vote to exclude these conditionalities, because, Commissioner, the money comes from the pocket of the citizens of each Member State. It is absurd for an unelected executive of the European Union to decide where the money goes. It is not normal to think about cohesion, at the same time to punish areas which, unfortunately, are less developed, and I hope that no euro will be cut from cohesion funds compared to the last period, and I also hope that the poor, remote areas, as you want, call them what you will, will enjoy the real funding. I also hope, Commissioner, that this strategic investment fund, absurdly divided by the first come, first served criterion, will be otherwise distributed to contribute to cohesion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, mar bhall den Choiste um Fhorbairt Réigiúnach, idir 2009 agus 2014, chonaic mé an dea-obair atá á déanamh trasna na hEorpa ar fad ag na Cistí seo, agus nuair a chuaigh mé ar mhisin go háiteanna cosúil leis an nGearmáin, go háirithe Beirlín Thoir, agus go dtí an Bhreatain Bheag, mar a luaigh Derek Vaughan, bhí mé ábalta é sin a fheiscint ar an talamh. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach nach mbeadh aon ghearradh siar ar an mbuiséad dosna Cistí seo, agus iarraim ar na Ballstáit é sin a chinntiú. Freisin, luaigh mo chomhghleacaithe Martina Anderson agus James Nicholson an tábhacht a bhaineann leis na Cistí seo, go háirithe don phróiseas síochána i dTuaisceart Éireann agus fáiltím roimh an ráiteas ó Jean-Claude Juncker, agus daoine eile nach é, go leanfar ar aghaidh leis an airgead seo dosna tionscnaimh shíochána. Tá sé sin thar a bheith tábhachtach agus caithfimid é sin a chinntiú.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Yes, we Parliamentarians and the Commission very often talk about competitiveness, importance, solidarity between Member States in particularly cross-border European projects. However, when we start talking specifically about financial commitments, solidarity unfortunately becomes just a sounding theoretical concept. I am referring specifically to the intention to reduce the amount transferred from the Cohesion Fund to the European Infrastructure Facility from ten to four billion euros. This would mean stagnating for important European transport projects, including the Rail Baltic project, which has a strategic implications not only for the Baltic and Scandinavian region, but also for the long-term competitiveness of the European Union as a whole. I will therefore not be able to support the idea of reducing competitiveness by some Parliamentarians and depriving projects of European interest of the principles of solidarity and competitiveness.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to draw attention to two important points for me. Firstly, the compatibility in this House of the importance of the Structural Funds, which is welcome. The second point has not come up, so I am speaking out to also insist on investment for culture, for the creative industries. It is there that there are various bureaucratic and financial barriers, and the lack of flexibility is the most severe, the most painful. Please note that decisions on investments in culture are most often made in small and medium-sized commitments in terms of the size of funding. It is therefore very important that culture is as free as possible from these bureaucratic constraints, because it is the most acute and costly there.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the joint work with my colleagues in the REGI Committee and the sensitivity of the rapporteurs, the regulation on provisions common to the Structural Funds will also cover the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. It was necessary to provide for legislative and administrative simplification for this fund too, in the wake of the current programming, but taking advantage of the critical issues encountered and above all respecting the peculiarities of the agricultural sector.  In order to better mobilise potential at local level, investment should be encouraged in the form of territorial instruments, such as integrated territorial investment and participatory local development, key measures of the EAFA. On the other hand, I do not agree with the provision, even in the forthcoming programming, of macroeconomic conditionality, which betrays the objective of cohesion policies. Blocking funds for regions for breaches of EU budgetary rules is a betrayal of the Europe of the regions and a failure of cohesion policies. The possibility of discontinuing the sanction procedure in the event of exceptional economic circumstances was also rejected. A number of amendments have been tabled against this conditionality. I hope that the vote will remedy this injustice.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I believe that today's discussion has made it quite clear that the Cohesion Funds, the regional development funds, are actually at the heart of the European idea. Here, ideas become strategies, and ideas become tangible projects for the benefit of all.  I think it's a bit like education policy, and that's why I'm glad that all the regions should benefit here. Because it is important, as in school, to promote talent and to reduce those deficits where there are deficits. There is no point in restricting one self to one or the other. Individuals – i.e. regions, project participants – but also the individual Member States and the European Union as a whole can benefit here. Another principle of education, however, is that it makes no sense to punish children if parents do not do things right, for example, when parents evade taxes to refuse to allow children to attend school: this is in fact macroeconomic conditionality transferred to education. I believe that this is something that we do not need.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Membră a Comisiei. – Domnule președinte, aș dori să vorbesc în primul rând în română, în limba mea maternă, pentru a clarifica câteva chestiuni.  În primul rând, vreau să vă mulțumesc tuturor pentru sprijinul dat și pentru această dezbatere atât de fructuoasă în legătură cu regulamentele comune privind Fondul de dezvoltare regională și alte fonduri europene. Bineînțeles, am primit și critici la adresa propunerilor Comisiei și apreciez acele critici constructive. Bineînțeles că nu apreciez acele critici care vin din partea unor oameni care, în mod clar, nu cunosc regulamentele, nu cunosc tratatele la care Uniunea Europeană este parte și este evident că, sigur, le luăm pe toate în considerare, dar cred că trebuie să pornim de la ideea de bază, aceea că Comisia face o propunere pe care dumneavoastră o aprobați sau nu și care se supune dezbaterii Parlamentului European și Consiliului ca și colegislatori. Vreau să vă amintesc, unora dintre dumneavoastră, de fapt doar unei doamne, că campania electorală începe pe 26 aprilie 2019 și nu suntem în campanie electorală.  În altă ordine de idei, aș vrea să le spun celor care critică bugetul acordat politicii de coeziune că, din cauza Brexitului, dumneavoastră știți poate chiar mai bine decât mine, avem o scădere, vom avea, din păcate, o scădere de 10 % pe an din bugetul Fondului de coeziune, iar toată bătălia noastră a fost de a menține această politică de coeziune care este politica cea mai vizibilă, cea mai tangibilă în viața de zi cu zi a oamenilor.  În ciuda faptului că suntem în fața acestui proces al Brexitului, în ciuda faptului că, pentru prima oară, Uniunea Europeană este chemată să adopte un fond de securitate, un fond de apărare, este pentru prima oară când Uniunea Europeană este chemată să acorde bani pentru securitatea frontierelor, în ciuda tuturor acestor aspecte, politica de coeziune, pentru prima dată în istoria Uniunii Europene, va avea un buget de 373 de miliarde de euro, cel mai mare buget din cadrul bugetului total, din care 80 %, mai mult decât în actuala perioadă de programare, se vor duce în regiunile cel mai puțin dezvoltate.  Deci, haideți să încetăm cu dezinformarea populației: peste 80 % din fondurile de coeziune se duc în regiunile cele mai sărace. Sunt țări, precum Spania, Grecia, Italia, România, Bulgaria, care, din cauză că nu au reușit să treacă peste criza economică și din cauza scăderii economice, vor avea creșteri economice, creșteri în alocări, iar alte state care au avut creșteri spectaculoase - suntem totuși după nouă ani de creștere continuă economică în Uniunea Europeană - vor avea scăderi în ceea ce privește alocările, iar aceste scăderi provin din faptul că GDP per capita - produsul intern brut pe cap de locuitor - este mai mare decât acum șapte ani. Deci, nu este vorba de nicio penalizare, nu este vorba de vreo scădere, este vorba doar despre recunoașterea creșterii economice care a avut loc în aceste state.  Aceasta a fost în legătură cu bugetul. În legătură cu vizibilitatea politicii noastre: sunt foarte de acord cu ceea ce s-a spus aici, mai ales cu ceea ce dragul nostru coleg, Derek Vaughan, a spus. Bineînțeles că suntem cu toții triști că Marea Britanie părăsește acest proiect european, dar este o lecție pe care trebuie să o învățăm, pentru că Uniunea Europeană a contribuit enorm la dezvoltarea inclusiv a acestei țări: metroul din Cardiff, extinderea metroului din Londra, de asemenea, Universitatea din Manchester, deci avem o mulțime de exemple de proiecte care nu sunt cunoscute. Asta pe lângă faptul că părintele fondator al acestei politici, primul comisar european pentru politică regională - se numea Lord Thomson -, este cel care a solicitat împreună cu Italia și cu guvernul Marii Britanii înființarea acestei politici de coeziune în semn de solidaritate atunci când minele din Țara Galilor au fost închise; dar, bineînțeles că, probabil, cei care au votat acum pentru Brexit în această regiune nu au știut că părinții și bunicii lor au avut locuri de muncă datorită acestor fonduri europene care au contribuit la dezvoltarea economică a regiunii lor. So I will pass now into English. I would like to thank warmly the rapporteurs – we are talking not about the Commission proposal, we are talking about your report. I would like to thank you, Ms Krehl and Mr Novakov, the Committee on Regional Development and all of you. Thank you very much for your high-quality work, for your hard work, for your efforts and, of course, you know very well that we count on you to move the legislative package forwards. Thank you very much for everything.  I think that our proposal lays the foundation for a quality and effective policy. You know very well that we have worked so much together to strengthen, modernise and simplify this policy, and now we are facing into new challenges, which are the trilogies. As you will vote on this report today, we can start the trilogues between Parliament and the Council as co-legislators – and, of course, I will represent the Commission. We must get the package through in a timely manner, while maintaining the quality of the proposals. You know very well that according to our studies, we would have liked to have this agreement before the European elections. It seems that it will not be possible during the Romanian Presidency, but I hope at least by the end of the year to have an agreement on the multiannual financial framework (MFF), on the budget because, according to our estimates, more than 100 000 projects from 27 Member States will not be able to be finished on time if we don’t have an agreement this year. As I said, unfortunately, it seems that it’s impossible to be ready before the elections, as we foresaw one year ago. So we have several challenges. The first challenge is maintaining a strong strategic focus, and partnership agreements are essential to this. Our new policy objectives are essential too, and thank you for all your support here. I would like to underline that, in the new partnership agreements that we will start to negotiate with each Member State in March, you will be able to raise your problems. For instance, the problem of decentralisation that was raised by MEPs Marinescu and Buşoi, and the problems of islands which were raised by the representative of the Balearic Islands. So it’s up to the Member States whether or not they include in the partnership agreement, and in the operational programmes, how to earmark the money and who will be the beneficiaries. For instance, I know that you referred to the three regional hospitals in Romania. We cannot decide from Brussels who will be the beneficiary of a project, it’s up to the government to decide. But bear in mind that we will start negotiations on the partnership agreement and operational programmes in March 2019 and I hope NGOs, Members of the European Parliament and everybody involved will have a strong dialogue with each government so that these local needs that you spoke about are kept in mind. On simplification: we are very keen on that, you are aware that I was in favour of radical simplification and, as you know, we have proposed 80 key simplifications. The challenge lies in both directions – maintaining the simplifications but resisting over-simplification. Simplification is not a goal in itself. Our goal is a quality, effective policy, making life easier for beneficiaries, of course, but we cannot allow over-simplification which reduces the project’s quality or value-added and I count on your support here too. Also we have to bear in mind realistic co-financing. Let’s remember, as I said, that today’s EU co-financing rates are exceptional because they were increased for the economic crisis. Moreover, our proposal for the co-financing rates means greater local ownership and in the end it also means greater total funding and a greater boost to development. The financial challenge we have is, as I said at the beginning, the budget. We have discussed various proposals to increase and protect the cohesion policy budget. I understand very much and I appreciate your support for the policy. In conclusion, we have a window of opportunity, an opportunity to make progress. The negotiators’ mandates for the trilogues cover substantial issues – strategy programming, management and control – together these make up more than one-third of the regulation and on these issues I see a convergence of interests, so I believe we can make significant progress. Remember that progress has no risk. We are all going to enter into the trilogues, the first one for cohesion policy will be on 19 March, knowing that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed. Progress on this issue, the issue of convergence, will provide clarity for managing authorities and beneficiaries. Let us seize this opportunity. Once again, thank you to all of you, but first of all to Ms Krehl and Mr Novakov.

name: Андрей Новаков
text: Rapporteur. – First of all, I thank everyone who took part in the debate. For almost two hours, we failed to understand in depth, to say everything we think about cohesion policy, which shows that it makes sense for it to continue to exist. It continues to excite all of us, no matter what part of the European Union we come from.  One thing I'm sure of everything I've heard – if cohesion policy disappears one day, it won't be because of those who attack it and disapprove of it. This would only happen for those who look idly by without doing anything about it. However, I will not be among these people, and I am glad that there are many others in this room who think like me. Because cohesion policy has no net payers and net beneficiaries. There are only one and they are net winners, because each one benefits from European politics – from the Black Sea coast to the Atlantic coast. Everyone can see the results of it.  There are few European policies that touch every single person and reach every single village, in small and large cities, to students, farmers, young scientists, entrepreneurs, businesses, all. And I am glad that today we will take a step in this direction and support cohesion policy, cohesion policy. Perhaps one of the most successful the European Union has ever had. We had a huge challenge and it was to help keep the next programming period from being late. I am pleased that we have made sure that in just ten months we can do a job that would otherwise take much longer and ultimately as early as Monday, if this Parliament approves our report today, we will start negotiations with the Council. I think it's right and that people will appreciate it. On January 1, 2021, the next period should begin and there should be enough money for all important projects for people – from traditional policies, roads, railways, schools, plumbing, ecology to high technology, to smart cities, etc.  Thank you all for your support.

name: Constanze Krehl
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to briefly comment on one aspect of the debate, namely the question of flexibility between the funds and other European Union programmes. In our compromise, we propose that the regions, for example, can finance research projects that cannot be financed under Horizon because the budget may not be sufficient through the Structural Funds. We suggest that the regions can work with InvestEU up to a certain limit. And we propose to you that we transfer an appropriate contribution, EUR 4 billion, to the Connecting Europe Facility. We also propose that we also have a balanced flexibility between the funds, which will enable the regions to invest precisely in projects. For us, this means that we are more efficient – yes, but we do not want cohesion policy to be cut by further transfers. We will be voting today on a modern cohesion policy for the citizens of the European Union. That is why I would like to ask my fellow Members to vote in favour of the report that Mr Novakov and I are presenting. I would like to express my sincere thanks for the great cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs, with colleagues. I would like to thank the secretariat, the staff in the group and my colleagues. It was a great collaboration. I think we are proposing a good result, which we can really say is for the benefit of our regions, for the benefit of the inhabitants of the towns and cities. Let's get on with it! Let us then also start the negotiations, the trialogue with the Council, so that the regions can be given planning certainty as early as possible.

name: El presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposal for a regulation on common provisions, which includes seven funds, is a milestone in post-2020 cohesion policy and in the EU budget. Cohesion policy is the Union's main investment policy, and its usefulness and importance are very high for all Member States. The Commission's proposal to reduce the cohesion policy budget and make it more difficult for Member States to access resources, for example by increasing pre-financing, co-financing levels or even by the institution of macroeconomic conditionality, is unacceptable. During the parliamentary conciliation process, I was pleased to find that the majority of my colleagues agreed with my proposals to maintain the cohesion policy budget and to reduce the burden on Member States of pre-financing and co-financing levels. However, I still cannot agree with the proposals that want to support the integration of immigrants from cohesion funds, so in today's vote I will vote against such proposals.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The so-called "macroeconomic conditionality" has been and is the basis for blackmail and the threat of sanctions on states, such as that made on Portugal in 2016, with the prospect of suspension of structural and investment funds due to non-compliance with the EU's deficit and debt targets. But this is not the only negative aspect of this proposal. Indeed, these common provisions continue to tie cohesion policy to other forms of conditionality arising from the European Semester, its instruments (country recommendations, national reform plans) and the neoliberal agenda of the European Union. The conditioning of decisions on priorities for the implementation of the funds – decisions that are increasingly outside the national sovereign institutions and specific development needs of each country – and a thematic concentration on the basis of the EU's strategic objectives, defined according to the interests of its main powers, but unrelated to national strategic priorities and objectives, remain at all levels of national priorities and objectives. The overall amounts foreseen for the Structural and Investment Funds also remain insufficient. It is not enough to keep cohesion funds at the same level as the current budget, it is necessary to strengthen them in order to counter the dynamic of economic and social divergence prevailing within the EU.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – As a reporter of the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 on the mobility and inclusion of persons with disabilities and for the period 2010-2020, I drew attention to the need to strengthen anti-discrimination and access provisions in the use of the Structural Funds and to use The European Funds in a way that improves access to goods, services and the built environment. For the current regulation of CPR in force, I have submitted a number of proposals, which have been built in, as the report officer of the EMPL Commission. I particularly welcome the fact that the new CPR has retained or extended these elements. The Structural Funds have long provided resources to increase the employment of persons with disabilities and to promote their inclusive education. It is important that resources are optimally accessible to even the most disadvantaged groups. For all seven EU funds, there should be a horizontal requirement that no one should be discriminated against because of their disability, that access to Union funds is ensured, and that partnerships with NGOs representing people with disabilities be strengthened in the planning and use process. Pre- and co-financing rates should be set in such a way as to make it easier for NGOs representing people with disabilities to obtain funding. It is necessary to ensure that EU funds are used genuinely in the interests of and accessible to people with disabilities in accordance with the UN CRPD Convention.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – The adoption of the Basic Regulation of Cohesion Policy in the European Parliament is an important milestone. It is important because, despite all the difficulties, it preserves the core values of cohesion policy. It preserves a strong, solidarity-and-future, effective development policy for the union as a whole. At the beginning of the debate, this was not at all self-evident. With my amendments to the draft, I have also sought to ensure that cohesion policy will continue to serve the cohesion of the Member States and regions of the Union. Continue to play a crucial role in the EU's balanced economic, social and territorial development. Face challenges such as globalisation and climate change. At the same time, do not forget about the outcasts, the poor, the children living in poverty – even if the governments of a Member State, such as the Orban regime, do not care about them. Parliament's draft meets these requirements, and I therefore support it. At the same time, I urge the Council and the European Commission to do everything possible to reach agreement on the legislation as soon as possible. Regional development is one of the most visible common policies for citizens, which can be seen directly in their place of residence. Let us be proud of the performance, of what the EU is doing through the Structural Funds for the better life of its citizens. And let's talk to the electorate about it in the campaign ahead, so that selfish, anti-EU politicians have no chance of destroying our Union.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. Thank you very much to the rapporteurs for their successful work. The priorities in the EU budget must finally change. We need to move away from stubborn investment in cows to sustainable investment in the future. The Commission's proposals, together with the European Parliament's report, are important steps forward. Simplification and de-bureaucratisation are essential in the allocation of regional funding. European cohesion policy is a unique investment instrument for regions at EU level, for all regions! It is important to me that this principle should continue to apply! The cohesion funds aim to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. Cohesion policy is therefore a strong and visible sign of solidarity on the part of the European Union. There are still serious differences in development in European regions, by which I mean the low-growth and low-income regions. We can reduce these differences with effective cohesion policy. In order to guarantee this, however, (a) the funds must not be further reduced and (b) they must not be linked to macroeconomic conditionality.

name: Soraya Post (S&D)
text: in writing. – Working on structural funds and the CPR, my main goal was to ensure that the relevant funds become a tool to protect, develop and empower people. I wanted to ensure that the future projects financed by these funds will be as inclusive and as non-discriminatory as possible and that they will enable better life prospects for everybody in the EU. Through the non-discriminatory outreach of these funds, we can hopefully eradicate poverty, one of the greatest challenges in the EU today, and achieve the SDGs, thereby making our society a sustainable one. I am happy to see that so many of my amendments to this end were taken on board by the REGI Committee. I am relieved to see that the elimination of poverty has been designated as one of the goals of CPR, similarly to the achievement of the SDGs. I am also proud to see that my call for a stronger gender aspect in all dimensions and stages of the relevant programmes was incorporated into the text. And finally, I am happy to read that my push for more transparency was heard.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Structural Funds are the main source of investment for many Member States, including Slovakia. When Slovakia entered the EU in 2004, our GDP per capita in the EU stood at 40%. Today, we are at around 80%, and this is also the result of funds that have been invested in transport infrastructure, social and health, but also in support of creating new jobs and protecting the environment. When the budget was created for the seven-year period after 2021 and after Britain's withdrawal from the EU, there were concerns about how the cohesion policy budget would be created, how much would be cut. I am very happy that Members are coming up with a 16% increase in the budget because they understand the urgency of balancing regional disparities in each Member State. Less developed regions should continue to benefit from stronger EU support. The funds will greatly support innovation, digitalisation, energy self-sufficiency, science and research. It is also good news to significantly simplify the administrative conditions for applying and using EU funds.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.) Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make it clear that in recent months we have had a great many points of order on the eve of the votes, which in the end were not.  I do not want to get too close to any of the concerns that are sometimes expressed, and I usually support them wholeheartedly. However, I intend to use this in such a way as to deprive anyone who does not raise a point of order. I would therefore ask you to give at the beginning of your speeches the reason for your intervention and the relevant provision of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: I beg your pardon, Mr President, I do not remember the number of the Rule of Procedure, if you wish, I will do so in writing. I would like to ask the Presidency to be able to check the debate that took place yesterday with the Italian Prime Minister, Mr Conte, because after my speech I was heavily offended by the benches of the League or the 5-Star Movement, I do not know which ones, so I would ask you to check exactly what was said by those benches, given that President Tajani also had to speak.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Viotti, there is no doubt about a point of order. We will check it.

name: Kay Swinburne
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, under the Rules of Procedure, I’d like to request referral back to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: Raportor. – Domnule președinte, este vorba despre o actualizare cu caracter strict tehnic. Citesc textul acestui amendament oral: ‘Takes note of the Central Election Commission decision on allocation of seats in the Federation House of Peoples, adopted on 18 December 2018, and calls on all political actors to address the remaining legal gaps in the Bosnia and Herzegovina elections law in a systematic way’.

name: Andrey Novakov
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, in accordance with Rule 59(4) I would like to request referral back to the committee to start interinstitutional negotiations. Thank you all for your support. It’s a small step for each of us, but it’s a big jump for Parliament. (Applause)

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Rapporteur. I request that referral back to the relevant committee be referred back so that the interinstitutional negotiations can begin.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, just one minute to inform the House that the report we are going to vote on, ladies and gentlemen, is responding to the debate that Mr Juncker put forward to us two years ago, when he proposed to us a series of scenarios on the future of Europe. The European Parliament's response to this debate is largely in this report, which also includes the contributions made by the Heads of State and Government who have appeared before this House. I would like to take this opportunity to thank President Tajani for an initiative which was very successful for this Parliament, and I would like to point out to you that I would also like to thank Elmar Brok, Maite Pagazaurtundúa, Pascal Durand, Barbara Spinelli and Fabio Castaldo, who have been colleagues in this report. And just, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to say that, if there is a summary for what we are going to approve here today, it is that Europe has to do together what we can only do together. The idea is a thick line of greater and better integration for the future of Europe.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I abstained today on the EU—Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) as I did at committee stage. While I recognise the strategic importance of our relationship with Singapore and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) region, and concerns about the liberalisation of our public services have been lessened thanks to the use of a positive list, this is a missed opportunity on labour rights. Trade agreements are a key means of setting the rules of the globalisation game and the Singapore FTA sets that bar too low. Even at the eleventh hour, Singapore hasn’t fully committed to ratifying the core International Labour Organisation Conventions, providing the most basic rights. Meanwhile, labour-rights activists in Singapore, like Jolovan Wham, face tough justice fighting for rights for the most vulnerable workers, migrant workers. Today I stand with him, and I call for substantive change, not more rhetoric.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, On the contrary, I supported this agreement and I am very glad that we have approved another free trade agreement with another country. Our philosophy, the EU's philosophy in international trade, must be the principles of liberalism, the principles of free trade, not protectionism. I am convinced that we will soon see the beneficial effect this agreement will have on EU-Singapore trade relations. When we evaluate this agreement in a few years, we will see – and I dare say so – an increase in trade and investment between the EU and Singapore. This will have a similar impact to when we recently evaluated the free trade agreement with South Korea, which has also contributed to the multiplied trade between the EU and South Korea. So I welcome this and please be bolder about this, let us accept such agreements with our other trading partners.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it was almost exactly 200 years ago that an erratic and romantic British colonial officer called Sir Stamford Raffles landed in what’s now Singapore. Its population then was 120 Malays and 30 Chinese. It had zero resources except its natural harbour. Now there are 5.6 million Singaporeans enjoying the eighth highest per capita GDP in the world. How did they manage that? This is a place with zero resources. They have to import their food, their drinking water, their electricity. What was the magic ingredient that transformed those swampy mangrove trees into the gleaming skyscrapers that we see today? Simply this: unilateral free trade. Singaporeans invited the traffic and commerce of the world unconditionally, without waiting for reciprocity, and they especially did so after 1965, following an acrimonious split with their largest neighbour. It was the moment, as Lee Kuan Yew was to put it, when they plugged into the global economic grid. And that is the opportunity for Britain or any other country in the world: simply remove the obstacles between businesses and their customers.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as I did in the Committee on International Trade, I voted against the trade agreement between the European Union and Singapore and, of course, also against the resolution. There are many reasons for this. I would like to focus in particular on the one indicated in this sign (the speaker displayed a sign in the Hemicycle), which we also pointed out through a series of amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group, all of which were rejected. The ISDS system, although renamed ICS, actually creates de facto arbitration courts that only guarantee the right of investors. In addition, there are the lack of binding measures on compliance with global emissions, the lack of measures and recognition of international labour conventions, and the lack of protection of our products. There are so many reasons why we voted against this agreement between the European Union and Singapore.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this Investment Protection Agreement between the EU and Singapore will benefit only those who have already benefited the most from globalisation. It will create new privileges for multinationals in 16 EU Member States and it fails to remove the privileges that already exist in the other 12. Because it provides special access to justice for foreign investors it directly attacks the fundamental principle that we should all be equal before the law, no matter how rich or poor we are, and there’s no economic argument to support it. The Commission has never been able to demonstrate any link between the investment court system (ICS) and investment flows – because there isn’t one. Another way is possible.
