The argument that you need ICS to eradicate investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) arrangements is disingenuous, as the German Bilateral Investment Treaty shows. I fundamentally object to any kind of privileged justice for multinationals and I therefore voted against this agreement today.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour on the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA). The agreement provides a strong impetus for greater engagement between the EU and Singapore and the south-east Asia region in general. It aims to remove nearly all custom duties, to get rid of overlapping bureaucracy, to improve trade for goods, white electronics, wool products and pharmaceuticals, and to encourage EU companies to invest more in Singapore and Singaporean companies to invest more in the EU. The PCA supports people-to-people exchanges, including academic mobility under the Erasmus Mundus programme, and facilitates the further development of cultural exchange in order to increase mutual understanding and knowledge of our respective cultures. Last but not least, the conclusion of the PCA can be used by the EU to further encourage the Singapore authorities to take decisive steps to improve the human rights record in their country.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Mr President, the hysteria of the American shutdown has just subsided, and it is another shutdown that, at the beginning of the month, left thousands of Bosnians defenceless in the face of the unleashing of nature. The inability of the authorities to cope with one of the most spectacular floods of recent years is only a symptom of a deeper evil: that of the impasse of a multi-ethnic and therefore multi-conflict state. This impasse is compounded by a process of European enlargement which, in the eyes of many citizens of the Western Balkans, lacks both clarity and integrity. In 2017, only 19% believed that their country would soon join the European Union and 42% considered the outcome to be positive. For many, Vladimir Putin's triumph in Belgrade demonstrates this: the future lies between China and Russia, where they believe they will find conditions for good faith cooperation. Without the courage to close the enlargement chapter, Brussels risks deepening an abyss of resentment and frustration.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE). – Herr talman!
text: Bosnia and Herzegovina has made great progress which should be noted. Among other things, it has adopted several painful reforms of the kind that are currently shaking the French Government. However, there is still a great deal to do. We want to see an improved rule of law, more efficient administration, a depoliticised judiciary and a freer media. That is precisely why it is important for the EU to continue to support the country, continue to support the reform process, offer a long-term EU perspective and help with administrative and financial support to the country, as has been the case so far. The report is well balanced and shows a realistic picture of the country. That is why I support it.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today is a very important day: Parliament, in its vote in plenary, has deleted the very damaging principle of economic macro-behaviour, namely the possibility of suspending funds for a State that deviates from the Commission's economic diktats, while subverting the vote of the Committee on Regional Development.  I am pleased because this is an important paradigm shift and a position and awareness of certain stupid and penalising rules for our territories, which therefore no longer have any reason to exist. We must now be careful, very careful, in the trialogues, so that the Council is not pressed by the hawks of austerity and does not yet change the text with the complicity, perhaps, of certain groups in Parliament. There are also many other positive elements in the report. The total budget for cohesion policy is being increased by proposing a more ambitious draft budget than that proposed by the Commission: from EUR 378 billion as against EUR 322 billion. Thanks to our amendments, we have also defended and obtained the principle of territoriality in cohesion policy. If there are – at the discretion of the Member State, however – these transfers to instruments such as eu investments, investment will have to remain in the same category of regions, that is to say in the same territories from which the resources come.  The share of European cofinancing, which is essential for the liquidity of regions and local authorities and therefore to start projects, has also been significantly increased, particularly for the less developed regions, i.e. the whole of southern Italy, from 70 % proposed by the Commission to 80 %. Also from an environmental and social point of view there are several steps forward compared to the 2014-2020 programming. We have therefore voted whole much in favour of the report and are preparing for a discussion with the Council and the Commission,

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the adoption of Parliament's position in legislation as important as the common provisions relating to the European Structural Funds: the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the EMPSM and the Cohesion Fund. I am particularly pleased that there is a 14% increase on the Commission's proposal. It is not fair that the new policies, the new objectives, had to be addressed with the cuts in agricultural policy and cohesion policy. That is why I welcome and vote in favour of this proposal from the European Parliament. Also that the funds contribute 30% to the objectives of the fight against climate change I think is a success of this Parliament's proposals, and that there is a greater allocation of resources by States to address Brexit, and finally very happy that Article 15, economic macro-conditionality, has been definitively closed by this Parliament.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I voted today in favour of macroeconomic conditionality being excluded from cohesion funds, because, in addition to suffering the consequences of austerity, our peoples will suffer even more consequences due to the imposition of the deficit, after public services have been reduced following the Brussels mandate, whether it is health, services for the older or labour policy , which affects many people in my country, Galicia. I also voted in favour of the safety nets so that my country would not lose funding for the change of category. But the funds aren't enough. Trilogues could once again be decisive in preventing inequality, including economic inequality.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I was very happy to support the common provisions on cohesion funds, because cohesion policy is the policy that is implementing the principle of solidarity in Europe.  With this policy, we build highways, railways, roads, water mains, sewers. We approach the little man and, through this policy, which is a binder of the European Union, every individual also knows the well-being of the European Union.  I am pleased that we in Parliament have managed to increase the funds for this cohesion policy back to the level already in the previous cohesion policy, because the European Commission's proposal, which has reduced this policy by 14%, is completely unacceptable to me.  The key here is to do everything we can to make the trialogue work to make this policy as simplistic as possible, because complicated European policy is also a major problem for the Member States.  However, Member States must ensure that they are qualified at both national level, so that they are qualified at regional level, at municipal level, so that there is no lag and slow payment of these funds. This is a major problem for the European Union if these funds are not used quickly enough.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is necessary for the future of the European Union and its citizens that cohesion policy remains the Union's main investment policy while maintaining its funding in the period 2021 to 2027 at least as high as the 2014-2020 programming period. The Commission's proposal provides for a smaller budget, however: EUR 330.6 billion for cohesion policy, compared to the previous period. Parliament has decided that the allocation for cohesion policy should remain, in real terms, at the same level as in 2014-2020.  I support the increase of EUR 47.5 billion, as well as the proposal for less developed regions to be supported by EUR 224.4 billion through the Investment for Employment and Growth Objective, and EUR 46.3 billion to be allocated to Member States receiving Cohesion Fund support. On the other hand, it is important to maintain the appropriate level of co-financing and I support providing greater leeway by providing for higher co-financing rates where appropriate, i.e. to have co-financing rates of 85 % for regions ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to speak quite positively today. I must say, however, that I am somewhat embarrassed by the vote. I, of course, welcome the simplification that is taking place within the framework of this legislation. Of course, a higher degree of flexibility, I also accept here, I even supported the ECR proposal on an even higher degree of flexibility, but I must express my embarrassment at the fact that the macroeconomic conditionality, the conditionality, has just been deleted. If countries are in debt and then European money is still contributing to their budgets, I do not think that is the right way to go. We have to act like sensible householders. This proposal, if it passed, I was actually considering voting against this proposal. I hope that the proposal will change again in the trialogue. At the same time, of course, I want to welcome the positive moments that I have mentioned and, for example, the fact that 30% of that share is reserved for climate change. And also that we have advocated not a fall in cohesion policy in the budget envelope, but conditioning if it falls out is a fundamental problem for me.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, even if macro-conditionality has been withdrawn, my vote is against this report because there is no clear change in the direction of the funds. There is no clear change to support my country's productive sectors. There is no clear change to support small and medium-sized enterprises. There is no clear change to support public health or education systems. On the other hand, if we continue with these budgets, we dismantle public pension systems, we will continue to reduce public service and fatten the interests of capital. These are the reasons why I voted against this report.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Mr President, because I am an MEP who is critical of what I believe to be the undemocratic federal evolution of the European Union – a Union that is being pushed up and pulled by federalists and centrists, including reports like this here – I voted against this report—Atondo on the future of Europe. However, I could also have voted in favour, because it is a useful document. I think it is very useful to use it to open our eyes to citizens who are going to vote for the European Parliament. This report is a horrifying shopping list of what the EU-federalists are working on, which are their wildest and in some respects wildest plans for something that started as cooperation between the peoples of Europe, but which threatens to end in an of concentration of power in the hands of people who want to build a world-strange and not wanted construction at all by the citizens. , if necessary against the will of the population. In any case, I am going to campaign with this report—Atondo in my pocket.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, as rapporteur for the ECON opinion on the future of the European Union, I stressed the importance of completing the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union, in particular because of the necessary opening up of favourable sources of financing to start-ups, SMEs, in particular less developed Member States where sources of funding are still much more expensive than in the more developed ones, which makes it impossible to raise their competitiveness, which is extremely important for quality participation in the single market.  In particular, I called for strengthening funding for non-eurozone Member States that must raise productivity, competitiveness, create quality and well-paid jobs, as a strong economy and improved living standards for people in these Member States are the best preparation for joining the eurozone.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Mr President, let us be absolutely right here. There is no debate here about the future of Europe. Here is an imitation of the debate about the future of Europe, here is a marquee debate about the future of Europe, and here are representatives of European socialists, people and liberals with a single narative – more Europe, more Europe, even more Europe. When someone comes here who sees it a little differently, like yesterday, for example, the Italian Prime Minister, this corps almost boos him, almost won't let him speak, and of course the European Parliament then chooses from it what suits him best, i.e. qualified majority voting, strengthening federalisation elements in EU architecture, unifying foreign policy, etc. This is not the way to the future of Europe, and I guarantee you that with this policy you will run into a wall in the European elections in May 2019. Of course, I could not vote for it.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 153a) on fair taxation for a just society (2019/2560(RSP)). I should like to inform Members that this debate does not include time for the catch—the—eye procedure and that no blue cards will accepted.

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: author. – Mr President, tax evasion in the EU costs Member States EUR 825 billion every single year. This is theft from hard-working people, pure and simple. From 1997 to 2017 the average company tax rate in Europe fell from over 35% to under 22%. Digital companies pay even less in taxes – only 9.5% on average according to the Commission’s figures. Internet giants – like Apple, Google and Facebook – pay practically zero tax on their European businesses. Apple famously paid only 0.005% in taxes, while Google and Facebook paid 0.82% and 0.03%. This is not only making a mockery of ordinary citizens and regular companies in Europe who are paying their fair taxes to contribute to society, but it is an existential threat to well-functioning welfare states, societal fairness and a sustainable transition in Europe.  We Socialists and Democrats want to stop international tax evasion and avoidance that also accelerates inequalities in the world today. We know that 26 people owe as much as EUR 3.8 billion – half  of the world’s population – according to new figures. We want tax justice and we want it now. We have put forward concrete solutions to achieve that and the EU needs to take the lead. We want a fair and urgent taxation of the internet giants who profit from European customers but pay almost no tax in Europe. We want an effective minimum corporate taxation in Europe to stop the harmful race to the bottom on corporate taxation. We also want a financial transaction tax to stop harmful speculation and to ensure much—needed taxes to fund public services. It is time for tax havens – even the European Council – to stop defending the broken tax system of yesterday. It’s time to stand up for fair taxation and demand that all companies, especially the largest and richest of them – the digital giants – contribute to society. We Social Democrats of course support the OECD solution to the problem of taxing digital companies, but we will not wait forever and we will not sit idle and silent while the richest and biggest companies in the world continue to pay less than 1% tax in Europe. We reject the false argument that EU Member States should not take the lead in stopping the non—taxation of digital giants. How on earth can opponents of the EU solution claim that 36 members of OECD and 128 members of the Inclusive Framework will reach a decision faster than the 28 Member States in the EU when they themselves are blocking progress in the European Council? The clock is ticking. We know that. France, Italy, Spain, the UK and Austria all have plans for national taxation of digital giants, as they should. Blocking an effective EU solution to the problem of the non-taxation of digital giants will not prevent uncoordinated action on this. It will actually ensure uncoordinated action. We have a workable EU solution to fairly tax digital giants on the table. We have stated clearly that if and when an OECD solution is adopted, this solution would immediately take its place. But, honestly, do you really think for a second that Donald Trump will fight for fair taxation of companies? Because he needs to support the OECD solution too. Do you trust a deal with the man who pulled out of the Paris Agreement and a G7 statement via tweets? This is a choice that the politicians of Europe must make now. Do we want to act and force internet giants to pay their fair tax in Europe or do we just want to wait and hope someone else will find a solution, while the countries of Europe are losing billions in taxes? We Socialists and Democrats have a clear message to the governments imposing fair taxation. Stop defending your richest companies who pay little tax. Start defending European citizens and welfare states. This is your job. Now it’s time to do it.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am grateful for the opportunity to make a contribution to the discussion on the fair taxation for a just society, which is a very important topic for all of us. A year ago the European Parliament had a topical debate on a similar question. This proves that we want, and we have to address tax issues on several occasions. While the EU needs to guarantee the prosperity and well-being of its citizens, collecting tax remains one of the key means through which governments are able to address poverty and inequality at national level. Some may say that the EU could do more in the area of taxation, but I’d like to recall the progress that has been achieved so far over the last few years in this area, and we assure you that the Romanian Presidency will continue work in this direction. Allow me to recall first of all the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive, which is a major success in the EU, providing for a comprehensive framework of anti-abuse measures aimed at ensuring that taxation will occur where value is created. There were also four significant extensions of the scope of administrative cooperation in the area of direct and indirect taxation. Tax rulings issued to companies will not be a secret anymore. Tax authorities are now able to receive and exchange information on country-by-country reports. Administrative cooperation in the area of VAT was also reinforced. Fair taxation also depends on international cooperation. As you are aware, global cooperation is key to combating base erosion and profit-shifting. For the EU, the list of non-cooperative jurisdictions and the work at the OECD level on digital economy taxation are two examples of successful international cooperation that has been established and that is contributing to the objective of fair taxation. Firstly, on the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions. Aggressive tax planning through the offshore system is detrimental to fair taxation and to a just society. However, all countries are free to adopt the tax policy that suits their specific needs. Tax policy is one of the key elements of national economy policy and each country has the right to choose tax incentives to make its economy more attractive. But when tax incentives are harmful, others should be free to adopt appropriate counter-measures. The EU Member States operating through the Code of Conduct Group were able to have a contribution to changing the behaviour of most of the tax havens. The Council has always stated that listing countries is not an objective in itself, and that most fundamental is that jurisdictions which are key partners of the EU share the same standards of tax transparency and good tax governance. Most of the more than 90 jurisdictions which were invited for a dialogue, and which are important partners for the EU, are adhering to the standards common to EU Member States. I think this is a major achievement, and this work will continue. More jurisdictions will be invited to engage in a similar dialogue in the near future. Secondly, on the digital economy, EU Member States are working closely with the OECD to find a global and comprehensive solution to the challenges brought about by the digitalisation of the economy. A broad approach is needed, examining the key aspects relevant to combating base erosion and profit-shifting, such as where tax should be paid and how much. The EU is working hard on an interim solution. The digital services tax directive would fill the gap while the long-term solution is being negotiated. We are likewise acting in the domain of VAT, where major progress has been achieved. Besides significant improvements to the current system of VAT, the Council has now started its work on the definition system and on the definitive system. I am fully confident that Member States will agree on a compromise. Everyone agrees that the EU needs a better system of VAT but a lot of technical work is required. I could continue with many other examples of good and promising work that are ongoing in the area of taxation. To conclude, I will stress the need for an honest debate on tax issues, and I am glad that we have a contribution to that today.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, hello to all of us, I am very pleased with this opportunity to debate together again on a subject that is very dear to me, and which is dear to us, that of tax justice. Almost five years have passed since we took office and we are nearing the end of our mandate, both for Parliament and for the Commission. The time for proposals is coming to an end and the time has come to assess the progress we have made in tax justice in the European Union. I would like to start by thanking the European Parliament, thanking all of you for your support throughout this mandate. Our two institutions have become natural allies in the fight against fraud and tax optimisation. We have exchanged very regularly, here or in Brussels, in the context of hearings and various special committees (TAX and PANA), and the reports you have published have fuelled our discussions and reflections on tax justice. It was absolutely imperative that we take action to strengthen tax justice in the European Union. In recent years, repeated scandals have revealed the shortcomings of our tax rules, which are visibly unable to combat fraud and tax optimisation. In addition to the shortfall in our public finances, which are estimated at between 50 and 70 billion a year in the European Union for VAT alone, these scandals have created a legitimate sense of injustice among European citizens, who have asked us to react. We heard their appeal and put tax justice at the very top of the European agenda; I am convinced that we have put the European Union at the forefront of this fight. Since 2014, we have managed to get fourteen proposals passed, eight of which are against fraud and tax optimisation. Despite the lock of unanimity, this is more than in the last twenty years. Our action was based on three priorities. The first pillar for tax justice has been transparency. The lack of information is always, as you will have noted, at the heart of tax scandals. Fraudsters play on the culture of secrecy, the kind of grey area that surrounds tax practices, so I have acted to put an end to tax opacity in Europe. Perhaps our most emblematic proposal is the obligation of transparency for tax intermediaries. We are targeting banks, law firms or consulting firms, which are often the great architects of tax optimization and who sell their clients tax schemes sometimes at the borders of legality. This directive will require tax intermediaries, from 2020, to pass on their tax planning schemes to their national tax administrations. The aim is not to monitor to punish, but to give tax administrations the means to identify and correct loopholes in their legislation. Then we abolished the banking secrecy of the European Union. The various tax scandals, including the latest "CumEx" revelations, have shown that some companies, or some taxpayers, are taking advantage of the lack of coordination between tax administrations to evade tax, and it needed to be addressed. As of 2014, we have therefore generalised the exchange of information between tax administrations in Europe and it is now compulsory and automatic in the vast majority of cases: each Member State must pass on to all others the necessary information on accounts, on tax agreements between states and companies, and on the taxes paid by multinationals in each country. Finally, transparency requires the exchange of information, but also a strengthened dialogue between Member States on their tax practices and, as you know, the use of taxation as a means to attract the wealthiest businesses and taxpayers is not the preserve of a few islands here or there. Some COUNTRIES in the Union, let us not be afraid to say, are defending a tax framework in which tax competition is a tool for competitiveness. And if tax competition is legal, unfair competition is not, or rather it should not be. We have tackled this problem head-on. Last March, the Commission for the first time identified seven member countries whose tax systems are used in, say, aggressive tax optimisation schemes. It was a difficult process, but it was necessary because among friends, you have to tell each other everything. The aim is not to punish, it is not to stigmatize, but to contribute to the creation of a fiscal framework that is fair and modern, that ensures the Europe's global competitiveness, while protecting the interests of Europe's 500 million citizens. The second pillar of my work for tax justice has been the strengthening of international cooperation. We have long known that tax havens around the world are the indispensable drivers of fraud and tax optimisation. In response, the 28 finance ministers adopted, for the first time, a blacklist of tax havens around the world. Many were skeptical, many doubted the effectiveness and sometimes even the sincerity of our approach. However, a few months later, it is clear that the European voice has been heard. Almost all of the identified jurisdictions have made, and this was the objective, specific and credible commitments to get off the blacklist. The quality of a blacklist is not judged by its length, it is judged by the efforts made not to be included.  And I continue the discussion with third countries. I meet very regularly with many prime ministers and ministers who have never walked through the door of the Commission, simply because they fear the blacklisting process. It is terribly effective and we will present the results in detail. The European Union has also established itself as a world leader in good fiscal governance. It was the first to adopt the OECD measures known as BEPS. It has translated them into its legislation, in the ATAD 1 anti-tax evasion directives and also, above all, ATAD 2. We are involved in the work of the OECD and the G20. Today, I am particularly interested in the OECD working group's proposals, published at the end of January, on the revision of the rules on taxation of profits and the introduction, which I believe, of an effective minimum rate. We will have to move forward on this subject, we will have to follow these reflections very closely. The third and final pillar of my work for tax justice has been the modernisation of European tax rules. I realized very early on that the obsolescence of European tax rules led to situations of intolerable injustice and fiscal inequality. So I started a major project to modernise the European tax framework. The main components of this modernisation have been, on the one hand, the final VAT regime, which could, I repeat, put an end to cross-border tax evasion of fifty billion a year, and which would greatly simplify the lives of our businesses; and on the other hand, the consolidated common corporate tax base, which would allow companies to operate in the single market as simply as within a single country, is also a very big project. Another important element of my proposal is the taxation of digital activities. Today, the huge benefits of digital enterprises are little, if any, taxed in the European Union. This situation is obviously unacceptable, so I have put forward two proposals to ensure fair taxation of the digital economy in the European Union. The first is to modernize corporate tax rules by introducing the concept of digital presence. And it will become all the more important as the OECD has now embarked on the search for global standards. The second is the introduction of a temporary tax on the turnover generated by certain digital activities in the Union. It is now ten months since the Commission's proposal was on the table and if we were able to convince a large majority of Member States, namely 25 out of 28 countries, a handful of recalcitrants is still blocking, and I regret that. On the one hand, because our fellow citizens are waiting for us to put an end to this manifest injustice and, on the other hand, because some Member States, including France, Spain or the United Kingdom , which is still a member of the European Union - are starting to move forward on their own. And it is a risk to the integrity of our single market. I end with a consideration for the future. The so-called "DigiTax" dossier illustrates the limits of unanimity. I hope we have an agreement in March. The Romanian Presidency is working on it, I thank them, but I know it is complicated. If unanimity is surmountable when it comes to reactions to tax scandals and when public pressure is strong, it can paralyze when it comes to structural reforms (energy tax, climate change, DigiTax, financial transaction tax, consolidated common base, VAT). It is for this reason that I have proposed, here in the European Parliament in Strasbourg, the transition to qualified majority voting in tax matters, by means of the bridge clauses that allow to move the areas in which decisions are taken by Member States, unanimously, towards qualified majority. Very concretely, this would enable the European Union to react more quickly and effectively and it would, tomorrow, strengthen the democratic legitimacy of tax decisions taken in the European Union. Tomorrow, be aware, ladies and gentlemen, if the transition to qualified majority voting were decided, the European Parliament would be co-legislator and the interests of all Europeans would be better represented. This seems important to me, at a time when the desire for representation and the thirst for democracy of Europeans are so strong. That is why , I know that there are elections coming up , I would modestly suggest that the political parties look at this issue: if there were a very large majority tomorrow, here, on all benches, to demand this passage, it would be a game-changer. And some of the ministers I saw yesterday or at Ecofin, very reluctant, could not ignore it. Finally, it would broaden the scope of tax policy in Europe. We could pursue broader social objectives, such as environmental protection, through taxation of polluting activities or regulation of financial markets or taxation of financial transactions. I call on the European Parliament to take this proposal frankly, to bring the debate to life - it is not going to end now - because it is also a way for this institution to strengthen its authority. That, ladies and gentlemen, and, dare I say it, dear friends, taxation is a privileged instrument for strengthening justice in the European Union. I regret today that we are not using it fully, even though the need for justice is growing among many Europeans, with four months to go before elections of which we all know the importance, I call on the Member States to seize these subjects to send a strong signal to our fellow citizens and convince them, if need be, even more of the usefulness of Europe. But here we have a fine case of Europe's usefulness: without Europe, we cannot fight fraud and tax evasion, and Europe has shown that it can be an effective instrument. Let us continue in this direction, and thank you for your attention and support.

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, fair and effective taxation has been one of the key policy priorities for the EU over the last several years. We have adopted a series of legislative acts that target tax avoidance, tax evasion and tax fraud. We firmly believe that taxes have to be paid where the value is created and that they have to be paid promptly and in full. However, in spite of these efforts, the situation is still far from perfect. Globalisation and rapid technological change have opened ample ways for evading and avoiding taxes, especially for very large transnational companies, digital firms, and also when it comes to VAT on transactions in the EU. Revenue losses incurred by national budgets due to those tax abuses are estimated in hundreds of billions of euros annually. We must not tolerate this situation. Our citizens expect us to take decisive actions against these malpractices. First, we have to fully enforce the existing legislation on a mandatory and automatic country-by-country reporting. Second, we have to take a tough stance on non-cooperative tax jurisdictions, including tax havens, and intensify efforts at OECD level to come up with a global solution. Third, fair taxation of digital companies needs to be implemented. Fourth, I call on Parliament and the Council to urgently arrive at a common position on Common Corporate Tax Base (CCTB) and Common Consolidated Corporate Tax base (CCCTB) files. Finally, VAT fraud has to be effectively tackled with a combination of national and EU measures such as single electronic invoicing systems, split payments and automatic exchange of information.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I believe this debate is timely. When one looks at the identity of a political whole, the way it treats tax justice speaks volumes about the nature of its project. Behind a tax system, political priorities are expressed, the possibility of financing public services, protection and guarantee of citizens, all of which are today at the heart of the concerns of our citizens. However, we now know that tax evasion is estimated at EUR 825 billion per year, while the EU's 2019 budget is less than EUR 150 billion. There is a gap here that we cannot accept. We need to fight for better identification and greater severity with regard to tax havens. Today, an increasing share of tax-related revenues comes from consumption taxes, while VAT accounts for between 15% and 25% of Member States' tax revenues, not to mention the fraud edcover, while it is a tax that does not ensure redistribution. We need to move towards this 21st century tax, the one we voted for, the one we adopted, with a consolidated tax base and a numerical presence identified as a legislative basis. It is in this sense that we will be able to move towards more just taxation at European level, it is a real priority. And it is in this sense that the Socialist Group is proposing an effective rate of 18% across Europe for this corporate tax. You have put forward a step-by-step proposal to remove the unanimity hurdle in the Council. I wish us good luck in this way, I do not know how far we can go but I am sure that this European Parliament must support this opposition with determination, because this is the way forward ..." (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)""

name: Ralph Packet
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we were here today to talk about fair taxation for a just society. But if I listen carefully to some of my colleagues, I hear them not talking about fair taxes, but about more taxes. But the people who work, save and do business are just the people who carry our prosperity on their shoulders. Thanks to them, solidarity is possible. And today they feel punished in many cases by the taxes that are already sky-high. Now I hear some colleagues calling for even more taxes in the name of justice. But you confuse justice with forced equality. You confuse giving more opportunities with imposing more redistribution. For me, justice means that everyone has the same opportunities to develop their talents to the full, without unfair rules that favour certain groups, and without a policy that only benefits certain lobbies. That is justice and there is still a lot of work to be done. So let's focus on that and not on raising taxes.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, one of the keys to strengthening the European project is the reconstruction of its social vocation. A phrase that perfectly sums up what this means was put by the President of the Basque Government – the lehendakari – before the Community authorities in Bilbao: it is time to devote at least the same effort to rescuing people as we have dedicated to rescuing banks. The resources we need for this come from our tax systems. Clearly, the first condition for taxes to be put at the service of the redistribution of wealth that development creates is that they are fair and progressive. The second is to stimulate the real economy and penalize financial speculation. And, besides, make them efficient by collecting. Contributing to this from European level involves at least control, coordination and transparency between tax administrations. It is essential to stand up to tax fraud and aggressive tax avoidance and planning practices. And maintain a coherent attitude towards tax havens. It is also urgent to conclude with the harmonisation of corporate tax interest rates, and I would add that those who tax the estate. They are both tools that countries use to take care of taxpayers. They help to relocate taxation from where profits occur and undermine cohesion policies. But they also reduce tax revenue as a whole. They are the source, along with the depth of the crisis, of many of the cuts that have affected social spending across Europe. Subsidiarity also at the fiscal level. Bringing collection responsibility closer to the ability to spend is a great tool to prevent the deficit and stimulate the real economy. Because spending capacity is going to depend on collection. Proximity also prevents corruption and turns solidarity, as collective action, into a more consistent practice. This is demonstrated for decades by the Basque concert and the Navarrese convention, which could be an excellent laboratory for designing the operation of a European Ministry of Finance. Finally, the European institutions can do much to guide public spending on investments with social and European value. But they need more resources to make their operations of promoting and co-financing public works with European added value decisive; programmes to support the real economy or convergence and social cohesion. That's where European sovereignty begins. That is why I think it is a good idea that the financial transaction fee can contribute to that purpose.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Whether in Germany or in the EU, our tax system is unfair. The gap between rich and poor is widening. In Germany alone, almost one in three people can no longer afford unexpected expenditures of up to EUR 1 000. In absolute terms, this affects 20 830 000 people in Germany alone. Moreover, the number of children in poverty has doubled on the one hand and the number of wealth millionaires on the other has doubled since 2005. Poverty of one is the wealth of others. In the meantime, tax dumping is being made easy for corporations, which costs the EU-Member States several thousand euros a year, as has already been said. Top earners and the wealthy are touched with velvet gloves, while the general public is asked to pay. VAT remains one of the main sources of income for the state, while gangsters in pinstripes enrich themselves in their rip-offs with CumEX at taxpayers' expense. Such a tax system is poison to society, because it destroys social cohesion. We need high and effective EU-wide minimum taxes for businesses to prevent tax dumping, Europe-wide standards for the taxation of wealth and top incomes, a digital tax that has also earned its name, and a comprehensive financial transaction tax. In this way, we are creating an effective top-down redistribution that counteracts growing inequality.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Probably nothing in Europe jeopardises social cohesion, as do the major tax injustices. It destroys confidence in democracy when people feel that those who could actually contribute more to social cohesion are no longer effectively being asked to pay. It is essential that everyone contributes their fair contribution to the community. Contrary to some prejudices, a great deal has happened here in Europe in recent years. Across the political groups here in the European Parliament, we have driven the Commission, and the Commission has put forward more sensible proposals against financial crime and tax dumping than any Commission before. However, the truth is that, although many of these have been decided, some of the very big proposals – particularly on the harmonisation of corporate taxation, on digital taxation, on transparency on the tax payments of large companies and on measures against the 50 billion annual VAT frauds in Europe – have not yet been adopted. And the biggest obstacle is that we still have the principle of unanimity in the Council on tax issues. This is the brake block for tax justice in Europe. That is why it is right that we should overcome this principle of unanimity in the Council. But it is not just the individual tax havens that are blocking here, but the contradictions between the great unity here in Parliament and the behaviour of the Member States in the Council are glaring. We have a liberal government in Holland that is blocking European tax cooperation. We have the grand coalition in Germany that is blocking tax transparency for large companies and digital taxation. We also have Christian Democrat governments that block tax cooperation in Europe, for example, from Ireland. And that, ladies and gentlemen, does not fit together. If we ensure tax justice across the political groups, the member parties and the relevant governments throughout Europe must do the same. That is why, please let us discuss this issue of dual language in tax justice openly and honestly in this European election, because only Europe can ultimately close the tax havens through cooperation.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are almost five years away from the LuxLeaks scandal involving hundreds of multinational companies that over the years have gone to Luxembourg to sign fine tax rulings to pay even less than 0.1% in taxes when, within several Member States of the European Union, and especially in the eurozone, the level of corporate taxation reaches far greater figures. You understand that with this situation, so many citizens are disaffected by the European Union, when they see the work of this body, which is failing to put a stop to these practices and instead points to measures aimed at reforming certain systems in certain countries, such as the pension system in Italy or Greece, always requiring a levelling down to compensate for certain imbalances and the non-completeness of monetary union. In this situation, therefore, we ask why the Commissioner, with the same emphasis as he calls for reforms to be applied to the countries of southern Europe, does not ask for reforms to be applied to countries such as the Netherlands and Luxembourg, which we have all been waiting for for decades, because these practices are denounced by several investigative journalists who have also risked carrying out certain investigations. Because? Because perhaps there are strong powers behind it, capital as usual, whereas it is easier to punish the people who will most likely punish you at the next elections.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, 'fair taxation for a just society' is a great programme! But it is amusing to see that it was the Socialist Group that asked for this debate. How ironic when we know that it is these same socialists who have constantly imposed a totally unfair confiscatory taxation and which has had the sole result of stripping the middle classes and weakening their purchasing power. Meanwhile, the American internet giants pay little or no tax. On average, GAFA pay only 9% corporate tax in the European Union, compared to about 23% for other companies, particularly SMEs. What multinationals call tax optimisation is actually a vast system of tax evasion, which uses and abuses all the loopholes in our respective laws. In short, a kind of organized gang legal fraud. Our various tax laws have not been able to adapt, it is true, to the digital economy. But instead of helping Member States to fight these unscrupulous multinationals, the European Union encourages the free movement of capital, but also the liberalisation of services, especially since the famous Bolkenstein Directive of 2006. For his part, Donald Trump, who is often criticized in this Chamber, has managed to pave the way for the taxation of GAFA with his major tax reform of 2017. For our part, we must defend a simple and effective principle: multinationals must be taxed in the countries where their activities are located and where their turnover is generated.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, we cannot talk here today about fair taxation, when the Union itself, through its austerity and fiscal adjustment policies, imposes unrealistic taxes on some Member States. In Greece there are many factors that demonstrate why taxation today is far from fair. Wealth generation and incomes collapsed, but tax revenues didn't. Citizens see their incomes falling and most of them going to the state. Tax rates have been increased, the tax-free threshold has been reduced, tax exemptions have been abolished and new taxes have been added, e.g. ENFIA, solidarity levy, excise duties, etc. Within eight years, exceptional taxes increased by 94%. Tax revenues on citizens' property have increased from 500 million in 2008 to 3.6 billion. Greece is currently third on the list of The Member States of the European Union with the highest insurance contributions. High taxation not only hinders growth, but also drives thousands of freelancers out of the market. Moreover, the non-reciprocity of taxation, as after the memorandums the level of social benefits and government services has been terribly relegated... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Fair corporate taxation is an objective on which we can certainly all agree. The debate on how to achieve this objective is therefore right, and it is important. However, it is also important to me that we do the whole thing on the basis of facts. And the fact is that a lot has happened in this parliamentary term in the fight for fairer corporate taxation. This was also a success for us as the European Parliament, because we have always been uncomfortable and have put our finger in the wound. The anti-BEPS action plan has been implemented, the automatic exchange of information between tax authorities has been extended – we should not trivialise this. Before we think about ever more recent measures, it is certainly not wrong to look at how what has been said works, whether loopholes are still open and where improvements need to be made. I do not believe in demands such as the introduction of an effective minimum tax rate for companies. I also find the excitement about the fact that the effective tax rates are generally lower than the nominal tax rates, because companies make use of statutory and intended deductions, for example for research support or provisions for occupational pensions. Do we want to abandon this by changing the tax code? Or have we not decided elsewhere to do the opposite? That is why we should simply be honest and continue to make these opportunities possible. So before we throw the baby out with the bathwater, I am very much in favour of analysing what we have achieved and then looking at what we still need to do.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to build on what Mr Giegold has just made clear. If we in Europe want to make progress in corporate taxation, and if we want to abolish a situation that Mr Bay of the ENF has just criticised, then we need a set of instruments at European level that simply makes it impossible for individual Member States or several Member States to prevent any meaningful further development here that makes it impossible for multinational companies to pay decent taxes here in this European Union. If, at European level, we want multinationals to pay their share of the overall tax burden in comparison with small and medium-sized enterprises, then this will only work if we can set the appropriate framework conditions at European level. And they will never come as long as individuals or the merger can block what they want at European level, because we have unanimity on taxes.  It is therefore the be-all and the end- and it is essential – if we want to take the decisive step towards greater tax justice here – that we move from unanimity to qualified majority solutions. If we do not manage to do this, if the conditions that we have at the moment are maintained, then what Mr Giegold outlined a moment ago will happen, namely that we will see a lack of public acceptance of the pan-European system at this point. And if we want to convince people that Europe is advocating tax justice between small and large companies, if we want to convince people that Europe is advocating tax justice between the normal wage-paying taxpayer and multinationalcorporations, then we must deliver here. And for that we need a qualified majority at European level, because that is the only way that Europe can act effectively.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, fair taxation for a fair society presupposes the blow of tax evasion and avoidance and the blow of the tax rulings that we have seen with The LuxLeaks in Luxembourg by Mr Juncker and in the Netherlands by Mr Dijsselbloem. It assumes that multinationals will be taxed in the countries in which they make profits. In Greece, the troika and the Eurogroup have imposed austerity, violent fiscal adjustment, a reduction in pensions and tax evasion, which has now intensified as the Greek people are forced to pay 3.5% of primary surpluses in the pockets of lenders. This by 2022 and 2% of GDP for the next 38 years. ENFIA has been imposed. An increased value added tax was imposed on the islands and an increased oil tax, causing Greece to freeze. A fair society will only exist when Greece is rid of the troika and loan lenders.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I have approached the question of taxation as a strong supporter of both global tax justice and of tax sovereignty for national parliaments. I support Member States cooperating to set EU-wide rules for tackling cross-border corporate tax avoidance and I’ve pressed the Irish Government to stop facilitating industrial-scale tax avoidance by some of the wealthiest companies in the world. But tax justice is not the same as tax harmonisation, and I am resolutely opposed to the proposals made by the Commission to end unanimous decision-making in the Council. Millions of EU citizens, especially those in less powerful states, are concerned at this move towards qualified majority voting. Let’s be clear about what this means. It means that a tax policy could be enforced on a country against the wishes of the democratically elected government of that state. Such a move would further alienate people of the EU from the EU institutions – exactly the opposite of what’s required. What we need is to build consensus for tackling tax avoidance together.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the social contract is broken. In scenes reminiscent of our dangerous history, we are seeing revolutionaries of left and right in pitched battle on European streets. While I abhor their methods, I understand the sense of injustice that lies at the root of this conflict. Since the financial crisis, inequality has sharpened, with those who caused the crisis continuing to accumulate wealth and power, while the pain is borne by the weak and the poor. I have always believed that inequality is corrosive and that societies and people flourish when there is justice and fairness, but even if you believe that inequality is the engine of innovation and growth, you must realise that you need social stability and public consent for your businesses to make their profits. This Parliament has made great progress in the four investigatory committees on tax. I commend those Members who sit on the right side of this House for embracing the task of implementing a fair tax system, but I would implore them to share that message with their national governments, who are playing the beggar—thy—neighbour game at the behest of corporations and blocking any real progress towards a fair and equitable tax system in the Council. Corporations have used the process of globalisation to shirk their tax responsibilities. The expansion of economic systems beyond the reach of national governments has allowed the selfish and the greedy to find ways to hoard their wealth at the expense of others. Ensuring that the rich and powerful, whether companies or individuals, pay a fair share of their income and profits in tax is a necessary requirement of establishing a new social contract in the age of globalisation.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I hate tax. I think tax is the arbitrary taking from companies, from shareholders and from individuals of their hard—earned money. However, even from that point of view, you must understand – and I agree – that there is a requirement for tax in a civilised state. We need to look after those who require help, the weakest in society, and there need to be payments for defence, law and order, etcetera. However, when you take a position whereby you are redistributing, through the will of the state, the tax that is taken from people, shareholders and companies, into what you think are the right priorities, you’re taking away the freedom of the individuals involved to spend how they wish. What’s more, when you talk about cohesive, Europe—wide taxation at the same rate, you are taking away people’s democratic ability to vote for a government with lower taxes. Sometimes it may be the case that people want a government that will compete. I personally would like to see the UK tax burden, which is the highest since the war, reduced, and I would like us to have a competitive lower tax rate, simplified to stop avoidance but lower. I would like to encourage businesses and wealthy people to set up in the UK because we all benefit from the trade and investment that brings. If you are too cohesive and harmonised, you take away democracy and competition.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: – Mr President, tax morality is a great thing: the realisation that it is fair to contribute personally financially to the society that also includes you, a society in which you feel secure and free. But in the Netherlands, taxes have never been higher and the population has been experiencing a loss of wealth for two decades. The only reason why we are talking about taxation today is actually that this Parliament also wants European taxation. On top of national taxes, citizens also have to pay the party here, a party that is still getting more expensive. Moreover, the European Union is not even a society. Once intended as a vehicle for trade, today it is a derailed international legal system. No one feels at home in that. Fewer and fewer people feel free to do so. It is therefore right that the European Union does not have the right to levy taxes on its own. Mr President, it must remain so. The taxes are already far too high.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, when I hear the Commissioner here, when I hear the arguments in the House, I see more and more: it is obviously about tax evasion, it is about tax havens. Of course, it is an unbelievable injustice that in a country like Luxembourg today most companies pay only 2.2% of the tax if, as we heard at the beginning, Google and Facebook pay 0.8 or 0.4% of the tax. This is a social injustice. After all, how much would the worker, who goes to work every morning and gets back through the traffic jams in the evening, be happy if he had to pay only 2.0%, 0.4% or 0.8% tax. And what happens to these taxes that are collected? Public procurement, public works – the costs are rising everywhere, and the costs are exploding. What else can the citizen believe when he sees that on the other hand migrants get everything free: clothes free, apartment free, food free, doctor free .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are all aware of the figures: we lose EUR 000 000 in potential tax revenue every year. That is about EUR 2 000 per EU citizen. Cause: tax evasion, tax avoidance and tax fraud. That is unfair, and that is unfair. It also shows that, on average, small and medium-sized enterprises pay 26% tax and large corporations such as Google or Amazon pay around 1%. We need to put an end to this state of affairs. However, it must also be made very clear here: the proposals on this have been put forward by the Commission and the European Parliament. Common tax base for companies, country-by-country reporting for companies, the digital tax, the financial transaction tax – all of this we have agreed and decided here. We always fail because of the same issues: the disunity of the Member States, the lack of European cooperation, the disunity and selfishness of many and the need for unanimity in the Council. Because of too little Europe, we have too many tax havens and too little scope for action. For more justice, we need majority rather than unanimity. European tax policy is a prerequisite for eliminating injustices and for finding solutions for citizens.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, you, who represent a socialist government and are in the Presidency of the Council, have an historic opportunity. As you have heard, this Parliament is entirely in favour of the Council deciding, using the 'passerelle' clause unanimously to vote from now on on majority tax matters, which is essential if we are to be able to take decisions on which everyone, as you can see, even the extreme right, largely agrees, at least all those who think they are staying within the European Union. I therefore really suggest that you take this opportunity and give us a signal that there are also governments in Europe capable of changing the course of reality in the Council and not just in Parliament.  Mr Moscovici, I believe that you have touched on many important points and that we absolutely agree with them. However, I would ask you also to address the problem of a more general directive... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, tax fairness and the creation of a just society are things that we all, or at least most, want here. Yet some mystical force seems to hinder justice. Large international companies, which also have the influence to participate in the design of tax legislation and the ability to hire a large number of top experts to design and promote models of tax avoidance, almost invariably pay significantly lower taxes than small and medium-sized enterprises. In the most blatant cases, the tax rates of these large companies are even below 1%. Many private health service providers have participated in tax avoidance, and they have also made headlines in Finland for serious neglect of care for the elderly. These companies live off tax money, but the bulliest of them do not want to contribute to the payment of their share. This is unacceptable and we must tackle it hard.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this has been the legislature of the great tax scandals: the panama papers, the paradise papers, LuxLeaks, the cum-ex scandal and so many others. The freedom of movement of capital, the existence in the Union of genuine tax lairs, such as Luxembourg or Malta, and the impunity of the big banks make the European Union a real paradise for evadors: a great queue for tax evasion, avoidance and money laundering. But this paradise is only within reach of the market gods and great fortunes. Instead, citizens face increasingly regressive and increasingly abusive indirect taxes, job precariousness, ten years of cuts and austerity. In the meantime, in the European Parliament we only adopt recommendations and the European institutions adopt purely cosmetic measures and directives. Either we take tax justice seriously or citizenship will lose the little confidence it has left in these institutions. We have to take sides in tax justice.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, the overexploitation of resources and the unequal distribution of wealth have always played a central role in the process of the collapse of civilizations. That was the observation of Nasa researchers in 2014. Since then, inequality has continued to worsen. We live in a world where 26 billionaires own as much wealth as 3.8 billion people. In France, the richest 10% own more than half of the world's wealth. This is not normal. Citizens, tired of these inequalities, are not mistaken. Let us no longer wait to reduce these unbearable wealth gaps. We need fairer taxation, a tax system that is both more social and greener, which accompanies the necessary energy transition while helping the most modest, because the two must go hand in hand. Fairer taxation is also the end of privileges, the end of impunity for individuals and multinationals who practice tax evasion so easily. It is a political choice, on which the future of our societies depends.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Moscovici, you admitted some time ago that there are as many as seven countries in the European Union that carry out aggressive tax planning. I believe that we must call it by its own name, by its proper name meaning 'tax havens', and I believe that we must also name these tax havens: Belgium, Cyprus, Hungary, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta and the Netherlands. To this list must also be added the most hidden tax haven in the European Union, namely Germany, which owns as much as 5 % of the global offshore financial services market, resulting in tax havens more than Dubai, more than the Netherlands and more than Panama. Now, these countries are doing favours to the large multinationals – as has already been said – by making them pay less interest and even by not making them pay taxes on dividends, with the result that they are penalised and that the Union's internal market is gradually destroyed, as was the case with Apple and Nike. So what is the point of strengthening cooperation and improving coordination in order to avoid tax fraud when there are then these Member States that behave like real tax havens, which act unhindered as tax havens within the Union? The debate on unanimity is a good thing, but I ask why the Commission says that it only wants to act now, whereas for five years – we are at the end of its mandate – it has pretended not to see this theft by certain States that are part of the Union but which in this way damage it irretrievably.

name: Stanisław Żółtek (ENF).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by So! Taxation should be fair, i.e. small simple taxes, only to maintain state structures, ensure security and order. And what is the Union doing? He fights any country that has small taxes. It forces a huge excise duty on energy, fuel. He pulls the haracz on his monstrous administration. It creates a complicated and stupid law that increases bureaucracy and enslaves citizens. Today, the fair work of people in Europe is made up of people who live in poverty, bureaucracy and millions of immigrants who are being taken to Europe for free. Today's European Union is the bloodsuer sucking out of European citizens most of their wages and willingness to work.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner Moscovici, on this issue the Commissioner has brought up the question of the passerelle clause and, in essence, the transformation of unanimity into the creation of revenue for transformation into a qualified majority. I'm going to give you a novelty, which you may not know, Mr Moscovici, and the novelty is this: in the agreement that the Socialist Party, which is in government in Portugal, of Minister Mário Centeno, concluded with the PSD on the financing of the European budget, with regard to the future of cohesion policies, it has effectively established the following: "Increasing the reserve of the sovereignty of the Member States in the creation of taxes is essential to strengthen the revenue of the European budget without penalising taxpayers". It has therefore established that there is a national tax reserve and therefore I want to know whether Minister Mário Centeno, in Ecofin, defended the position that the Socialist Party endorsed in the agreement on the future financial framework which is that the revenues of the European Union have to go through the national parliaments afterwards.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, fair competition, social justice do not exist in a Union in which Member States rival tax dumping by letting one are tax hells of others and all being tax havens of kleptocracies on the planet. In Portugal, the Troika blessed the 2012 tax amnesty. A massive money laundering operation, while taxes on those who pay them were brutally going up. Shocking injustice is the Portuguese State, while continuing to use taxpayers' money to save banks, nothing has, to this day, recovered from overseas assets revealed by successive financial scandals, including the criminal tax blackout that, between 2011 and 2015, under the troika's gaze, allowed the diversion of more than ten billion euros to offshore without tax control or laundering. Yes, the path of tax justice passes through the European Union. What country alone can let the tech giants enact taxes on financial transactions? Not to mention the CCCTB or the pressing VAT reform to end the tax fraud that gives billions to organised crime, including terrorist groups. We absolutely need to end unanimity in the Council on tax matters. The shocking fiscal injustice is jeopardising democracy in Europe, it is jeopardising the European Union itself.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking about tax avoidance and loopholes. In principle, this House is only about tax competition. They want to abolish tax competition between nations. And when Mr Giegold and Mr Simon say that we need the principle of unanimity, that is exactly what it is: you do not want tax competition, you want the tax cartel.  And everyone knows that a tax cartel leads to higher taxes – that is the point of the tax cartel. This is also said: fairer taxes are higher taxes for you here. No! Higher taxes burden consumers and businesses, and then comes the digital tax. I don't know what all this is all about.  I mean, there are theories of upheaval: those who pay taxes are not the ones who pay the taxes. I would like to see something in terms of the theories and the facts of the tax transfer. No one in this House has examined what is happening to the money that has been earned. If it has been reinvested, it is well invested, because when it is distributed to the states, something socially nonsensical is done. It is important that companies invest. That is what matters.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, taxes are always paid by the taxpayers. You can hear that in the name. It doesn’t matter how you do it, but it will always be the taxpayers who pay tax, and the fact is that in the European Union we have the highest taxes in the world. European taxpayers are paying much more tax – 10% to 15% higher – than any of the economies competing with us. That’s a problem for jobs and investment which we won’t solve by having even higher taxes at European level, although you over there always believe that higher taxes are fair and just. It is fair and just that people can live on their incomes. It is fair and just that we can attract investment and get new jobs and more taxpayers: thatʼs fair and just.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: Mr President, 26 billionaires, including Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates, own as much as the poorest half of the world's population. The tech giants are the largest companies in the world and pay the least tax. The 99% of workers therefore make it against the 1% of big money and big data. Fair taxation, fair sharing. We must restore that principle so that they pay a fair tax contribution, including the multinationals and the billionaires. Europe can do this in two ways. Firstly, with a structural reform of the income tax. The current systems are dated, unable to cope with funding through the Cayman Islands or intellectual property in Bermuda. From now on, countries will have to decide where companies make a profit and therefore where they pay tax. The consolidated base, the CCTB, is exactly a proposal for this, and Europe must choose to do so. After all, why are reforms about health care, the unemployment law and pensions, not about income tax? Secondly, through a tax on the digital economy. The inequality that the world's largest corporations pay the least taxes is crying out for action. The digitax for advertisers like Google and Facebook, but also for Uber and Airbnb, can't wait. We have to do it now. But tax pirates such as the Netherlands, Ireland, Luxembourg and Malta are holding back this and want to continue the tax race, ostensedly out of self-interest, but ultimately for the benefit of big business and its shareholders.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – Mr President, any tax is an involuntary transfer from the taxpayer to public budgets. It is therefore very important that the power to tax remains with the Member States, because only these have genuine democratic legitimacy to tax citizens. Competition from tax systems and tax rates is good for the European Union. It is what leads to lower taxes on a ten-day course – that is what we want if we are to be competitive in the world. What is important, however, and what the Commission must do is make sure that states compete fairly, so that it does not happen that some countries, such as Luxembourg, negotiate special tax regimes with large concerns, as happened during the days of the current President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, when he was still Prime Minister of Luxembourg.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici, Portugal is a sovereign nation, it is not a region of the European Union. I believe in a Europe of Nations. The ability to launch and collect taxes is one of the sovereign manifestations of countries that I do not accept - when Portugal in the Council already represents only one vote - that Prime Minister Portuguese, António Costa, sell to Brussels at a balance price.  It was what was most lacking, that sixteen countries only, for example, decided to launch taxes on the sea Portuguese and Portugal, through their government, could not say "no". That's what was missing! We are absolutely against the end of unanimity in the Council on tax matters. Moreover, I wonder how does the Commission not know that Article 355 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union expressly prohibits the removal of unanimity where own resources are at issue? By the way, Commissioner, we are three months away from elections, then they complain that populism is growing. Do you think it is normal that, three months before the elections, on the back of national parliaments, the end of the unanimity of the States should be decided, the end of the right of veto? Now what difference between General De Gaulle, who was the one who set unanimity, a great European statesman, because of the vital interests of the States, and the socialist Pierre Moscovici and the Portuguese António Costa decided to sell the vital interests of their countries.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In tax justice, it is not five minutes to twelve, but five minutes after twelve. The Commission – Commissioner Moscovici, you have done your job, we in the European Parliament have done that. It is now up to the esteemed finance ministers, everywhere out there in Europe, to act. Please do this! Take this with you: it is an unimaginable EUR 825 billion that we lose every year through tax fraud and tax evasion. What could we not do with this money! Forty times, for example, finance the European Youth Guarantee, in other words helping unemployed young people in Europe out of their misery. For Austria, what does this mean for my country? Almost EUR 13 billion! What can we do with it? That's nearly half of health-care spending. In other words, unimaginable things that people in Europe also need. And that is why unanimity must go. Dear Finance Minister, act! It really is high time!

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, we often discuss fair taxation in this House. I would say this is because it is difficult to reach a consensus on what would be fair in the context of taxation. Some think wealthy should cover virtually all of the state's tax revenues, and others think it is necessary to reduce tax pressure so that those with more money can invest in good projects and create new jobs.  It is important to find balance and tax as much as necessary to raise enough funds for quality public services without jeopardizing the prosperity of the taxpayers' own. For this to be possible, the public sector needs to be reduced to a reasonable measure and keep public spending under control.  The state can always spend more and it's never enough. As a rule, public sector growth is also increasing inefficiencies, so the provision of public services should be carried out in partnership with the private sector. This leaves plenty of room to introduce rates that will not stifle taxpayers or force them to avoid paying taxes. I believe this is the right path towards fair taxation.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would point out right away that, for me, the Commissioner's speech was more than satisfactory. First of all, because he was not limited to this issue, but he was able to show more frankly what he looks like in the system of various financial commitments in Europe. What do I want to pay attention to? First of all, the fact that I do not believe too much in creating an ideal, universal, fair, fair tax system. However, I really believe that this should be our objective, and in my opinion many of the voices in this House have been aiming for this. What are the chances of achieving this fundamental objective? – large under three conditions, four can. Firstly, the fewer loopholes, the different tax differences in Europe, the better. Secondly, taxes should, of course, be universal and inevitable, i.e. automaticity will promote rationality here. That is what I want to draw attention to.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this debate which shows your interest in these subjects and also, beyond the differences in sensitivity, which are normal, since you are politicians, a certain convergence of views, at least what I see as a majority convergence of views, which I have seen since the beginning of my mandate and of our joint work. We have done a lot together and I think we should be proud of that. The mandate of this Commission and the mandate of this European Parliament will have been marked by absolutely decisive progress in the fight against tax evasion and evasion, which is totally unprecedented, and our citizens must be aware of this. I think that is part of the very strong achievements in this period where we sometimes fight Europe, where we criticise it, where we question it. But there is still a lot of work to be done and I will focus very quickly on three issues that I think are important. The first is the revision of the blacklist of tax havens. The challenge is to see- as I said , what commitments have been made and kept by third countries, to see if the overall system has been effective. I am sure that I know that many commitments have been made, member states will now have to stop the new lists, both the blacklist and the grey list. We will see - I believe - a lot of countries come out of the blacklists and grey, and others enter, because in truth absolutely spectacular movements will have been accomplished. I would like to say here that without the registration process of the Union, all this would not have been possible. The second is the tax on the digital giants. I am aware that it will be difficult to convince the few Member States that are opposed to it, but the debate will have to be sustained, the need to preserve the internal market, when more and more States are moving forward alone. I also believe that we must continue to campaign for this, the time for the Europeans is also important.
