Finally, I would like to add that discussions on digital taxation will have to continue, where the European Union will have to defend a clear and coordinated position. Progress is being made at the OECD and the topic will also be discussed at the G20 in Osaka. We must invite all our partners to take up this problem because a global response remains the most appropriate. The third is the passage of qualified majority voting. He has animated your debates and it does not completely surprise me, I find it quite natural. It is not a socialist who proposes it - I am a socialist - it is the Commission which has made a communication on this subject and you are well aware that the majority of the Commission is rather EPP than socialist, in truth. Why does she do it? Because it finds that the real problem for us is not the level of taxation, or the tax rates - we are not even proposing to go back to it, we do not have the competence - but rather the technology, the leaks, the loss of resources, those big multinationals that do not pay their taxes. Frankly, if we were able to recover all the fraud, for example at VAT, and make the multinationals pay for the internet, I take these two examples, so do you really think that our national sovereignty would come out weakened? I would add that qualified majority voting has become the rule in almost every area in the European Union. I take the example of judicial and police cooperation.  Who will make me believe that it is more complicated to do so in tax matters than in these matters, which are areas of sovereignty so dear to the States? But I do not want to pre-empt the debate; I know there will be no decision made in this mandate, but I wanted to start this debate. What for? Because this is a great citizen's debate and, I repeat, I hope that the next European Parliament will be made up of parliamentarians who will be attached to democracy and also to the powers of Parliament, to the control over the Council, and that they will urge ministers to go in that direction, because these are in fact rearguard battles. I do not know when it will happen, but it will happen, simply because that is the meaning of the story. Or we decide that Europe stops and that we are not able to have a real energy tax, a real taxation to fight climate change, a real taxation of digital, a real taxation of financial transactions and that we are powerless in a context where others - China and the United States, not to name them - are able to protect themselves , to be extremely offensive on the tax front.  That is why I think this debate is a healthy debate, that must be taken calmly and where true arguments must be exchanged. I am prepared to carry it to the end of my mandate, because I believe very strongly in this and because it was the right time to do so, when the citizens are going to debate these issues. I know that now the issues of combating tax fraud and evasion are at the very top of the European agenda. We will still have a lot to see together, a lot of fights to fight together, and I want to assure you that until the end of my mandate, until the end of the mandate of this Commission, I will be at your disposal to advance this cause to which I have really, since I am European Commissioner, devoted a great part of my time, a great deal of my energy because I think it is , quite simply, very useful, useful to Europe, useful to Europeans.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you so much for inviting the Council to the debate. We heard a lot of interesting thoughts and we listened to you and the bottom line of the debate today is that we share common values and we should continue to work together so that the tax systems of the EU Member States are fair and they contribute to our objective of a just society. We should not forget about the social dimension of taxation that was much highlighted today. We fully agree with the Presidency of the Council that this should be the case. At the same time, I think there was an issue everybody touched upon, which is to use qualified majority voting for taxation. You know very well that, under the current rules, in order to change the way you vote you need a decision of the European Council and this has to be followed by the agreement of all national parliaments. I think that the first step in that direction started with the communication of the Commission. It’s important that the dialogue on all these aspects has already begun. I think every one of us in the Presidency of the Council especially is scrutinising the communication of the Commission in order to build upon and take stock of the ideas that are there and to pass them to our leaders and our democratically elected national parliaments so that they reflect more thoroughly on these issues. I would like to express, on behalf of the Council, that we are confident that the Member States will continue to find the best way forward together and we will do our utmost as Presidency to contribute to this objective during our term.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – What should be a normal, ongoing quest to ensure that taxes are just and fair and are being paid, has been transformed into a wholesale exercise to bring about harmonisation of income and company taxes across the EU. The claim is that unfair tax competition needs to be eliminated. But harmonisation would favour the more advanced economies of the Union. The centrifugal forces in the Union that apply under eurozone, single market rules would continue to strengthen, reinforcing the divergences between regions that have emerged over the years. In reality, the only way by which the peripheral economies of the Union can reduce the lags between their economic performance and that of the ‘centre’ is by having recourse to tax flexibility. If even this is removed, then the only policy adjustment to reverse economic downturns will be a reinforced internal devaluation underpinned by austerity policies. That will become increasingly unacceptable to European citizens. Indeed, another aspect of the current political discourse about taxation abuse is that it provides a ‘progressive’ screen for political actors who back antisocial austerity policies. To counter tax abuses (which may or may not be rampant), what is needed is not harmonisation but total transparency in the administration of taxes.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Every time we adopt new tax legislation at European level, voters ask me what will be new now. Will we finally be able to catch those who are skilfully hiding their profits in tax havens, or will the new measures only be a new obstacle to micro-entrepreneurs who are already struggling with bureaucracy on a daily basis.  I have doubts about the way we're ever going to get to the green branch. As markets and business develop, we are open up to areas that are not subject to tax legislation. Skilful tax advisers are always one step ahead of us to worry about unfairness in taxation.  Nevertheless, I would like to take this opportunity to commend the work of the Commission, which is trying not to do so, and at the same time to warn the Member States to stick to the rules they adopt at European level, as this is the only way to maintain confidence in the European project.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – Fair taxation is a priority. It is now, and it always has to be. But it could be even better. Google, Facebook and other internet giants receive expensive gifts from the Member States. Europeans lose €825 billion a year in tax avoidance. This means EUR 1650 per European citizen per year. This can't last. From a democratic point of view, it is crucial that something changes. If this does not happen, the legitimacy of the Union will be compromised. But more importantly, europeans' money, which is now simply disappearing, can be reinvested in European society. If we ensure that taxes are spread more fairly among citizens and businesses, everyone can enjoy the system. Then no unreasonably high contributions need to be paid. We believe that a just world is possible. We must therefore take all the steps that are possible to achieve this. This requires the cooperation of the Member States. In our view, negotiating in an efficient manner is only possible by abolishing unanimity in the Council.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE)
text: Written. – Our tax system is clearly out of the blue today. Digitisation and globalisation cause borders to blur and companies to easily channel their profits to where they are least taxed. In terms of taxation, on the other hand, we remain stubbornly committed to our sovereignty. But how sovereign are we when there's nothing left to tax? For me, it is simple: taxes have to be paid where economic activity takes place. As long as we cannot regulate this, we should not be surprised if multinationals and internet companies on average do not contribute half of what our SMEs pay. That is why we urgently need to work on dossiers such as the CCCTB and a digital tax. The EU should be a trendsetter, but it is paralysed by quarrels and mutual vetoes in the Council of Ministers. The European Commission has opened the debate on the abolition of the unanimity rule in European fiscal decision-making. It will take political courage, but let us put an end to this once and for all so that we can tackle necessary issues.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on Soledad Cabezón Ruiz's report, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the evaluation of medical technologies and amending Directive 2011/24/EU (COM(2018)0051 – C8-0024/2018 – 2018/0018(COD)) (A8-0289/2018). I want to make the following statement before I make the following statement: blue cards will not be allowed, and, as far as catch the eye is concerned, depending on the time, because, at 17.00, you know very well, we have votes and we have to stick very strictly to the schedule to fit in this time. So, catch the eye we will evaluate when we see where we stand with time and ask each speaker to fit in time.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, I begin by reiterating my recognition that a European proposal from a health technology-assessing agency is timely and that it would do 'more Europe'. It is true that the European legislation on medicines developed since 1965, in the wake of the tydomidomid disaster, has contributed significantly to the improvement of health standards in the European Union and that we also believe today to have areas of improvement. The European Medicines Agency evaluates and authorises medicines on the basis of efficacy and safety, without taking into account quality in terms of effectiveness or added therapeutic value. Someone, like me, might even consider that it may not be ethical, as well as that it can bring sustainability to health systems. But the truth is that Parliament, echoing citizenship, wants to ensure access to medicines, to health technology. High prices in the context of the crisis were the trigger for these difficulties in access, but there is also a lack of adequacy between research and medical needs, and more quality is also needed. There is an excess of incremental research to the detriment of genuine innovations; some studies number them at 85%. Moreover, even high drug prices do not go hand in hand with the high therapeutic value added in many cases. In the case, in particular, of cancer medicines, which have seen their price multiply by more than ten, they have shown only 15% of them to show an increase in survival at age 5. Member States have been carrying out this quality assessment as part of the pricing and reimbursement process. Since 2003, the European Commission through EUnetHTA has funded collaboration between them to approximate criteria, methodology, improve and increase clinical evidence and establish the clinical value of health technology. In addition, advances in genetics, the latest medicines for ever smaller populations, advanced therapies or technology itself increasingly require more stringent clinical evidence, and sufficient in any case to be able to make decisions about it. However, despite the positive consideration by the Member States of this voluntary collaboration, they have not made use of it. The European Parliament also considers it necessary to deepen this collaboration and move on to a stability scenario, with a regulated and publicly funded procedure that improves access to health technology by European citizens, contributes to the sustainability of health systems and increases the quality of research, also aligning this research with patients' needs. The European Commission presented us with an HTA proposal, justifying it in the need to improve the functioning of the internal market and thereby the predictability of industry. While it is true that distortion may exist in the internal market, this cannot be the main objective of the proposal, since this distortion may in large part correspond to the conception of the medicine itself as one more consumer good and which is governed by market laws. However, this Regulation also does not have to oppose – and may be able to contribute – this improvement in the competitiveness of industry, stimulating quality innovation and improving research efficiency. Parliament's position has come to give an answer, in my view, to all these challenges which I have posed and, above all, seeking the necessary confidence in the process, ensuring independence, transparency, objectivity, scientific quality and external validation of the whole procedure. All this allowing for clear prominence and control by Member States through their national process evaluation agencies. And ultimately, ensuring that, although the clinical evaluation may be global, the decision is finally local. Member States may carry out their own re-evaluations to adapt them to their national contexts, within the national competences of the pricing and reimbursement system, which includes specific clinical criteria in addition to social, ethical and economic, away from doubts about possible negative effects on the sustainability of national health systems, as we have been shown. At the same time, it opens up new areas of collaboration in emerging health sectors such as precision medicine or the disinversion of outdated technology. In short,, as I said, a balanced, timely and guarantee proposal with patients and also with national health systems. So, in my own way of see, necessary. A constructive and dialogue position on the part of the Member States is now needed, to which this Parliament has always been open. The opposite may mean blocking the necessary discussion to improve access to health technology by patients in the European Union. A stubborn stance is not good, against and without dialogue or alternatives on the part of certain countries, which can only lead us to repeat previous experiences with other health dossiers that only end with the result that the only ones who end up losing are patients. This Parliament has worked hard and quickly to be able to close this dossier in this parliamentary term and send a very important message to European citizens, who have been asking us for improvements in access to medicines, health technology; which has health among its priorities, as the Eurobarometer repeatedly demonstrates, and which will assess us in the coming months at the ballot box. I therefore appeal to a constructive position on the part of the Member States in order to be able to close this dossier and give that answer requested by the European city.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to discuss the Commission proposal for a regulation on health technology assessment. Parliament has shown very active and constructive engagement on this file, which led to the adoption of the ENVI Committee report in Plenary on 3 October last. Once again, I would like to congratulate Ms Cabezón Ruiz for her excellent and timely work as rapporteur for this file. I also want to reiterate my thanks to the shadow rapporteurs, Ms Grossetete, Ms Meissner, Ms Konečná and others as well as the ENVI Committee, the Committee on Industry Research and Energy and the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Regrettably, negotiations between the institutions have not yet commenced, but the adoption of Parliament’s formal first reading position would send a clear signal on the importance of continuing to work on this file as we move towards the end of this mandate and onwards into the next one. The Commission appreciates Parliament’s overall support for its proposal, including a clear and ambitious product scope on medicinal products and medical devices. While time does not allow me to comment in detail on all the various amendments, I want to echo some of the points made by the Commission in October. First, on the issue of the national use of European joint clinical assessments, the Commission welcomes Parliament’s strong support in ensuring that joint clinical assessments will be used by Member States and will not be repeated. The approach suggested by Parliament to add some qualification as to the meaning of non-duplication of European clinical assessments at national level has been helpful in the ongoing discussions in the Council. While the issue is still open, it needs further discussion. It takes a step towards addressing the concerns expressed by some Member States. Parliament has also added that the legislation should not prevent Member States from conducting complementary clinical assessments outside the scope of the joint clinical assessment. I am ready to support such an approach. Other amendments were aimed at further qualifying the proposal. They stress that Member States continue to be responsible for drawing their own conclusions on the added therapeutic value of health technologies in the context of their healthcare and cure systems. The second general area I would like to comment on concerns the respective roles of the Commission and the Member States in the cooperation process. In this area the amendments follow the spirit of the text as they aim to clarify the Members States’ responsibility for conducting the joint work and the supporting role of the Commission. The third important area relates to the quality and transparency of joint work produced through EU cooperation. The proposed amendment should ensure the submission of appropriate evidence by technology developers and provide for a high scientific quality, independence and transparency in the joint work. There were important objectives of the Commission’s proposal and I’m convinced that the real added value of strengthened cooperation on HTA at EU level lies in the quality of joint clinical assessments. Together we are all much stronger. Lastly, let me stress that the Commission has concerns when it comes to the removal of the harmonisation of national rules related to clinical assessment. This was one important element of our proposal, notably to improve the functioning of the internal market while contributing to a high level of human health protection. In proposing such harmonisation of national HTA methodologies, we had actually responded to the previous calls for action from Parliament. Among those calls I remember that your resolution on access to medicines called for the harmonisation of HTA tools and methodologies, and it’s clear. I would like to conclude by stressing that the Commission welcomes Parliament’s constructive proposals and stands ready to continue to discuss and explore solutions to outstanding issues with the co-legislators. The Commission is currently fully engaged in the discussions in the Council as these continue to progress and we welcome the Romanian Presidency’s commitment to move the discussion forward. The HTA proposal is expected to lead to a saving and benefits for all key actors. It will support Member States in their investment decisions to prioritising truly innovative technologies. National authorities will be able to pool their expertise and avoid duplication of efforts, making better use of human and financial resources. Industry will benefit from clearer rules and greater predictability for their business planning, as well as cost savings. The healthcare sector accounts for approximately 10% of European Union GDP or 1 300 billion per year. But, above all, this proposal is about European citizens, about European patients. Patients are at the heart of this proposal, which aims to deliver more efficient, transparent and effective European Union HTA. The new model of EU cooperation has a clear potential to facilitate better access to innovative health technologies. Yesterday we discussed issues about women and cancer, about possibilities to guarantee access to new treatments and HTA is a tool which can help us address these issues. I therefore call on you to help make this initiative a success. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Lieve Wierinck
text: rapporteur for ITRE's opinion. Mr President, with this new legislation, we are taking a step in the right direction, for three reasons. Firstly, thanks to this European cooperation, patients with a rare cancer or a rare disease are more likely to have the availability of a medicinal product that works. Provided the necessary privacy protection, Member States will have access to large-scale research data. Secondly, the clinical evaluation of new health technology ensures that Member States are kept informed of market developments and whether these products work better than those already present on the market. By putting innovative developments in the spotlight, we are stimulating our health sector at European level. Thirdly, I am satisfied that flexibility remains, both for the Member State and for the coordination group that is compiling the evaluation. Member States shall decide whether to provide a reimbursement system for this new technology. The coordination group retains an overview of which new technologies are groundbreaking. If we are to draw the full map of research and innovation for Europe and put the patient first, then a European evaluation of health technologies is the way to go, together with the Member States.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, as I mentioned previously, I welcome the new proposal aimed at strengthening EU cooperation on health technology assessment. I’d like to thank Ms Cabezón Ruiz and my colleagues for the close collaboration. I believe that joint clinical assessment should be done at EU level in order to shorten the process and provide faster access to innovative drugs for all patients in the EU without jeopardising the final decision of the Member States. As the rapporteur in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I took particular interest in two main objectives of the proposal: to increase the level of human health protection and to ensure better functioning of the internal market. We amended the proposal so that health technology developers would have the possibility to request an update of the clinical  assessment where additional evidence from clinical practices became available, and we also asked for a flexible mechanism to introduce innovative technologies and treatments for patients. I support adoption at first reading. I hope that under Romaniaʼs Presidency an agreement will be reached, but I’m sure that the Romanian Presidency will achieve important progress.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, the treaties remind us that Europe's mission in health is to give everyone equal access to quality care. So how do we understand that the clinical added value of a drug allowed throughout Europe differs from country to country? How can patients be explained that the same treatment is considered innovative, useful and effective across the border, when it is considered to have less added value in their country? How do you tell a patient that they still have to wait to get this new drug that is already available in the neighbouring country? Let's make no mistake about it. It is not a question of talking about prices and reimbursement, but of jointly conducting a scientific assessment of the therapeutic added value of a new technology, compared to existing alternatives, in order to promote higher value-added treatments, to enable Member States' budgetary decisions and to speed up patients' access to medical innovations and then also to avoid duplication of work; this would cause all its added value to our common procedure to be lost. I regret that the reluctance of the Member States has not allowed us to move faster on this essential text. Thanks to our rapporteur, however, in September we adopted a reasonable text which was to help overcome these differences. Today I call on the Council to think of the patients to whom greater European solidarity in health can only benefit.

name: Biljana Borzan
text: On behalf of the S&D. – Mr. Chairman, the reform of the health technology assessment system is one of the main requirements of the Medicines Access Report adopted in 2016.  I am pleased that despite the negative signals from some Member States, the Commission has recognised the potential of an expanded and reformed HTA system. The benefits of close cooperation between national and regional HTA bodies will ultimately benefit everyone: patients, pharmacists, doctors and health systems. The new platform will save Member States and their authorities time and money by avoiding unnecessary repetition of assessments already made by other countries. This is especially true for countries that have small HTA capacities.  Unfortunately, these arguments were not sufficient for the Member States in the Council. When it comes to health and health, time is not money, but life, and that is why I must express my displeasure with the Council's refusal to start negotiations.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. It is indeed the case that we have had very good cooperation on this legislation in Parliament, and I would like to express my sincere thanks. That was constructive, and it was really very important.  Because what have we achieved now is this: what have we achieved? That access to medicines for patients should be faster, because we want to have a decentry authorisation. It makes no sense at all that instead of just once, we should go through this up to 28 times – as it is at the moment. This is really not something we need. And, in principle, this simplification benefits both patients and public authorities, scientists – in fact, all, including manufacturers. Nevertheless, the scepticism of the Member States was very strong. In other words, large Member States such as mine – Germany – and Spain have protested and said: this is not something that is at EU level. I think they are completely wrong. It is important that everyone, including the small countries, which may not have so much research, can benefit from the fact that people throughout the EU can benefit from centraladmission. That is why I think it is perfectly good that we have this law now. It was important to me from the outset to see, on the one hand, where the Member States themselves might also need competences, and, on the other hand, to see what is happening with medical devices. I was rapporteur, as was Mrs Borzan, on the medical device regulation. And just a year ago, we adopted something that would give medical devices more safety standards, better requirements for performance, etc., regardless of their class. We also have the clinical added value in it. And I didn't see that we should make the same demands with THE HTA now that we are implementing it. I would therefore have preferred to have said that we are making a strong law on medicines here, and that medical devices will be considered later. That was not quite a compromise line. However, I think we have found a very good compromise in which we have very much narrowed the application to medical devices. I would like to mention something else that has not yet been mentioned, which was not included in the Commission's proposal: these were methods that can be outlined for the implementation of HTA. They are now in it. Some of these are already good practices, and I think that is good for the Member States and their experts who are supposed to work on them. Finally, it is also important that we have now taken account of national assessment systems, some of which are different. For example, there are different definitions of survival and quality of life in the basis of reimbursement. This is not equally weighted everywhere, and that is why we must also be able to carry out national criteria without duplication, of course.  It is a pity that the Member States do not follow us, otherwise we could negotiate. That would be good for patients in Europe.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I must say that I am extremely disappointed with the current situation. The option in which we voted on the document is rather weakened in itself. And the proposal focuses purely on clinical trials. Both economic, social and ethical aspects have been eliminated. We have also provided for an extremely long transitional period, during which Member States will not have to participate in the system at all. Our solution to joint medical device assessments essentially means a veiled removal of medical devices from the system. Apparently, too, this too will come to the Member States too little. I am beginning to wonder whether it makes sense to discuss this proposal further, because if it were further weakened by the Member States, it would probably be better to stay with the current voluntary cooperation in the end.  Meanwhile, European patients are desperately waiting for this new treatment and are also indignated by our postponed mandatory assessment by many years. Patient organisations quite rightly expect to be more involved in the evaluation process. The exceptions we have also adopted for faster access for patients to orphan drugs must be put into practice as quickly as possible, because the successful fight against rare diseases is a fundamentally cross-border matter. The Member States, headed by the Austrian and Romanian Presidencies, should be ashamed. We have no choice but to move the necessary document into a new period, which is a disgrace.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Can you imagine that a new cancer drug, which is new to the market and has been positively evaluated by the European Medicines Agency, will prolong the lives of patients in France by one year, in Germany by two years, and not at all in Italy? I can't imagine that. Fortunately, there are national differences, differences in mentality, but in terms of the effect of drugs, we Europeans are quite similar. That is why it must be possible to do this scientific part of the evaluation in Europe in a uniform way. It is a waste of resources if the authorities of the Member States, as well as companies or other applicants, have to do this 26, 27 times. That is why I still believe that the Commission has made a good proposal and that Parliament has also delivered a wise opinion on this. We should not exaggerate, Mrs Koneen: ethical assessment is a matter for the Member States – the Member States have a strong competence – but as far as scientific evaluation is concerned, this must be possible. I regret that the Council was not prepared to do so. We have included all the legitimate concerns of the Council in our decision-making, and it is therefore a pity that we have to take this decision tomorrow. But we should keep up the pressure. This proposal must not die, but must be adopted at some point.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, research, innovation and the new and good economy meet to achieve a qualifying objective, that of a Europe that puts people and their rights at the centre. Thinking about evaluation models that simplify procedures means gaining time and quality, avoiding duplication and overlapping, guaranteeing results based on the sharing of paths within a grid of quality parameters, having at its disposal a bouquet of good practices recognized as such.  Centralized authorisation, therefore, is the objective of this proposal that meets the demand for quality, that improves the overall performance of research and clinical trial paths and that contributes to making compatible the objective of sustainability of the costs of health systems with the effectiveness of care, making accessible technologies and drugs intended for the diagnosis and treatment of complex and rare diseases that put a strain on health systems , patients and families.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, proper health technology assessment (HTA) can be the unbiased tipping point for the game-changing technologies available for patients. This is a matter of supranational interest for European citizens and cannot be weighed only by economic factors. Assessments, pricing and reimbursement can be set as a touchstone for the sustainability of health systems. So far, this is the only tool able to ensure that citizens have affordable and effective treatments vis-à-vis the values demanded by profit-making manufacturers. However, the reality shows that HTA is fragmented throughout Europe. In fact, by reaching different outcomes, these assessments leave citizens and health professionals with different spans of choice, according to their Member States. Here, you can also count on us to fight for equal opportunities. This proposal relies on the collaboration of Member States but still leaves room for national decisions. By centralising the clinical assessment we can avoid duplication, save resources and, above all, create a European Union with less asymmetry in access to health care. This proposal is only effective with the combined efforts of the national regulatory agencies and I greatly salute the integration of patient representatives in the assessment procedure. This will make HTA involved from mere farmer ecological data on to a more realistic evaluation. That weights the contributions to the patients’ quality of life. But for the assessments to be beyond any doubt, they need to be as transparent as possible. This is the only way to build confidence in the health technology chain of value. I hope this regulation will bring us closer to the united, safe and healthy Europe we all long for.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The approval of medicines and medical devices must be bundled in Aeurope of uniform and comprehensible scientific criteria. Due to the proliferation of various national medical assessment regulations, some products are approved earlier in one Member State, approved more quickly than in others. With the new cooperation mechanism, we could speed up access to the latest and best medicines and treatments for Europeans and ensure that they are assessed on the same criteria throughout the European Union. This includes medications, medical devices and products such as prostheses and artificial joints. Common European approach to clinical testing, scientific consultation and evaluation of new technologies on the market not only makes processes more efficient and faster, but also enables much more thorough testing procedures before a product is approved on the internal market. We call on the Council to stop preventing this.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a very high proportion of new medicines placed on the market do not show a clear technological improvement compared to existing medicines. Competition is often played more on the name of the drug than on its composition.  This Parliament has done a great deal of work on introducing the European evaluation of the added therapeutic value of health technology and on harmonising the criteria for clinical evaluation of medicinal products, which would lead to a higher quality of research and innovation and the elimination of unnecessary duplication. If the aim is legislative harmonisation leading to an improvement in the quality of the drug market, the system for evaluating health technologies cannot be voluntary, as Germany would like.  Unfortunately, after a long legislative process, the citizens of Europe will not see this regulation finally approved by the end of the parliamentary term due to the lack of unity of purpose in the Council. With tomorrow's vote, we are handing over our final position to the next European Parliament, in the hope that in the interests of the citizens of Europe we will be able to arrive at a shared position as soon as possible.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it’s extremely important that, this time, we do even better and more coherent work on health technology assessment than the Commission and Parliament have so far managed, because the regulatory framework is either disabling or enabling, depending on whether you look at it from the patient’s perspective, the user’s perspective or the competitiveness and business perspective. If we have 28 different kinds of regulation, there’s always this unfair and unjust practice. Some get the applications and some do not, and you can’t create European e—health digital medical devices and medicines, to be provided for everybody, if you have 28 different kinds of regulation. So it is vital that we have an enabling European framework, with only very stringent exceptions, to be there for the patients’ and markets’ sake.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, health technologies obviously need to support people, to support the patient, because health is a public good. However, when the whole process of developing health technologies enters the internal market, then the main thing is the market. In other words, health is transformed into a commodity and is put at the service of multinational groups and pharmaceutical companies. We must therefore achieve health technologies that are in favour of the patient himself and that there are cheap medicines, in order to effectively address the dominant problem, which is to support the health of patients. Unfortunately, in Greece, by imposing its own policies, the troika has removed important medicines — such as cancer medicines — from the health system. Expensive cancer drugs, which Greek patients are unable to obtain.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened to your views with great interest and thank you for your overall, very strong support and I see that we are all like-minded here. I can assure you that the Commission will carefully analyse all the points raised by Members in today’s discussions. Let me reiterate that the Commission is ready to provide its expertise to the European Parliament and the Council in order to support the negotiations and facilitate possible compromise solutions. As has been recognised by the European Parliament, the proposed regulation will benefit a wide range of stakeholders, including Member State authorities, health technology developers, the healthcare providers and payers and, most importantly patients, across the EU. Equal treatment and equal access is the cornerstone when we are speaking about innovative treatment. I can assure of the full support of the Commission towards reaching an agreement on this important file. Once again I thank you for your continued support, and let’s do our best to encourage Member States now to once again reassess their positions and move as soon as possible to final conclusions.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 14.2.2019. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments in anticipation of voting.)

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr. President, the finalist of the 2018 Sakharov Prize, Nasser Zefzafi, leader of the popular Rif movement, is seriously ill in prison and is not allowed adequate medical assistance. I believe that it is part of the European Parliament's commitment to human rights and with a finalist of the Sakharov Prize to demand that the Moroccan Government be immediately released so that it can be treated by doctors, so that their family can be given the medical part, so that freedom can finally be given to political prisoners of the Rif.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you colleague. As Vice-President with the human rights portfolio, I will pass on this communication to the President at all.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have received a letter from the father of Amaya Coppens, who is a Belgo-Nicaraguan citizen who is in prison, in Nicaragua's prison, accused of terrorism, and with whom we, who were there, meet. She was beaten in jail in retaliation for the encounter she had with us, so she told us, and now she does not receive visits from her family. This is horrible and one more reason to add my voice to that of teammates Jáuregui and Gabriel Mato, calling for the president's intervention in relation to this repression of the duo Murillo—Ortega in Nicaragua.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr Gomes. In the same way, as I said to Mr Urbán Crespo, I will pass on the communication to the President as soon as possible.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Isabella De Monte
text: Rapporteur. In accordance with Rule 59a of the Rules of Procedure, I request that the matter be referred back to the Committee on Transport and Tourism for the start of negotiations with the Council.

name: Pavel Telička
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would never have expected the Greens to provide a helping hand! (Laughter) In any case, in accordance with Article 59, I would like to ask the House to agree to referral to the committee for interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you Vice-President Telička, thanks also to the Greens for the chivalrous help. (Parliament approved the request)

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I, like my predecessors, ask, pursuant to Article 59a, to refer the document back to the Committee on Transport in order to start interinstitutional negotiations. Thank you.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all my colleagues for their strong support and, in accordance with Rule 59(4), I would like to request referral back to the committee to enter into interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the reason for the oral amendment is we have left two members of the cannabis family out of what should have been there. It should also include cannabis indica and cannabis ruderalis. Cannabis ruderalis has very low amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) in comparison to cannabidiol, which is what some people want here and cannabis indica has a better balance of cannabidiol with THC, so if you want to do it right, include this.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group, I object to this oral amendment.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union on Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the future of the INF Treaty and the impact on the European Union (2019/2574(RSP)).

name: George Ciamba
text: (President-in-Office of the Council) on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am here on behalf of the High Representative to convey her message on this subject of great importance for European and global security. The Treaty on Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces in Europe (INF), signed by Presidents Reagan and Gorbachev in 1987, is among the key international agreements which marked the end of the Cold War. While neither the European Union nor any of the EU Member States are parties to the INF, we do have a very high stake in the preservation and the implementation of this treaty. Due to the INF, some 3 000 missiles with nuclear and conventional warheads have been removed and have been destroyed. This happened under mutual supervision in the form of on-site inspections. The INF Treaty is also an important contribution to the disarmament obligation under Article 6 of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT). The EU and its Member States are united in their support for the NPT, which remains the cornerstone of the global nuclear non—proliferation regime, the essential foundation for nuclear disarmament and an important element in the future development of nuclear energy applications for peaceful purposes. The NPT has made a crucial contribution to international peace, security and stability over the last 30 years. Let me recall that all NPT states parties are committed to pursuing policies that are fully in line with the treaty and the objective of achieving a world without nuclear weapons. We, as the Union, stress the need for concrete progress towards the full implementation of Article 6 of the NPT, especially through an overall reduction in the global stockpile of nuclear weapons, taking into account the special responsibility of the states that possess the largest number of warheads, namely the Russian Federation and the United States. But the INF Treaty is not only about prohibition of intermediate-range nuclear-armed missiles, it is about an entire category of ballistic and cruise missiles, regardless of their warheads. In the view of the High Representative, the United States and the Russian Federation need to remain engaged in constructive dialogue to preserve the INF Treaty and ensure its full and verifiable implementation, which is crucial for Europe’s, and global, security. Obviously an arms control treaty which is not respected by all of its parties is not sustainable. The EU, our Member States and the United States have raised many times in Moscow our serious concerns regarding Russia’s compliance with the INF. These concerns have not been addressed so far, and the treaty now seems to be on its way to unravelling. The INF is not outdated and we, as Europeans, very much hope that the INF Treaty will still be saved. We do not want to return to a Cold War. We do not want another arms race in Europe or anywhere else in the world. We call on all parties to urgently engage in a dialogue on strategic stability with arms control at its core. Arms control is crucial to our collective security. The world does not need a new arms race that would benefit no one and, on the contrary, would being even more instability. Thank you for your attention. This was what the High Representative would like to share you, and I do so on her behalf.

name: Michael Gahler
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the The INF Treaty and its foreexistence are in the best interests of Europe. Since 1987 and in the implementation of this Treaty, we have seen a whole category of weapons disappear from European soil. That should continue. It is all the more regrettable that, unfortunately, we have had to find out that the Russian Federation has been violating this Treaty for a number of years – as the Obama administration has already noted.  In the long term, of course, a treaty that seems to be binding on only one side is not tenable. Nevertheless, it is not tolerable for us that both sides ultimately took the opportunity to withdraw from this Treaty. We therefore call for Russia and the United States to sit down again, and if we Europeans can be helpful in this, then we should do so. This is what we expect from our executive side. In this context, we should always bear in mind that the loss of this Treaty is also a bad omen for other categories of weapons, namely strategic weapons. The START Contract expires in 2021 and I fear that if we cannot get the substance of this INF Treaty, we will also see a threat to the START Treaty. This cannot be accepted politically.

name: Clare Moody
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their work on this resolution. It is an important statement on behalf of our Parliament about a treaty that has made our continent and our citizens safer. The EU has been the main beneficiary, and it is in our interests to return to effective implementation of this treaty. However, it was the Obama administration, in 2014, which first stated that Russia was in violation of its obligations under the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty and there has been no subsequent demonstration of Russia’s compliance since then. Having the INF Treaty provides a framework that helps to avoid misunderstandings and miscalculations. It is also imperative that the right signals are sent on other arms control and disarmament treaties, most particularly the continuation of the new Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START). Although our priority should be to preserve the benefits the INF Treaty has brought, we call on the High Representative to explore new, additional multilateral avenues to deliver arms control. For these reasons, the resolution makes clear that we want Russia to return to full compliance with the INF Treaty and for the High Representative to take the necessary action to ensure the continuing protection of our citizens that a revitalisation of this treaty would present.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I very much welcome the statement made by our S&D colleague. If I may, just a tiny bit of history. In 1977 the then Soviet Union began deployment of the SS20 mobile nuclear armed intermediate-range ballistic missile with the range to target all of western Europe. This had a political as well as a military objective. The political objective was to create dismay among Western European governments, to stimulate the so-called peace movement and to create division between the Europeans and the United States, whose territory was not directly affected at that time. NATO responded with an effective dual-track approach, and the tough stand taken by the West, led by President Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, and the desire by Gorbachev at the time to move forward, enabled the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty (INF) to be signed in 1987. It was a great achievement. Now, new forces are at work in Russia and once again, it would seem that opportunities are being seized to create dismay and divergence between Western allies. Over the past five years, we’ve observed development of a cruise-missile system, the 9M729 by Russia, which is in breach of the INF Treaty. Just as in the 1980s, now we must respond again with absolute transatlantic solidarity. I’m pleased that the joint motion is evidence of this and the ECR fully supports it.

name: Urmas Paet
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, recent developments indicate that the INF Treaty is likely to come to an end. This is unfortunate for its biggest beneficiary, Europe. Since the United States has already confirmed that Russia has been in violation of the INF Treaty for years and NATO is also convinced that this is the case, and both the US, and later on Russia, have notified their intention to withdraw from the treaty, Europe might be facing another race to arms. Time is of the essence, and it is imperative that Russia uses this six-month period to return to full and verified compliance with the INF Treaty. That is the goal. Meanwhile, the possible end of the INF Treaty shows us that there is a much larger problem, and that is the current state of affairs between Russia and the Western world. These developments indicate clearly that it is imperative to enhance cooperation between the Western countries, between NATO and the European Union – to demonstrate the unity of the Western world in response to Russia and others on this issue. While the end of the treaty should be avoided by means of negotiations, it also demonstrates that the more global approach is needed on this issue, since time has moved on and there are more players in the game, like China and others. Also new technologies have to be taken into account, like cyber and outer space. So, ideally, a new strategic stability framework would incorporate the essence of the IMF treaty and new players both geographically, but also new technologies.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I am sure that almost everyone here in the Chamber who wants the INF Treaty to continue and uphold the INF Treaty and who stand up for it. That is why we must also consider what we in the European Parliament can do to ensure that the INF Treaty remains in place. I would like to say this here also because it is clear to us, as the Left Group, that the struggle and the effort for disarmament, peace and stability on the European continent must be and remain the central concern of the EU and all external action by the EU and its individual Member States. Yes, and nuclear disarmament in particular must be mentioned first these days. This is also the aim of the resolution, which in many parts sets the right tone. But I think we are also pushing ourselves around a specific question. The US is abandoning all international agreements and institutions. The existence of Europe is now in jeopardy. If the EU ambassador to Washington is downgraded, it also has to do with how American foreign policy is to be shaped today. And this is also part of the action of President Putin, who is reacting to this central strategy of the United States, so to speak, one-to-one. The violation of the nuclear disarmament agreement began in 2002 with the ABM Treaty. And now we have the situation again: what will happen to the INF Treaty? Today's press conference by NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg made it quite clear what lies behind this facade: the Allies do not want to react one-to-one, but they say: we will deploy an additional 30 battleships, 30 land battalions, 30 air force quadrilles within the next 30 days or just below. And as a result, an additional USD 41 billion will be invested in defence spending. In other words, the European continent is once again in danger of being the pawn of the arms race. We should not allow the games of nuclear weapons between the United States and the Russian Federation to be played on the backs of the People of Europe. Nor do we need a new deployment of medium-range missiles, wherever they may be, by the Russian Federation and the United States. We must therefore really engage in diplomatic negotiations in order to enable the INF Treaty and possible further multilateral agreements.

name: Klaus Buchner
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Global disarmament and non-proliferation of nuclear weapons is one of the most important objectives of our present.  For us Europeans, the threat of repeal of the INF Treaty is a step into a dangerous world. The European Union must now take the lead, together with the Member States, and mediate between Russia and the United States. It is therefore essential to promote multilateral nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation by all political means. That is my urgent request to the High Representative and Vice-President. Neither Russia, the US, nor China, nor any other country will make their countries safer through a nuclear arms race and even more missiles. The more nuclear weapons – whether short,medium, or long-stretched – are directed at major cities, the greater the risk of causing millions of people to die in agony as a result of a misjudgment or a technical defect.  Mutual inspections and verification measures must be resumed immediately in order to investigate mutual allegations and to save the INF treaties. This has not happened in recent times. Our legacy to the next generation must not be a future European Hiroshima.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, invalidation of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty will certainly undermine European and global security and peace. However, the real problem is that Russia is introducing into Europe its new missiles, capable of carrying nuclear warheads. Russia has continued to do this for several years, clearly violating the INF Treaty. Parliament was therefore right to condemn the Russian Federation for continued breach of the INF Treaty. Still, Russia has a chance, until July, to return to full and verifiable compliance. International, effective and credible arms control remains the basis of European security. However, facing aggressive disregard by Russia of its commitments, there is really no other course of action for NATO, in the foreseeable future, than to be united, determined and fully prepared to foil or prevent any tilting of the international security balance by countries relying primarily on force and intimidation.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The termination of the INF Treaty by Washington and Moscow is a dangerous mistake on both sides – a dangerous one, especially for us in Europe. I am outraged by the apparent lack of willingness to save and develop it. Moscow could have presented credible evidence against Western accusations long ago, and Washington could have long since pushed for negotiations. If the New START agreement is not renewed in 2021, we will have the situation for the first time since the mid-1960s, without any international treaty to restrict or prevent nuclear armament. We need a better INF treaty, with better scrutiny on both sides. But one more thing: if you want China on board, you have to find other ways than to destroy existing rules. Above all, I expect visible efforts from the EU Foreign Ministers and the High Representative. Don't accept us becoming a pawn for other people's geostrategic plans! It is primarily about our safety and that of our children.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by None of us want Europe to be a battle of great powers, but we cannot be blindly faithd that every good intention materialises. Nor can we leave the United States solely responsible for our security if we are aware of Russia's aggressive policies, and the principle of Russia's policy is always to probe the resilience of adversaries – those whom they designate as adversaries. If we do not react, we will not guarantee that Russia will withdraw from actions that destabilise security or threaten peace. In this situation, in which our allies deem it necessary to declare this treaty non-functioning, we only have allied solidarity and adequate responses to the threats that Russia is currently posing. We have recently seen pressure for Belarus to rendud its independence. In fact, apart from resolutions, we do nothing, and in fact solidarity in this case does not cost much money.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I have had the privilege of living during a period when walls between countries were dismantled, when disarmament and détente between countries was a reality in our neighbourhood. A period when the Cold War ended and we began to socialize with each other, when the borders were opened and trade between our countries increased. But now it looks different. The climate threat is the greatest threat to us humans on earth and not long after that comes the nuclear threat. Both can be avoided if the political will exists. If countries can agree on both the budget and the rules, we can cope with both climate change and peace. But instead of disarmament, we are seeing a rearmament around the world. More and more countries have acquired nuclear weapons. Development of unmanned weapons systems has been going on for a long time, now also a race over who first acquires lethal autonomous weapons. The fact that the US-Russia INF agreement is now crashing is extremely worrying. Nevertheless, the agreement scrapped over 3 000 missiles, and it has played a major role in reducing tensions in our part of the world. I also call on the parties to return to the agreement. We are now faced with a choice between taking part in the arms race or actually trying to maintain that war does not solve the world's problems and that we must do everything in our power to avoid them arising. In 2017, the UN Convention on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons was adopted in response to the non-proliferation treaty of nuclear weapons states. It is time for the Member States to sign and ratify it. Someone has to go first. We must think about future generations.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur In the early 1980s, Russia built missiles, and the West forced them to eliminate all medium-range missiles with its own missiles. Today, Russia is again building missiles, and we are not in negotiations, but the Americans are terminating a treaty that the Russians are happy to terminate, because then there will be no legal obligations to which we can point out to the Russians. That is why I believe that russia's breach of contract is wrong, but so is the early dismissal by the United States of America, which only plays into the hands of the Russians. We know that today, through China and others, we are in a different situation, that dualism is not there as it was in 1980. But I believe that forcing a treaty to exist and conducting negotiations on the basis of which transparency, which also involve the other nuclear powers, is better than to drop a treaty, where there is no chance and where we too must be prepared to express transparency by also offering that, for example, the missile systems in Romania should be taken into account on such an issue. to find a new starting point in this way, to come here for discussions. Transparency is everything here, and Washington and Moscow should be prepared to do so.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I imagine that Mr Brok does know, Germany being a member of NATO, that the system in Deveselu is part of NATO and the German authorities have full access to all the capabilities there. This is why I will invite all of you to be cautious. Now, Mr President, Mr Minister, we are now living in a new nuclear era, characterised by the development of new generations of nuclear missiles and launchers. Well, the hypersonic capabilities are just one part of the new realities. What is there to do then? In less than six months that will lead to the USA’s full withdrawal from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty (INF), following the continued Russian violations of it, a constructive dialogue is still possible and urgently needed. As Europe was the main beneficiary and the remains the only target of all INF systems, Europe should push and should work with its allies, the US being the most important one, to guarantee the return to the negotiations of the two signatories: the United States and Russia. Nevertheless, all efforts must also be made to preserve the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) agreement, which will soon experience quite the same situation as INF and to guarantee that the new developments, new update agreements should provide the necessary monitoring systems.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The termination of the INF Treaty by the US and Russia is a serious mistake. But the arid, uncommitted sentences with which Mr Ciamba demonstrated the EU's security-policy eunuchentism here for four minutes – just 29 in front of just 29 MEPs – is also a serious mistake. Mr Ciamba did not speak as if it were a question of existence, but as if it were a bureaucratic side issue. And he obviously is not interested in what this Parliament is discussing. Mr Ciamba, could you try to listen! Mr Ciamba, could you listen! This fits well together – the uncommitment and the arrogance. We do not want an arms race. Yes, we don't want rain either. But what do you do? You did not say in a word what initiatives should be taken. Brok has made proposals on this. Make some! We must also take into account the fact that China is now playing a role in this debate. You don't even mention that.  We Greens are against it. Strongly opposed to the fact that the weapons that were banned by INF, which Russia is now putting into position, will also be stationed on our side. We are fighting against this kind of retrofitting. But all this is of no use to us if we do not act together at European level to prevent this escalation from happening. Wake up, please be nice!

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think that what we are debating is a very serious security threat to Europe. We now face a real threat from Russian missiles. Once again, our cities and our continent are in focus and one could ask why that is. We are a long way from the time when President Obama went to Europe and talked about a world free of nuclear weapons. Now we have Trump in the White House withdrawing from the INF Treaty and also, in a way, undermining multilateralism.  In this serious situation we have to stand up as Europeans, believing in the rule of law and in treaties rather than in the law of force that we have been seeing on many sides around the world – Putin, as well as in the White House. So we have to stand up for multilateralism and we still have to fight for a world where we do not have proliferation and where we can once again see a future without nuclear arms and nuclear weapons.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, our aim was, and continues to be, to eliminate an entire class of nuclear arms. Indeed, I support the zero-option for all nuclear arms. As I’ve said before, my dream is to see the day when nuclear weapons will be banished from the face of the earth, who said that? Ronald Reagan. And like my teacher and Security Studies Professor Harald Müller, I hope he will not be embarrassed, I would like to underline in today’s context that a European response is needed to the possible new arms race, in a new threatening world which doesn’t remember the balance carefully developed in the Cold War. I think European defence forces should also perhaps even reply with a nuclear component. Forgive me my radicalism here because Putin’s Russia doesn’t believe in deterrents, and thinks that the new arms race is the answer. We should show that we are ready for that and in that case, Bodil, we will have total peace. If we reply with force Putin will understand us, if not we’re finished. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, Mr Tarand, you said the European Union should have to reply with force to Mr Putin’s Russia. What kind of force do you have in mind? On what forces are the European Union’s security and defence now based?

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I will only take 20 seconds. I have in mind that a joint European defence force – being ridiculed as a federalist project – should have a German Commander-in-Chief and an English-speaking army equipped with the most modern resources and weapons.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Russia has not respected the IMF Treaty and Mr Trump has once again decided to play putin's game. The United States and Russia thus set out in retaliatory escalation to move us again into a nuclear arms race, into an era of aggravated nuclear danger, even if it is by miscalculation. And what happens to the START Treaty, with the aim of drastically reducing the number of nuclear weapons of the United States and Russia, which expires in 2021? What happens in the face of technological advances that allow supersonic nuclear? How does China react? What do you do when Europe is at the geographical centre of the threat? We cannot let Europe be a chessboard between the United States and Russia again. We can't be afraid and accept what's unacceptable. I am for a zero policy on nuclear, letting them turn, therefore, to multiplyamerican nuclear missiles on our soil. This is the time for the Defence Europe, in fact, to assume itself politically and militarily with strategic autonomy. It is the only way to defend our interests, to speak loudly and to prevent the planet from slipming into catastrophe.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I think the situation is serious because the end of the NIF Treaty (intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty) is reviving the nuclear arms race, not only between Russia and the United States, but also for all the middle powers, such as Iran and Saudi Arabia. This is really a direct threat to Europe. The end of the FNI treaty is the obsolescence of a treaty that has allowed, under pressure from environmental and pacifist activists, to massively reduce the number of nuclear missiles stationed in Europe. The end of the NIF Treaty threatens the entire architecture of non-proliferation treaties, including the NPT (Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty), signed in 1968, which is the only universal treaty we have today. If European countries refuse to take in American weapons on their territory for longer, they will block President Trump's ambitions. We also need to review the concept of intermediate weapons, between 500 and 5,000 km, which is no longer adapted to the realities of the 21st century, with nearly a dozen nuclear powers and new vectors. So the European Union must quickly propose a mediation process between the United States and Russia. We must also propose a nuclear-free zone in Europe, the so-called ZEAN (nuclear-weapon-free zones), as there are six recognized in the world. All the countries of the European Union must also sign the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons. That is a strong signal to stop the escalation of nuclear weapons.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I grew up as a child in the peace movement in East Germany and i have seen very well what it means to experience this danger of war within Europe here. The INF Treaty has made Europe safe for thirty years in the context of land-based medium-range nuclear weapons. That is why we Europeans in particular are most interested in setting a new set-up here, by the United States and Russia, both of which must sit down at the same table.  To this end, Russia must also disarm the cruise missile developed in recent years and finally establish transparency. It is not time to discuss the development and re-deployment of missiles. Medium-range missiles have nothing to do with Europe. That is what we must focus on. We must ensure that we speak with one voice. This is very important so that we can address Russia and America together here.  Europe must show transparency, including with regard to the military bases and the situation in Poland and Romania. Here we must help to ensure that we can re-negotiate, so that the New START Treaty does not expire in 2021, but that we continue to focus on disarmament.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I think it is very painful for all of us to realise that we are moving away from a nuclear-weapon-free world with every passing day. With the repeal of the INF Treaty, we are on the verge of an arms race that threatens to turn the current international order completely on its head. And if we, as the European Union, do not manage to hold together now, we will become the playing field between America and Russia and a new nuclear battlefield in the world. I therefore call on the Council to take initiatives and to reach a common position. It must not be the case that our response is an upgrade in Europe. Our response must be to invite to a new conference on disarmament, to save and develop the existing treaties and to counterbalance the cancellation of international treaties with transparency and openness.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the INF Treaty was indeed a success, because it led to disarmament on the Old Continent. This, of course, was at a different stage. Now we have a growing competition between the United States and Russia. It is obvious that the United States has stated that it wants to denounce the INF agreement and are trying to find various steps to do so and are, of course, also taking advantage of Russia's own policy. But the one who is paying for it is the European Union and so far I have not heard any serious initiatives on the part of the Council on this issue. What's he supposed to do? How will he face the challenges? Because, in the end, the big problem will be the European Union itself. Initiatives are therefore needed on this issue, because it seems that we are going to a more general rupture and competition around equipment between the United States and Russia.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, on 20 October President Trump announced the withdrawal of the United States from the INF Treaty, signed in 1987 between Reagan and Gorbachev, and ensured that the two superpowers would not use nuclear weapons. But now things have changed. With the withdrawal of the United States, which, it should be noted, also released Russia from the corresponding obligation, a new strategic reality is created in Europe and the foundations are laid for strategic competition which will inevitably also involve nuclear weapons. In my view, the real reason why the United States withdrew from the INF Treaty is as follows: Russia has developed missile systems in Syria and on its border with Ukraine that prohibit the infiltration of AMERICAN aircraft and ships into the areas protected by those systems. In order for the United States to react, it must attack these systems from a long distance. So they have to install long-range missiles on land, similar to the Tomahawk missiles launched from submarines and ships that have a range of 1,300 to 2,500 kilometers. The Russians, for their part, have developed a terrestrial variant of the Kalibr system, which has similar range. So, as you have said, you realize that the INF Treaty is now permanently and irrevocably in the past.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Questioning security is not done through words, but is done through facts, hard facts. But vice versa. In words, we will not provide security, but precisely an adequate response through facts, through a minimum of treaties, through certain agreements. The INF agreement ceases to apply, but ceases to apply primarily because one of the parties , in short, did not comply with it. The other side, the United States, is trying to adapt to a particular situation by denouncing this agreement. I want to make it clear that, in order to restore security, especially the security that we are discussing in Europe, hard facts, agreements, certain treaties are needed, but also, unfortunately, stronger facts in some cases, so that the other side – in this case Russia – simply compels these treaties. And that's what I'm calling for.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, President Trump’s macho sabre-rattling and nationalistic calls of ‘America first’ have set the tone for dangerous political brinkmanship that puts all our lives at risk. In an era when we should be working more closely together for a sustainable peaceful world, Trump goes against the grain by abandoning partnership in favour of a regressive unilateral approach. By pulling out of the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty, Trump has not only put the possibility of nuclear confrontation in Europe back on the table, he has also hinted at a wider threat, that of world-scale military confrontation between the US and China. France, Germany and the EU are defending the INF Treaty, whilst calling for greater Russian transparency. Britain’s response, however, has been at best ambiguous, with Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson quick to support Trump, saying Russia has made a mockery of the INF Treaty and must get its house in order. Well, Trump, Putin, Williamson: three men high on testosterone playing dangerous games. Women campaigners won the battle against cruise missiles in the 1980s and women will once again oppose men’s war-mongering. We are organising.

name: President. –
text: Ms Ward, you have a blue-card question from Mr Bütikofer, do you accept it?

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Sorry, which group is this gentleman from? I’m happy to take a question from a Green. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – You will like my question, my question is: was it President Trump who broke the INF or President Putin?

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – (inaudible) ... colleague is that it is men playing games with the lives of people around the world. War is a man’s game. Most of the speakers in this debate have been men, and if you look at who is in power on the Foreign Affairs Committee, who is doing all the warmongering? It is men, and my point is that women’s voices need to be heard at this level and it is women who make the peace and it is women who dismantled and got rid of the cruise missiles, the US missiles, they were on our land in the UK. I refuse for us to be another US state.

name: George Ciamba
text: (President-in-Office of the Council) on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. –  Mr President, thank you for this important exchange. I think the importance of the preservation of the INF Treaty for European and global security, as well as our common preoccupation with increased stress to our security, has been very well highlighted.
