I will not respond to the last point that was raised. I am here representing the High Representative, so I think it makes no sense if you take into account whom I represent here. I would also like to refer to the fact that I think nobody here spoke as much as they should have about the allegation that the Russian Federation has begun producing and deploying new missiles, which could be aimed at Member States and which are not in compliance with Russia’s Treaty obligation. This deserved to be treated more seriously and needs to be resolved. This should happen through a responsible dialogue, including at the highest levels. The stakes are simply too high. Now we come to the allegations concerning the NATO capabilities in Romania or Poland. We made it very public and it was very transparent –which is not the case for any of the Russian missiles – that we know what we have in these places and we made it very clear that this is not a violation or a prohibition of the possession of missiles, if there really is a defensive factor. And I think it is not fair to say that the European Union is not doing enough to save the INF Treaty. The EU has a long record of speaking in support of INF Treaty preservation and implementation – both bilaterally in our contacts with the State parties and very publicly in multiple international fora like the United Nations General Assembly, the Conference of Disarmament in Geneva, the Review Conferences of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and on multiple other occasions. The most recent example was the agreed EU statement delivered on 18 October 2018 at the First Committee (Disarmament Intelligence and Security) of the UN General Assembly in New York, which included the following passage: ‘We call on the Russian Federation to address serious concerns regarding its compliance with the INF Treaty in a substantial and transparent way. We ask the United States and the Russian Federation to remain engaged in active dialogue to preserve the INF Treaty and ensure its full and verifiable implementation, which is crucial for Europe and other regions’ security.’ So this is what I wanted to say and I think I will thank you on behalf of the High Representative for being part of the discussion today.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure, six motions for resolutions.  The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Thursday 14 February 2019.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Franck Proust, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the establishment of a framework for the control of foreign direct investment in the European Union (COM(2017)0487 - C8-0309/2017 - 2017/0224(COD)) (A8-0198/2018).

name: Franck Proust
text: Rapporteur. "Mr President, Commissioner, to know where we are going, we need to know where we are coming from, and I think I can say on behalf of all that we are coming back from afar. When three member countries proposed the creation of a European investment filtering mechanism, the reception was frosty. When the EPP proposed a DOCUMENT from the Eu to the European Parliament on this mechanism, the reception was reserved. When President Juncker presented the proposed regulation here in September 2017, there was a majority of skepticism.  I would also like to congratulate here on the effectiveness of the services of the European Commission, which reacted very quickly with a regulation, from the very beginning skilful, particularly on the question of competences. I believe that we can all be congratulated for having taken into account both the context, the need and above all the interests of each one, thanks to the excellent joint work of the three institutions: an Austrian Presidency of the Council aware of political issues, a Commission listening to the proposals and a pragmatic European Parliament. I would also like to thank my colleagues and co-staff, with whom the work of reflection has been a strength. It was this trio that did it. So, as you said, Commissioner, this mechanism is a first. The first European mechanism will be a major complement to national filtering mechanisms. And to use the famous title of another Proust's novel, we were "in search of lost time". Our main partners already have a mechanism: the United States, together with CFIUS, has had expertise since 1975. This mechanism is therefore a symbol of Europeans' awareness that the world around us is not filled only with investors with benevolent objectives. You will agree that this vision was very naïve. From now on, Member States will no longer be able to turn a blind eye to foreign and strange investments in Europe and say 'we did not know'. We did not know that a whole European value chain was acquired by a single state or foreign company, we did not know that a dual-use technology, civil and military, was acquired by a foreign army, we did not know that the ultimate investor, who was hiding behind a conventional investor, was aiming to sabotage a European programme. Not knowing is a mistake, at a time when evidence of these fears is sometimes enshrined in the political planning of the economies of certain foreign powers. Of course, we remain open to foreign investment because we need it. Europe is a land of innovation and will remain competitive, also thanks to the free movement of capital. But freedom does not mean anarchy. Freedom does not mean impunity. Filtering does not mean banning. Filtering means retaining the best and the shackles of this filter, in this regulation, are up to the current stakes, and this thanks, too, to the European Parliament, which has played its part in strengthening the Commission's proposal, making this mechanism something other than a timid try. We have strengthened the collection and exchange of information, we have strengthened the anti-circumvention of national mechanisms, we have strengthened intra-European and also international cooperation. Above all, we have marked a step in replacing the law of silence with the law of dialogue. Finally, you know that I cannot fail to talk about the third scenario, this worst-case scenario for which I have fought, to the end, and which already allows us to anticipate the concerns of at least one third of the Member States about foreign investment. The Commission, at the heart of this scheme, will then have to give an opinion. This instrument is an opportunity that Member States must seize for public order and the safety of Europeans, because we are in the single market, but not just in a market. Europe, with this instrument, will be better able to protect itself from the butterfly effect of an investment, not to mention the investment race between the United States and China, which should not make Europe a supermarket. It must remain a showcase. So yes, we're coming back from afar. In record time for a new regulation, we have reached this agreement and now we can say that we know where we are going, towards a Europe that affirms and defends its offensive and defensive interests.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When you talked three years ago about the need to learn something from the US in investment screening, you were usually met with complete incomprehension. In the three years we have learned a great deal. Like Mr Proust, I would like to thank all the institutions involved in this successful exercise, particularly the Commission. This was a very pleasing cooperation. Also with the Austrian Presidency and not least with you, Mr Proust, as rapporteur. You have managed this wonderfully. Investment screening was viewed with scepticism by many Member States when it came to the table. We can see today that there has been a change of opinion. A number of Member States, which at the beginning did not want to touch this with tweezers, have come to the conclusion that they must also actively pursue this. It is important to note that we do not want to pursue protectionism, but we are not blue-eyed either. It is not an industrial policy instrument, but an instrument for defending security and public order.  We have indeed worked quickly and I am grateful for this cooperation. We will certainly have to take further steps in this area. But it shows that this Union is capable of acting under new challenges and can break new ground.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Proust for the work you’ve done here –tireless, energetic and also very inclusive. Also Mr Bütikofer for the work you have done and the very constructive approach that you and your colleagues had in the trilogues that we’ve been doing jointly on this. As you know, the Commission made it a priority to finalise legislation on the Foreign Direct Investments (FDI) screening before the end of this term. President Juncker announced it here, sitting here, in his State of the European Union in September 2017, when he announced that he wanted to move on to propose a proposal on investment screening. And with your support we are about to deliver just that for our citizens, that their security and public order interest will be protected. By concluding this file we send a very strong message to our partners. We are open in the European Union to foreign investment. That is, and has been and will be fundamental to growth, jobs etc. But a condition for being open is to be able to trust that foreign investors will not threaten our security and our strategic interests. Increasingly, in an interconnected and interdependent world, we share opportunities but also threats, and this becomes even more important in the internal market where a foreign investment in one Member State might have an impact in another, or the whole Union. In September when we launched the proposal, this was, as was said by the two rapporteurs, a new policy area. Several Member States and some of our international partners, actually, most of them, were already experienced in this type of legislation, screening foreign direct investment. But the majority of our Member States did not have their own legislation or mechanism in place. This proposal has triggered a constructive debate at European and national level, and what we see is that several Member States are now in the course of reforming or even introducing their own screening mechanisms. This regulation will help set a common framework, increase cooperation and information sharing and building on efficient practices. Thanks to the new regulation, Member States and the Commission will have a much better overview of foreign investment in the EU. Moreover, for the first time, they would have the possibility to collectively assess potential risks to their security and public order. I welcome Parliament’s and the Member States’ understanding of the need for a key role for the Commission here as well in this mechanism, when security and public order in several Member States could be at risk or with projects of the Union’s interest, like Galileo or Horizon 2020, fundamental for our future. In its initial position and in the course of the negotiations, Parliament has made it clear that it was supporting this proposal and it has sought further improvement, and they have largely passed into the final compromise. The cooperation mechanism has been reinforced in many aspects. For instance, with the possibility for a Member State to proactively seek opinions or comments, the strengthened provisions on anti-circumvention or an increased scrutiny by the Commission when a third of Member States issue concerns on a specific foreign investment. Furthermore, you have proposed reporting with the yearly public report on the implementation of the regulation. International cooperation with like-minded third countries is also encouraged, and I would like to thank you for these improvements. Tomorrow’s vote will be an important milestone. As we will be shifting towards implementation, we will use the transition phase to ensure that Member States and the Commission can swiftly put in place the necessary arrangements for this new mechanism. I think we can all salute this moment and hope for a very strong vote tomorrow because we know that this is of concern to our Member States, to our companies, to our citizens, and we will have delivered by then.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her remarks. The interest in this foreign direct investment (FDI) screenings framework arose, of course, from concerns about external investors buying technologies in our European countries which could be used for their own strategic objectives, while they themselves maintain barriers for investments from European countries. We’re pleased that the draft regulation agreed in trilogue recognises that it is the sole responsibility of Member States to safeguard their national security. It’s important, therefore, that individual Member States retain responsibility for setting up screening mechanisms for FDI on grounds of security and to cover critical infrastructure and sensitive technologies. These now specifically include, among other categories, aerospace and defence facilities and nano and bio technologies. There is also a need to consider whether a foreign investor is directly or indirectly controlled by government or its state bodies or armed forces, including through the ownership structure. So this is a difficult and complex area and I might just – somewhat mischievously and separately – remark that while today we’re considering only FDI into the Union, some of the considerations should also perhaps apply to activities within the Union, particularly investment in assets in one Member State by state-controlled assets in another. But that’s another matter.

name: Roberts Zīle
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, dear Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. I am very pleased that the European Union ceased to be naïve and to think that all investments from third countries only generate profits for her owners and jobs in the European Union. And it's good that this screening system is being built.  I am also pleased that Mr Prosta took the views of these many committees and did not lose what was created in the committees. And also on behalf of the ECON Committee, I can say that we were pleased that we incorporated the exclusive economic zone of the Member States, which is also territorial waters, as a place of investment in the European Union.  And, more importantly, in critical infrastructure investments from third countries, we counted the media, because the media is one of the most important elements of a democratic society, and if the media is repeatedly trading through some other Member States of the European Union from third countries... in other Member States. And I am very pleased, and I very much hope that the Member States will also cooperate on such cross-border parts that change the content of third countries' investments. Since I very much hope that this is the first step– very successful. Let us not be naïve! We have in third countries not only technology theft, but also the desires of public opinion influencing.

name: Christofer Fjellner
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I shall begin by thanking Mr Proust, who has led the work on that honour. But before we discuss investment review, I think we need to start at the right end, by establishing some important truths. The first is that investment, including foreign ones, is good. They create jobs and growth, and we need more of that in Europe – jobs, growth and investment. This was clearly visible not least after the euro and financial crisis. The second, the major problem we have in Europe today, is unfortunately still investment protectionism, that countries want to protect their crown jewels from international or foreign ownership. Sometimes French who want to protect themselves from Italian, sometimes Italian from French, sometimes Dutch people who do not want to sell Akzo Nobel to Americans. But it is not just investment protectionism that is the problem, and it is not just too few investments that are the problem. After all, we have too many trading partners making investments other than commercial interests. Not all of our trading partners have good intentions, and then we must have the tools to meet them. Sometimes it's about security policy. Sometimes it is a question of stealing technology or sabotaging technological development in Europe. Then we have to have a full toolbox to meet it. This initiative should be followed up by wider initiatives, for example in the borderland between trade and security policy to protect our cybersecurity. What we see today with Huawei and ZTE worries me – that I cannot call home from Brussels to Sweden without doing it over Chinese switches. This should be a lesson for Sweden too, because Sweden belongs to one of the few countries in Europe that does not have this kind of investment write. Then I think that instead of standing in the corner and thinking that we know best, Sweden should look at our neighbours in Europe and learn from their examples.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in the case of investments such as the sale of the German robot maker Kuka to a Chinese group, or the possible acquisition of Huawei in Europe, there is rightly fear for national security, the leakage of knowledge or cold profit, as was the case with the division of the Dutch chemical group AkzoNobel under pressure from activist shareholders. However, Europe should not put a stop to foreign investment, because many of these investments also contribute positively to employment, to innovation and thus to our economic growth. But we have to be realistic. The first steps we are taking here today are good, but in the end we must move towards a mechanism whereby the European Union makes a fist against uninvited guests. This is the only way to protect knowledge, safety and workers.

name: Joachim Starbatty
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The ECR would also like to thank Mr Proust, not only for the constructive atmosphere, but also for the pleasant atmosphere you have created. Protection against foreign takeovers and investments on grounds of security and public order is legitimate. It also makes sense to exchange information between EU countries. However, the use of this instrument must remain strictly limited, as Mr Fjellner pointed out; it must not deter the vast majority of legitimate interests. Investment and legal certainty must not be called into question. The ECR attaches great importance to the fact that this instrument is not introduced or applied for protectionist reasons, because the EU benefits from investments from outside the EU like no other location. This danger was present in the original report. The politicization of screening under the influence of third parties would have brought aspects beyond security and public order to the fore. This would have encouraged protectionism. That is why the ECR was the only group to initially vote against Parliament's report. In the trilogue agreement, crucial aspects have been changed for us – for the better. Parliament's influence on the individual decision has not been realised. The final decision in each investment case rests with the Member States, in other words the principle of subsidiarity. Member States that do not have a screening mechanism will not be forced to introduce it. The agreement in the trialogue creates legal certainty and, from the ECR's point of view, meets the necessary requirements, and that is why we will vote in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I agree that this is an important piece of legislation, which addresses some of the concerns currently related to investments coming to sensitive sectors in Europe. These concerns exist, various Member States face them and I am convinced that we can now bring a new instrument to our toolbox in this area. For instance, if we had this regulation in place today, we could have come up with a more coordinated approach to some of the Chinese companies, Huawei for instance. Personally, I value in this legislation the exchange of information between respective stakeholders in the Member States. Some of the potentially problematic investments could come to several countries, and it would be beneficial to share information on them. It remains on a voluntary basis to set up a screening mechanism at a national level, but there is no doubt that there are good reasons to control investments coming to very sensitive areas such as critical infrastructure, defence and the security industry, but also the media or – very topical now – telecommunications and new digital technologies, such as artificial intelligence. The EU needs to remain open to foreign investment. It has always been a source of our economic growth. Through the process of negotiating this regulation, I emphasise that this is by no means a protectionist tool, but a guarantee for the EU to face those investments where economic goals are not a primary consideration, a sort of warning in the same way that we need trade, defence or anti-dumping legislation. They are triggered only when a threat is identified. I believe this regulation will prove useful and functional once applied.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that the aim of the mechanism we are going to vote on tomorrow is, in theory, to protect strategic sectors and infrastructures. And we think it makes sense, that you can have a screening mechanism.  What's the point, though? That in the presence of neoliberal extremism, which very often strongly obliges or induces privatisation – and certainly austerity policies have acted in this direction – with a policy that favours competition, even prohibiting the possibility of State aid, if not publicising and nationalising strategic sectors, investment screening can be reduced to an instrument for defining hierarchies between Member States of the European Union. It could therefore become, as a tool for Member States to make their businesses stronger, an instrument for fuelling a trade war. From a trade defence instrument to an instrument of trade war that would give priority to the strongest Member States of the European Union.

name: Christelle Lechevalier
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, this framework for the filtering of foreign investment aims to protect us from non-European, hostile investors who want to take ownership of our strategic companies and their technology. At a time when the Chinese are buying back key infrastructures and companies with unique know-how in our countries, in order to recover the expertise of course, it is time to say stop to laissez-faire. Awareness is needed and the National Gathering delegation will approve this text, which is a late first step towards measures to protect our economy and our strategic assets. It should be remembered, however, that for decades the European Union has favoured outrageous free trade and the most unbridled liberalism. If today the whole of Europe is potentially threatened by extra-European investments in states without filtering mechanisms, it is above all because of the common market that you have set up, without reservation. Just this afternoon, most Members applauded one of the new free trade treaties that organise the unfair competition of our companies with those from all over the world. For 40 years, the Commission, the majority of Members and our governments have been complicit in the policies that have led to our deindustrialization. They have also allowed many strategic companies to be acquired by foreign interests. The arsonists you are now want to put in place protections to limit, as best they can, the damage caused by their own policies. With three months to go until the elections, let us hope that this mechanism is not just a communication to our citizens and that it will allow for real change. The Europe of tomorrow will have to protect the interests of its Member States. This intelligent protectionism has always been one of our priorities, let us hope that it becomes yours as well.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Union's control over investments by third states on its territory is part of a real war; Which, of course, turns into a warm war. The Union defends itself against the economic penetration of third parties: Russia, China and others. Against Britain, as a Trojan horse of foreign investment after Brexit. Control is not compulsory, only because of internal contradictions within the Union. But it acts as blackmail in the interests of its monopolies. The scope of controllable investments and the concept of security defended by the audit change according to its respective interests in high-tech infrastructure investments, defence and media and propaganda control. Investment in defence by NATO countries is excluded, of course. Workers need to know this: the famous freedom of capital and movement goes for a walk. There is protectionism if the interests of monopolies are to be protected. But it is activated permanently and always against the workers and the peoples, who must overthrow it against the wars of capitalists and satisfy their own needs.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very grateful that tomorrow we will probably vote in favour of this proposal by a large majority. I am particularly grateful because we have discussed this issue for a long time in many Member States, including here in Parliament. Perhaps it was one of the reasons why movement finally came in, that Frank Proust and some colleagues from our group used the European Parliament's indirect right of initiative and thereby also signalled that there is support here in Parliament. What is important to me is that, from my point of view, we will take a good step tomorrow, but please only take a first step. I think it is good that, at the moment, the Member States have to take the decisions. But let me be quite frank: when I look at how dominant many foreign governments are in the Member States, how small some Member States are in the global context, and how small all our Member States are in the global context, I would like to see that we will find majorities in a next step, perhaps in the next parliamentary term. to take the next step, to give the European Commission more power.  And I would like us to reconsider the scope of application. When I see just how much money we are investing in the next European research framework programme, I hope that, if in doubt, as you have indicated, Commissioner, we will also have the opportunity to protect our research results from foreign acquisitions if necessary.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, fortunately common sense has prevailed. The final version of the new Regulation on the control of foreign investment, which resulted from the trilogue between the European institutions, is a balanced solution, allows to respond to concerns that are legitimate when particularly important values are in danger, but it does so without harming the capacity to attract external investment. And, it should be remembered, foreign investment is important to the European economy and is even more important for European countries that lack the equity to invest. I therefore welcome the two fundamental rules that have been enshrined: the fact that the new procedure for exchanging information and analysing investments is exceptional and reserved for security and public order, and the fact that the final decision on investments belongs to the sovereign states. They decide the investments on their own territory. We can thus move forward in protecting our common interests without undermining our ability to attract foreign investment.

name: Ralph Packet (ECR).
text: Mr President, one of the great strengths of our European economies is the openness with which we welcome investment from all over the world. But anyone who thinks that foreign investment only comes with good intentions is wandering. We are seeing more and more aggressive acquisitions or investments by companies that, for example, seem to be under Chinese state control. The European Union must not pursue a naive open borders policy for these investments. We must maintain a balance between openness and protection of our strategic interests. And that must be done without putting pressure on the good economic ties between countries. We remain available for free trade, without opening the door to protectionism. That is why I support a European framework in which the European Union takes a coordinating role. Member States thus retain their independence to develop their own mechanisms. This is an area in which the European Union can create added value through its scale without replacing the individual Member States.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the analysis and control of foreign direct investment may be necessary on certain occasions and in specific and of particular sectors of particular importance. But the reasons set out in this report do not seem to us to be eer the right ones or the ones going in the right direction. Dangerous foreign investment is one that can close factories or so affect a sector that jobs are harmed. Dangerous foreign investment is one that promotes polluting and harmful practices against the environment and, of course, does not respect social responsibility. When the European Union protects, unfortunately it does not do so with workers in mind. However, this instrument focuses on security and defense as the only argument for declaring how relevant a share purchase or acquisition is. Selective protectionism to prevent investment from non-eu-friendly countries is not the way to protect those who truly need it, who are no other than workers.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. There is no question that, within the European Union, we must protect ourselves against investments that do not serve purely economic interests, but other interests, as we have seen, particularly in the recent past, by China, but also by other countries. In this respect, the proposal that comes from the Commission is very welcome. I must say, however, that Parliament did not have a particularly happy hand in trying to improve this proposal. I would have very much welcomed us taking on board what has come from the Commission without improving or making it worse here in Parliament. Because in trying to intervene there, we have taken on board some protectionist elements. I believe that in some places we are overshooting the mark. When I hear today what is also being said by the CDU about the fact that we are already thinking about extending this, possibly shifting competences from the nation states to the Union level, then that makes me think a little what awaits us in the coming years. After all, it is quite clear that if we take this from the national level, and therefore from the level where strategic interests are actually concerned, to the European level, we will simply shift the problem. Because, of course, there are also different interests between the European states. And if you say that small countries may not be able to protect themselves against it on their own, then that is true. But it is also clear that small countries may not be able to protect themselves against the interests of large countries within the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Pretzell may assure you that the concern you have just expressed is unnecessary, because the direction proposed by Daniel Caspari will not find a majority in Parliament. It is not and will not be a protectionist instrument.

name: President.
text: – It was a statement, but you could answer.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. So I'm not quite sure if that should reassure me when that comes from you. But I very much hope that you are right.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Well, I see that the big brother could not sleep one night, that something else is eerily to him and now the big brother will be watching foreign investment. It will monitor foreign investment in different countries. He meddled in things that had somehow happened without him. Well, someone malicious might think that maybe the European Commission has envies the possibility of taking bribes to member states, to the governments of the Member States. Of course, I am not such a malicious suspicious person, but why give it. Even in fever, I would not have thought of such bad things about the Commission, but why give an excuse to the bad people to think about such things before the elections. So I think the Commissioner – well, because someone who is also suspicious might think that commissioners can influence smaller Member States in this way, discourage investment, pay out investments from some countries, so as to give such proposals not to reject investors to invest instead of in that country, but in another country. So I think it's as protectionist as possible, and you've recently lamented Trump's policies, and now you want to do stories like this here at home. The criteria for this justification are vague, this meddling is unclear and the justification is completely non-obvious.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank my colleague, Franck Proust, for his work on this very important issue. This first European FDI filtering mechanism marks a new stage and is part of the continuity of the modernization of trade defence instruments and the denial of China's market economy status. The world is changing and it is time for the European Union to adapt to the realities of today's economic challenges. We can no longer stand still in the face of the Chinese, American, and GAFAM giants who impose their law, without a state of mind. As such, our competition rules are outdated and the decision to ban the Alstom-Siemens merger is a serious mistake. We must absolutely allow the creation of European champions, it is urgent that Europe now live with its time.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the mechanism for filtering and examining foreign investment in the European Union is a necessity. Who wants to believe otherwise... This is not about protectionism, it is, after all, about safety, and I do not think it is, as my colleague said before, a way of taking money from the Commission. I am usually critical of the Commission, but now we all have to think that if we do not have a harmonised system, in all Member States, of filtering, of verifying foreign investment, not only is unfair competition being created, that SMEs in the European Union are being destroyed, but we end up with no security, and, in the end, today we debated another report , on the sustainability of the European Union.  I think we all want to have a European Union. We must have a safe single market, but also safety. That is why I very much appreciate this regulation and I think it is up to us to apply it correctly, and it is very good that the possibility of verification by the Commission is provided for in the regulation and to report to Parliament how this regulation applies. I think that here we need to see, rather, the problem, how harmonised application and how to filter. It is a statement that I like very much: we must also take into account the specificity of that country.

name: Innocenzo Leontini (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join in the appreciation for the work done by Mr Proust. I fully support this European Commission initiative to establish legislation for the monitoring of foreign direct investment in the European Union. The aim is to fill a gap and create the legal conditions for the countries of the European Union to provide themselves with conditions for the entry of foreign direct investment, especially on the basis of considerations relating to national security or public order.  This monitoring action, in line with what is already happening today in states such as the USA, Canada or China, will particularly cover certain strategic sectors such as infrastructure or major advanced technologies. In addition, the regulatory provisions may also cover investments by state-owned companies or in close contact with foreign governments.  I am convinced that we must protect Europe's independence by promoting its primacy in key sectors for industrial and technological development. That is why we need to adopt texts such as this.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ‘if you can’t beat them buy them’. As the world’s main destination for foreign direct investment, the EU cannot allow this proverb to underpin global trade and investment. To harness globalisation we need to safeguard the critical infrastructure and long-term strategic interests that directly support jobs and people in Europe – and protection is not protectionism, as was insinuated by Mr Pretzell. In a hyper-connected single market, this regulation will enable patterns to be highlighted that might escape individual Member States, like my small Luxembourg, because foreign investors can knock on one door after another. Coming from a small Member State, without formal FDI screening, I hope that in the future every Member State, including mine, will assume this responsibility and perform minimum screening. Openness can never be a goal in itself, in a Europe that protects. To conclude, I want to thank Franck Proust for his excellent work: he has done a tremendous job. (Applause)

name: Aleksander Gabelic (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and everyone involved in this important work. The EU's openness to foreign direct investment is not only about money and job creation, but also about the technology and knowledge that investors bring. Although we have a positive starting point, we must realise that the world has changed. Not all investors act on purely commercial grounds. Therefore, we should not be stupid or naïve – especially when it comes to strategically and security-critical sectors in which certain well-known state-owned companies from a number of countries act and which do not play on the same terms. That is why it is very good that the EU is addressing this issue and getting a clear framework. I think it is very welcome that the Member States have recognised the need to deal with the problem and that we are working together better now. A single EU approach can make it easier to deal with the challenges of foreign direct investment in the EU, which is very important and positive in these times we now live in.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we live in dangerous times and we need to be fully aware of foreign investments coming into strategic sectors in the European Union. It’s no longer about the growth of particular Member States but more about the security of the European Union. We cannot pretend that ownership does not matter and that foreign investment is always good. There are external dangers that we need to counteract better, and a risk with foreign investment in strategic sectors that we need to address because this can threaten or undermine national, European or even global security or public order. Foreign investment is investment – which is good because it leads to economic stability, activity and jobs. Moreover, foreign investment promotes the international exchange of capital, ideas, business strategies and technologies – which is good for the economy and for people. That’s why I welcome the appropriate balance between open investments and screening which was struck in the Mr Proust’s report.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur for a good job. Openness to foreign investment remains a key principle for the EU and a major source of its growth. We should nevertheless be cautious about investments that could endanger our critical infrastructure, technological development or even security. The experience from many Member States shows that in many cases we are facing serious problems with third countriesʼ state-owned enterprises taking over European technological companies only for the key strategic reasons. The EU and Member States should be sensitive to such investments, especially in cases where our investors do not enjoy the same rights to invest in the FDIʼs country of origin. Moreover, we should also be more sensitive to such investments in the countries in the EU accession process, as strategic infrastructure might eventually be incorporated into the EU when it was in the hands of third countries, often the ones which are problematic.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will admit that, as the Commission seeks new competences, I am not very enthusiastic, and I always prefer that those competences which the Commission has so far exercised as best as possible, but only as a last resort. Here we have a situation where, on the one hand, it is proposed that Member States should be able to maintain, amend or adopt new – I stress new – mechanisms for monitoring foreign direct investment. Secondly, it is proposed to lay down minimum procedural requirements. Fortunately minimal. Thirdly, it is now proposed to give the Commission, fortunately conditionally, new powers to monitor foreign direct investment. And fortunately, it is important to give opinions that are non-binding. What is safe comes at the end, i.e. it is confirmed that the Member States retain final decision-making powers. And this must be maintained and respected.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Although this document, which we are discussing today, is not about China, I will refer to China as one of the most striking examples. The EU's policy towards China has always been and is open, benevolent and consistent. Until now, the Chinese have been able to invest in EU Member States whenever they wish and wherever they wish. However, for potential European investors in China, bureaucratic obstacles are not diminishing, but are increasing. China does not respect the principle of reciprocity. The screening mechanism for foreign direct investment must therefore be validated and operational in the near future. Foreign investment in sectors such as energy, communication, transport – I mean maritime and airports, railways and media – must be checked in all countries. The European Commission and the European Parliament are united in their capacity as to the necessity of the verification mechanism. However, I cannot say this for all the Member States. Some of them, where Chinese investment is significant, are already speaking with the voice of China, clearly representing China's interests, and this is indeed dangerous.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is important to be aware of the risks that some direct strategic investments may entail. This is an issue that concerns the whole of the European Union, which is why I agree with this regulation. It is a well-known fact that some countries – and China has been appointed here – are trying to dominate key sectors in individual countries through their investments in state or semi-state enterprises, gain influence, acquire know-how of strategic importance, even, I believe, influence policy. We in the Czech Republic had such a rather unfortunate experience with the investments of CEFC, whose boss was connected to Chinese military intelligence.  Thus, investment screening is a legitimate instrument of the Member States that they can use in view of the need to ensure their own security and, of course, effective when we can use a common framework, so I thank you for it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, we have observed bilingualism and hypocrisy in its splendor. As long as the European multinational companies of the hard core bought instead of lentil plates the companies of the European South there was no problem. Now, then, that strong Chinese companies or Russian or American companies appear to buy European companies, everyone is complaining. I did not see you complaining, several of you, when the memorandum made the Greek banks de-Greek. When a German state-owned company bought the Greek Telecommunications company or when an Italian state-owned company, by order of the Memorandum, bought the Greek Railways. Or when a French company takes advantage of the largest investment, which is the Rio-Antirio bridge, and when a German company, such as Fraport, bought the fourteen regional airports instead of a lentil plate. As you can see, dear friends, capitalism avenges the capitalists themselves.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we note the European Union's concern for strategic companies. Now let's face it, you have to have a certain can! So was it not the European Union that forced Portugal, especially during the Troika, to sell all its strategic companies in the area of energy, transport and the financial sector?  We were perplexed! This proposal cannot be disconnected from the increasing penetration of Chinese capital into the European economy. It must be said that, for us, the origin of capital is not important, what is crucial is public control over these companies. And in this regard, we call on the Commission to soften and to create conditions for countries like Portugal to regain control, sovereignty over these strategic companies in the name of their development.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this was a good debate and I can see that, with a few exceptions, there is strong support for the proposal. That’s very much thanks to our good cooperation under the leadership of Mr Proust, and also with Mr Bütikofer and others, who have made huge efforts to get this done in what was quite a short time. I would like to underline the fact that this is not a protectionist measure. It is not intended to stop investment that we need for jobs, for growth etcetera, and it is not a way for the Commission to tell Member States what investments they should accept or not. But it is a very important new tool, which would help us strengthen our collective capacity to respond to challenges that have arisen because of globalisation, in particular when foreign investments threaten our strategic interest. It would be the first time that we have the means to assess those risks and address them – reflecting the fact that we are an integrated economy in which foreign investors operate freely from one Member State to another. We will be able to share information, to coordinate and to get a much better overview thanks to this proposal. We’ve had very intense exchanges over the past years on how we should calibrate this instrument: the balance between the roles of Member States and the Commission; the balance between confidentiality and security interests; and how to protect them, while still exchanging meaningful information and ensuring reporting. The outcome of the negotiations reflects, in my view, this careful balance. We are in the area of security and public order, and that places responsibility on all those involved, the Commission and the Member States, to ensure that the cooperation mechanism is trustworthy, works in practice and is efficient. We will, of course, report regularly to Parliament on how this regulation is implemented and then – maybe soon when it works – Mr Proust, we can say to our voters that ‘c’est le temps retrouvé’.

name: Franck Proust
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I think I, like you, note that the interventions of the various political groups show strong support for a high-potential mechanism. I have noted with satisfaction the support of the National Gathering, which has always supported, as it says, but without making any contribution or tabling any amendments. Worse still, its representative, Mrs Jamet, had even voted against the text in the INTA committee. And then, even though we are in the pre-election period, let us cease all these caricatures, these infox on free trade agreements which, to hear them, would aim to amplify unfair competition, whereas on the contrary, these agreements are aimed at regulating our trade relations. I also did not understand the few criticisms of the Commission, because the Commission will not decide anything; the Commission will only issue opinions, and we have insisted that this is so, that the principle of subsidiarity of States is never called into question. Only the states will decide whether or not the investment is viable on their territory.  However, I have one regret: yesterday afternoon we received Mr Conte, President of the Italian Council, who assured us of his preference for closer cooperation between Member States in many areas. This is in total contradiction to Italy's position since this government came to power. I must tell you that it is the only Member State to have rejected the agreement on this filtering instrument, I say the only one. What's the reason? I can't explain it. For the most skeptical countries have come to support this proposal, as you said, Mr Bàtikofer, we can all welcome it.  Despite this, we have moved in the right direction: monitoring the implementation of this mechanism is in the hands of the Commission, but with the watchful eye of the European Parliament. Discussions around this regulation have brought a strategic issue to the table and Hungary has become the fourteenth Member State to create its mechanism at the end of 2018. Other countries are thinking about this, of course they must be encouraged in this way to create a national filtering mechanism in each Member State, in order to strengthen the effectiveness of the European mechanism. This is what we are going to put in place in a pragmatic way so that Europe continues to be seen as an attractive continent for foreign investment, but not naïve when it comes to defending its interests. So, if we come back from afar, let's bet we'll go far.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate on this point is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 14 February 2019.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is massimiliano salini's report, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the interoperability of electronic toll systems and facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on non-payment of road charges in the Union (COM(2017)0280 - C8-0173/2017 - 2017/0128(COD)) (A8-0199/2018).

name: Massimiliano Salini
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the proposal for a directive for which I am rapporteur, which will see its procedural procedure concluded with tomorrow's vote, amends the current rules on the interoperability of road toll systems and is intended to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on non-payment of tolls within the Union.  The current legal framework of the European Union, as you know, concerning the electronic collection of tolls, has not guaranteed the achievement of these objectives, in particular because service providers face enormous difficulties in accessing the market and have to meet requirements that are normally considered excessive and unworkable. It is difficult to enforce the payment of tolls on owners of vehicles registered in different States of the Union, as there is no legal basis for the exchange of information in this area.  The proposed amendment that we have tabled and which refers to the proposal presented by the Commission immediately achieved a considerable consensus, both because the Commission's proposal is considered by us rapporteurs, here in Parliament, to be a good proposal, and because we have found a very shared position on this in the negotiations in Parliament. The result obtained is a very full text, I have to say, compared with the initial proposal, in which we find most of the provisions of interest to all the delegations concerned.  As far as the scope is concerned, the agreement reached provides that only for the exchange of information to solve the problem of non-payments should the tolls of the so-called UARs, ZTLs, low-urban emission zones, and tolls collected manually be included. This is an attempt to prosecute more infringements. However, this inclusion does not concern the part that most closely refers to the interoperability system. We have applied simplification here.  Another major subject which is very complex and which has required considerable discussion concerns the list of technologies. With regard to this list – let us remember, we have satellite systems, mobile communication systems, we have 5.5 gigahertz technology – we can say that since the beginning of the negotiations there has been a clear alignment between the Council and Parliament to bring this list back into the body of the directive. This has made it possible to establish a stable framework, a framework which, with regard to the debate on the list of technologies, is constantly subject to codecision. A clarification on this issue: we have discussed the technology of reading ANPR number plates and this technology will try to introduce it when it is more mature, in order to guarantee the collection of tolls. As I said, Article 4 on interoperability contains all the elements concerning the requirements for service providers, the obligations of the service providers themselves, the obligations for tax collectors, the issue of payments, conciliation procedures, a number of issues that were previously in the decision have now been included in the directive. Articles 5 and 6 provide for all procedures related to the legal framework on the exchange of information and Article 8 seeks to ensure adequate data protection. Here too, by acquiring the elements resulting from the opinion of the LIBE Committee, we have tried to provide the necessary guarantees.  Well, it is useful to remember that we have done a lot of work and electronic electronic easing is the first text of the mobility package that comes to an end. I believe that this is an excellent tool for the debate on the future parts of the mobility package.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the recast of the directive on electronic tolling was the first proposal of the first mobility package on which the co-legislators reached an agreement in trilogues. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Salini, and the other members of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, for their constructive approach throughout the negotiations, enabling such an agreement to be reached so smoothly and swiftly. Tolling is a precious instrument for making the ‘users and polluters pay’ principle a reality for road infrastructure. But it has to be used in a way which is efficient, which does not create barriers to the flow of traffic and which protects the data that is being collected. The text you will be asked to vote on tomorrow addresses the fundamental problems in the field of electronic tolling. Let me recall just its two main objectives. First, regarding the rights and obligations of market actors, it will clarify the grey zones which, so far, have been hampering the commercial deployment of the European electronic toll service (ETS) in certain Member States. More balanced and realistic requirements will lead to more competition on the ETS market and more efficient operations. This will mean savings for road users, savings for toll chargers and additional revenues for Member States. Life will also be made easier for road users, in particular transport companies. They should ultimately be able to pay tolls, wherever they go in Europe, with a single on-board unit. They should have to sign only one toll-service contract and should receive a single invoice at the end of the month. Second, the agreed text will introduce a mechanism to facilitate the cross-border enforcement of toll payment. Today, Member States have no effective instruments in place to identify the owners of a foreign-registered vehicle for the purpose of toll collection. It is already possible for national authorities to go after those who commit a road-safety-related traffic offence but those who evade toll payments can escape fines. We have calculated that this leads to a revenue leakage of around EUR 300 million per year. Clearly, toll evasion is one of the main obstacles to a wider deployment of barrier-free tolls in the Union. In addition, the agreed text extends the scope of application of the directive to tolling systems using automated number-plate recognition as the main technology. This is important to keep pace with the technological development on the ground, as stressed by the rapporteur. Lastly, the co-legislators have extended the scope of application of cross-border enforcement. It will apply to all types of road fees, both electronic and manual. The Commission can only support this extension. This initiative will help in the transition from traditional vignette schemes, and tolls with barriers, to modern and smart, free-flow tolling systems, the kind of systems we need in order to shape more sustainable mobility in the future. Overall, I believe that all three EU institutions can be very satisfied with the outcome of the negotiations and I’m looking forward to tonight’s debate.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I am somewhat surprised, but Mr Škripek seems to be coming later. First of all, I would like to thank Massimiliano Salini for this very technical job. I think he has brought it to a successful conclusion in an excellent way. As Mrs Bulc said, there are major financial interests on this issue, but also interests in terms of data and fairness. Because it matters whether you take tolls based on distance or on the basis of time units. At the same time, we are currently seeing a proliferation of toll systems in the Member States of the European Union. We have recently received the advice of the Attorney General of the European Court of Justice. And we have quite a bit of problems with tolinning in Wallonia, for example. My question to the Commissioner is, in fact, now that we have this technical dossier by Massimiliano Salini: what about Mrs Revault d'Allonnes-Bonnefoy's dossier? This is really about tolls, the level of tolls and the integration of the systems. Is there any progress in the Council on this? That is the most important issue for me at the moment.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: On the part of the S&D Group. Finally, the introduction of a single European electronic toll service will allow drivers to pay road charges for journeys across the EU with one single device. It ends with a picture of a dashboard stacked with toll boxes as it travels across Europe. I believe drivers will appreciate a better view from their vehicle. The agreement will also help European carriers to reduce costs. They will not have to purchase equipment for individual toll systems or register intricately in individual Member States. They also earn states that cost a lot of money in unpaid road tolls. The text will also allow to recover unpaid fees from foreign drivers.  I am glad that cooperation with the rapporteur, with the shadow rapporteurs, with the Austrian Presidency and the Commission during the negotiations took place in order to reach a constructive solution, and for that, as rapporteur for S&D, I would like to thank you.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Tolls are an important source of funding for the construction and modernisation of infrastructure. We fully support the objective of this directive, which is to standardise electronic toll systems, so that specialised providers of the European electronic toll service offer road users on-board equipment compatible with electronic toll systems in the European Union. The need for users to install multiple on-board equipment in order to be able to move freely on European roads is an important and costly obstacle that needs to be eliminated if it can – and can be. Concrete steps are also needed to enable the relevant national authorities to effectively enforce the payment of fees by owners of vehicles registered in another Member State. In the opinion of the ECR Group, this report responds properly to these challenges and will contribute to strengthening Member States' cooperation on road charging.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, we will vote tomorrow on the adaptation of the so-called EETS directive. I am very happy that we have managed to get this part of the first mobility package to the finish line. Hopefully, the other parts will follow soon, because European road transport is in need of clear rules. With the EETS directive, we are taking an important step towards better aligning the different electronic tolling systems. For EETS providers, the market to offer services becomes more interesting. This allows us to drive through all European countries with less red tape, with one EETS provider, one interpreter box and one invoice. Countries are not obliged to levy tolls. But if they do it eventually, payment and enforcement across borders will become easier. It is also important that automatic number plate recognition is included in the new regulations as a possible technology in tolling. This technique is reliable and is already widely used in Europe. In addition, it is important that toll defaulters do not escape the dance through the existence of administrative boundaries in Europe. We facilitate the cross-border exchange of information in the face of default with privacy safeguards. Finally, Mr President, the amendment of the EETS Directive is important in order to be able to introduce payment for use and pollution in road transport in the future. This really puts European road transport on the right and sustainable path.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, electronic toll systems should be able to cooperate with other systems and should be based on open and public standards that are available to all system suppliers without discrimination. The system for charging road users should be simple, fair and should not discriminate against drivers from other Member States. The level of the charges should be objectively reflected in the degree of environmental performance of the vehicle as well as on the technical condition of the road.  I am very glad that we have succeeded in pushing for the use of one on-board unit in all Member States. This eliminates the need to purchase individual short-term vignettes for travel in the Union. Although not all my requirements have been included in the Directive on the cooperation of electronic toll systems and the facilitation of cross-border exchange of information, I consider the final result to be a reasonable compromise and I thank the Rapporteur in particular for it.

name: Georg Mayer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has done on In itself, it makes perfect sense to standardise these systems in Europe-wide traffic, in other words to create a uniform system for lorries, so that we do not have to carry different systems in the car. On the other hand, however, this also means replacing the national vignette. After seeing in October what happened in the Bonnefoy report, what chaos has arisen here in the House, because we did not know what is going on with this kilometre-dependent toll and what is not, you can already imagine where the journey is going here. Because the journey here, I think, is clearly also to say that we want to introduce a toll for passenger cars at the end of the day. Once again, this system makes perfect sense for trucks. For light vehicles, we are simply opposed to it, because that would in fact mean replacing the vignette in Austria, which we reject. Once again, in connection with the Bonnefoy report, which is also linked to last week's ECJ decision, this is clearly a sign that a kilometre-based toll is to be introduced throughout Europe, and that will not happen with us. There is also a second aspect: public transport. We have recently decided to introduce electric buses: again, an additional cost, which, of course, will be borne by consumers at the end of the day.  All in all, if you look at these packages all together, that is, mobility should become a luxury, and both private and public transport will become a luxury for people. We cannot support that.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the Commissioner, the rapporteur, Mrs Salini, and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work. It is also from small things that Europe must be perceived as united by its citizens, and having a single, interoperable electronic electronic card system at Union level simplifies movement in the territory and is therefore essential.  Efficient transport networks are crucial to the competitiveness of our economies and to the success of the internal market. Road transport continues to increase and the potential of the road network must be fully exploited. Using a single piece of equipment not only allows users to interface with all systems in different countries, but also facilitates the cross-border exchange of information on infringements related to non-payment of tolls.  For these reasons, I am in favour of a European electronic toll system that will streamline payment procedures at toll booths, thereby also reducing traffic.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I really wanted to thank you. I also join in recognising both the Commissioner and the Rapporteur. Indeed, we have a situation today that this version of the directive, which is currently being proposed, is fortunately no longer very controversial. On this occasion, however, it is worth asking why there are now such serious problems in implementing an efficient toll system in Europe. In my opinion, this is primarily due to the fact that the directive, which has been in force since 2004, is not only unsealed, but also largely detached from economic realities. Therefore, if these new proposals are not to remain on paper, a market-based approach must prevail. The point is that the benefits of this new system are borne by road users and network managers. Then there would be a chance for the reality of this right.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by congratulating Mr Salini and all my fellow Members on the excellent result achieved in the trialogue.  The text we are voting on improves the exchange of information on vehicle data, provides suppliers with easier access to the toll collection market and facilitates the use of a single electronic toll device on board for all road journeys within the European Union. There is a mechanism for mutual assistance between Member States for the coercive collection of cross-border road tolls, but legal arrangements must be put in place involving local authorities in order to better address the problem of cross-border enforcement of penalties for non-payment of tolls.  Finally, the problem of privacy: the introduction of electronic electronic processing systems has implications for the confidentiality of personal data, since full travel profiles can be derived from them. In order to avoid this, it will be up to the Member States to provide anonymous and encrypted prepayment options for the European electronic electronic card service.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. We have a good solution thanks to the work done. I am very pleased that in this case we have not a new directive, but there is an opportunity to amend the previous one. However, two elements will be important once adopted. Firstly, the implementation system. On the one hand, we know very well that these anachronistic toll systems should go to the lamus. They are expensive, they are inconvenient, they also very often increase traffic jams, in short, in front of the places of their collection. What is also important, however, is that we keep in mind all the time the compatibility, the coherence of the system, a certain convenience for all those who also move through smaller countries, because this transit can in many cases be really cumbersome. And one important thing that I hope will be applied through the introduction of information systems, simply the inevitability to pay these fees, the elimination of various gaps.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, we are discussing a serious issue, at a time when a debate has begun throughout the European Union on whether it is legal to impose tolls. This is something that is being discussed now and in view of the European elections. There are political forces but also citizens and road users who feel that these charges are wrongly imposed. We also have the opinion of the Advocate General in austria's case against Germany the day before 6 February, which also on charges levied on foreign drivers. So I think the debate has a broader dimension. It is not only about how the fees will be collected or how to find a way to collect these fees by enforcement, but also whether this is legal, especially with regard to Greece, since all highway revenues have been allocated under orders from the troika to foreign lenders.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I’m really delighted I came in for this debate. We have here – as I’ve been listening closely – an electronic system, a single on—board unit that can go anywhere in the EU, cross-border enforcement and information exchange, modern smart technology with no toll booths, no border restrictions, no issues of any such kind. May I request the Commissioner sends a copy of this to Mr Barnier? I think that what we’re talking about here – surely this technology could be at least looked at for a solution to the Northern Ireland backstop situation with Brexit. it is very similar technology to what would be required. Instead of looking for people to charge tolls, you’re looking at cross-border trade. We’ve just seen here that there is no requirement for a hard border or a toll booth. it is a very exciting idea. It may not be what you were envisaging tonight, but I think that you may have stumbled upon the whole solution to the Brexit discussion, so I congratulate you. You may well go down in history, madam. Thank you.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I believe that the adoption of this directive will send a positive signal to the tolling industry as well as to Member States wanting to implement fair and efficient road pricing. It will help reduce the cost while enhancing the market in electronic tolling, ultimately benefiting citizens. But before I conclude, allow me to respond to a few of your questions and comments. First of all, the question regarding the Eurovignette. The Council work on our road-charging proposal will continue under the Romanian Presidency. I wish presidencies had been more ambitious and ready to engage on this topic, but we expect the Council to be ready to engage into negotiations with your House by the end of the year. Let me also respond to honourable Member Mayer. I would like to clarify again one very important point, today we are discussing ETS, which is an electronic tolling system, and again let me restate that the issue related to the vignette systems will be addressed in the road-charging initiative, which is also part of the first mobility package, which as I said will be negotiated with your House hopefully by the end of 2019. I will invite the honourable Member to explore its functionality in other matters by himself, so allow me at the end just to congratulate again Mr Salini and thank all Members who have contributed to achieving the compromise on this file. I’m really looking forward to a broader support during the vote tomorrow.

name: Massimiliano Salini
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate has indeed shown that we have reached a balance on a game that is of interest to everyone. The challenge of interoperability is a challenge that has to do with the idea of Europe. It's a bad word for interoperability, but it means harmony, it means collaboration, it means communication, it means seamless exchange.  And those who earn the most – and for the work they have done, I would really like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs, but also all the members who have spoken, and in particular the Commissioner for the debate that has taken place – from a harmonious system of movement, it is first and foremost the weakest groups, that is to say, all those who find it most difficult to bear the cost of non-Europe. Allow me to be a Commissioner and allow me, Mr President, to close this debate with a more political than a technical emphasis. We have already done the technical part, we have dealt with it properly in the negotiation phase. To talk about Europe, as Mrs De Monte said, is to talk about things like this, that is to say, to talk about instruments which, by answering real questions and needs, make something useful and inexpensive and immediately verifiable available to the most fragile citizens. Not to mention the usefulness that companies will have from a system such as this, because the movement of goods and people has as its first recipient the weakest groups and as the second privileged recipient the most enterprising groups of civil society, that is, those who create value on a daily basis, those who need a hospitable environment so that their energies can be released. The transport system, which is often blamed in this House for the problem of the environment and sustainability, etc., is in fact one of the great protagonists of this Europe, which many people talk about without knowing what it is and which we are talking about trying to build it.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, February 14, 2019.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Ivan 'Tefanec', on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the mutual recognition of goods legally marketed in another Member State (COM(2017)0796 - C8-0005/2018 - 2017/0354 (COD)) (A8-0274/2018).

name: Ivan Štefanec
text: Rapporteur - Thank you very much, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the completion of the single market in goods and services is one of the European Union's key priorities in the economic sphere. The European market accounts for up to a sixth of all world trade in goods, generating around 25% of the European Union's GDP and 75% of intra-Union trade. It is therefore necessary to continue to promote the free movement of goods and services between Member States, as well as to create favourable conditions for trade with third countries, since the single market and the free movement of products are one of the attributes for the successful functioning of the Union. However, there are not always common rules between member states and the principle of mutual recognition does not always apply.  Which means, in practice, that in the absence of specific Union legislation, Member States are free to set national rules determining the requirements that products must meet. Such national requirements may coexist in different Member States, but if they differ from one another, they may create barriers to trade within the Union. According to the principle of mutual recognition, goods marketed in accordance with the law in another State are not required to be prohibited in another State unless the other State has reasonable grounds to prohibit or restrict their sale. Mutual recognition covers products which are not or are only partially subject to harmonised Union legislation, such as a wide range of consumer products such as textiles, footwear, childcare articles, jewellery, tableware or furniture.  These goods represent around 20 % of the market. However, since mutual recognition has not always been found to work, the new Regulation on the mutual recognition of goods aims to improve the functioning of this principle and to ensure compliance with existing rights and obligations arising from the principle of mutual recognition. The adoption of this Regulation is also a response to the lack of application of the principle of mutual recognition in the field of goods due to a lack of awareness of this principle, legal uncertainty in its application and a lack of administrative cooperation between national authorities. In practice, this means that Member States continue to have the possibility to protect their legitimate national public objectives and to restrict the marketing of products, even if the market elsewhere is compliant, unless the decision is justified and proportionate. I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to work as rapporteur on this important proposal to improve the functioning of the single market. I am also very pleased that, together with my fellow citizens, the Council and the Commission, we have managed to find common ground in the trilogues on the text of the regulation, thus improving the functioning of this principle. I consider as key points, firstly, greater use of the principle of mutual recognition of goods, secondly, an increase in legal certainty for small and medium-sized enterprises, which will lead to simplified procedures vis-à-vis national authorities, through an established declaration of mutual recognition; Together, solutions will be sought to contentious issues relating to the mutual recognition of goods as well as cross-border cooperation. Last but not least, it is an improvement in solving problems using the already functioning SOLVIT system. This mechanism provides new effective remedies for restoring trust in the mutual recognition of goods.
