name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it is a pleasure to be here ahead of the final vote on the proposal for mutual recognition of goods. As you know, this is a very important proposal for the Commission. Let me first recall why we felt it was necessary to act. Mutual recognition is essential for the proper functioning of the single market for goods. it is about cutting red tape and making things simpler. Where no specific EU legislation is in place, Member States are free to set national rules that lay down requirements to be met by products. Such national requirements can coexist in various Member States. A product that can sell in one Member State, you should also be allowed to sell in any other Member State. That is a mutual recognition principle but evidence suggests that neither businesses nor national authorities make sufficient use of it. Many businesses do not even know about mutual recognition and just take national technical rules for granted. Many of those who know about it prefer not to rely on it as they find it rather unpredictable. Those who try to invoke mutual recognition to sell their products on other markets are often faced with denials or restrictions. Their only choice is to go to the national court procedures – very long and costly. As a consequence, businesses prefer to adapt their products to national applicable requirements or give up entering the market and authorities find it difficult to apply. National authorities are often cautious in accepting products marketed in another Member State. The lack of trust in rules that differ from their own makes them apply their own national requirements and deny mutual recognition. This is still one of the biggest remaining barriers to the single market for goods. Today, cardigans, shoes, notebooks, tableware, different goods, lawfully sold in one Member State can still, unjustifiably, be rejected in another Member State. Businesses lose market opportunities and consumers don’t benefit from increased choice and lower prices. With this new regulation we are moving to meet business and consumer expectations, and we are hoping to prevent further missed opportunities. By removing the remaining barriers to the functioning of the single market for goods, intra-EU trade could increase by more than EUR 100 billion per year. So I welcome the cooperation and support in the negotiations and I would like to particularly thank the rapporteur, Mr Štefanec, and shadow rapporteurs for the great work on this file. The negotiations were very constructive. This is why they were also speedy. We reached agreement in just under a year. This shows that we are all aware of why this is important. I welcome the compromise that we have reached. It will transfer mutual recognition in a reliable and efficient tool for businesses wanting to trade in a single market and it will benefit national authorities. The voluntary mutual recognition declaration will make it easier for economic operators to demonstrate that their products are lawfully marketed in another Member State and will make it easier to solve problems, building on solid foundations. It will offer economic operators a business-friendly alternative to long and costly court proceedings. Businesses will be more easily able to fight unjustified market access restrictions by using the problem-solving procedure and defend their right to mutual recognition. The Commission will intervene in this procedure, providing the expertise to assist solid centres in solving the case. We will put in place stronger administrative cooperation to facilitate the application of the mutual recognition principle, especially in sectors where the application is problematic. I welcome the importance Parliament attaches to strong administrative cooperation in this area. National authorities can discuss common problems and their chosen solutions. It is only by creating trust amongst them that we will have a true culture of mutual recognition. In addition, the Commission will implement an action plan on mutual recognition to complement this proposal. We will focus on raising awareness for businesses and authorities alike and emphasise the role of mutual recognition. And we will give special attention to sectors where the use of mutual recognition is economically advantageous but has been problematic or insufficient to date.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ivan Etefanec, for his excellent work. It is precisely the fact that there are still a whole range of goods in the European internal market for which there are no harmonisation rules. And in the field of these goods, the old principle of the past applies that a product legally manufactured in one Member State should actually be lawfully marketed in all other Member States. Unfortunately, this is often a principle that is not applied everywhere. In the United Kingdom, for example, there are special rules on the fire safety of furniture which do not apply in any other Member State of the European Union. And with that, of course, protectionism can be pursued to a little extent. This is the the sit-in in many Member States, but also in those who always claim to be not using such measures. That is why it has been a good thing that Mr Etefanec, together with the other Members, has attached great importance to the fact that these obstacles can and must be removed piece by piece. The Member States do not always like this, but the truth is that if the Member States want to avoid harmonisation, they will actually have to apply the principle of mutual recognition in full. And there are procedural rules that the Commissioner has mentioned. SOLVIT is certainly a method that can help. However, all Member States would also have to invest human resources in the same way, so that the institutions can really communicate with each other. It is not enough for one Member State to provide many people, another Member State that has problems but has only one person, then it does not work. So there is still a lot to improve, but the step that is being taken with this regulation now is really great. Therefore: Many thanks to Ivan Etefanec.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that the work that has been done on this regulation, which finally leads to the mutual recognition of goods legally marketed in another Member State, is very positive. In this way, it is possible to clarify and simplify the procedures that companies and national authorities are required to follow, as well as to improve the functioning of these principles with regard to mutual recognition.  As we know, free movement is not complete, the single market in goods needs integration. Mutual recognition fills this gap. The significant improvement in the application of the principle of mutual recognition will make it possible to give a blank cheque to companies. We will make life easier for businesses across Europe, while ensuring that Member State authorities have the opportunity to exclude unsafe products from their markets. In this way, we will be able to facilitate the recognition of safe and legitimately marketed goods and facilitate their placing on the market in any other Member State.  Superiority of the general public interest is also guaranteed. Member States may object to the marketing of certain goods where a legitimate and proportionate public interest is at stake. We have defined ways of improving administrative cooperation between national authorities, which will lead to a reduction in administrative burdens.  This regulation provides greater regulatory clarity for a wide range of consumer products, such as all those in the area that affects both food consumption and those intended for household life. In short, we are faced with a strengthening of product safety standards. This serves to define a high profile of policies concerning goods and their mobility and also the quality of consumption throughout Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mutual recognition of goods applies to products which are not subject to Union harmonisation legislation or are only partially covered by it. The fact that a product is already legally on the market strengthens legal certainty. Unfortunately, the despicable agreement of the Prespas, apart from the sell-off of our Macedonia and our history, leaves exposed Greek companies that use the name of our Macedonia to trade names, trademarks and brands, such as Macedonian wine, Macedonian halva, etc. This is because Article 3(4) entitles Skopje companies to use corresponding names called 'Macedonia'. The confusion will continue for at least three years. I'm asking you, Mr. President. Dombrovskis: how does the Commission intend to protect Greek companies that legally use the name of our Macedonia in trade names, trade marks and brands from unfair competition from Skopje companies that illegally use the name 'Macedonia'? We want an answer to this question, which is particularly serious. It is expected by the entrepreneurs of Northern Greece; the entrepreneurs of all Greece. I would ask that we have an explicit answer to put an end to the confusion surrounding this issue. I appeal to you, Mr Dombrovskis.

name: Bill Etheridge
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, at the moment Member States can set the standard as to what quality of goods they accept, and this proposal – as I understand it – would seek to standardise the quality and standards of the products being sold across the EU. Of course, the aim is to facilitate smoother trade – a noble goal, and one which I think we all share and would all like to see. Even those of us who will hopefully be outside the EU soon still hope to see a smooth flow of trade. After all, without trade, business and growth, the people are poorer – and no one wants to see that. However, in the form that this has been discussed tonight, it is yet another attempt to buck the market. Why shouldn’t different nations require different standards? Why shouldn’t they? Why can one nation and its people not say ‘we require a better level’? It seems to me that if you seek to make a mutual set of standards and bring everyone together, there is a danger that you are forcing some nations to accept a lower quality of product. This is not the marketplace. This is not good capitalism. This is not good trade. Why not allow businesses and business bodies to work on international standards, to come together and say ‘this is the kind of standard level that we’re aiming for’, and let them make proposals to put forward for international trade. After all, they are the experts. They’re the people who understand the market. They’re the people who understand production. President Reagan once said ‘government is not the solution to our problems; government is the problem’, and I think that unintentionally – certainly unintentionally – this is another example of that. Government should be removed from the process of trade, and the whole thing should be depoliticised. The proposal in front of us will cost billions in new regulations and training. The eurozone is declining in industrial output, by 0.9% month on month. This suggests that there is something being done wrong here. This proposal, as was mentioned by one of our colleagues earlier, could facilitate a serious lowering of standards – the UK fire safety standards were mentioned earlier on. Well, if a certain nation – be it the UK or any other nation – wants a level of standards on safety or anything else, they should be allowed to do it and businesses should be able to say ‘hang on a minute, this is what these guys need. We want to sell into this market, so let’s tailor our marketing and our production to fit that’.  Before I came to this place, I had a 20-year career in steel sales and exotic metals, and we would buy and sell all around the world. It was clear to us that in some places you needed a higher quality, a higher standard, and when you sell to those places you work out how you’re going to do it. Frankly, if they want a higher quality and standard, it’s a business opportunity because you can sell it for a higher price. Quality is a great driver of price. It should be a profit motive. Why not, if people want a higher quality? Allow market freedom. Allow people to look into this. Allow businesses to see where one nation might be able to accept something of a certain level, which is perfectly acceptable but can be done a lot cheaper and more competitively, and then look at the ones who are demanding higher standards, because that’s what the people and the customers there want and say ‘OK, we’ll do that for you, but by God you’re going to pay us for it’. When it comes to trade and business, there are always possibilities. There are always chances to make money and to do trade as long as government and politicians, regardless of their good intentions, step back a little and allow the market to do its job. Where there is demand, supply will find it. And when supply and demand come together, we get what we all want: business, profit and taxation for services, and everyone is better off. I think that we need to look at this in a whole different way.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the preamble, the free movement of goods is presented as a fundamental freedom. This is the original sin of this text. This abuse of language, however, perfectly illustrates the ultraliberal doctrine of the European institutions and of this Chamber. The freedom of movement of goods is not, and never will be, a fundamental freedom; it remains an economic facilitation, the result of trade, customs and international agreements, and that is it. Considering Europeans as consumers and Europe as a market will never solve the european Union's deep lack of credibility and legitimacy. To persist in this way, leads us to a dead end. The total free movement of goods is not an end in itself. It can be an effective development tool, only if it is strictly in line with national interests. Restricting the scope of Member States' action is a mistake and a reversal of economic common sense. The rigidity of this materialistic and ultraliberal vision of Europe brings only economic and social imbalances detrimental to consumer safety and respect for national specificities. Europe is a very different and much more beautiful reality. It is unworthy to sum up this continent to a market populated by consumers. I and my political group, echoing the irresistible rise of patriotic ideas in all Member States, believe that Europe and Europeans deserve better than this disembodied, cold and boring project. So trust us: in the very near future, we will offer them the possibility of another future so that economic common sense and the search for the general interest and the common good can be restored.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear Colleagues, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The European single market has been in place for 30 years. It is the object of our pride. We say that this is the greatest achievement of European integration. In theory, there is also a principle of mutual recognition, but in practice this principle is not respected. Around a quarter of products traded on the European single market are not covered by harmonisation rules and are regulated by individual Member States in terms of standards, technical standards, packaging, appearance, composition and so on. Unfortunately, this means that the European single market is not so single at all and that, in fact, we are dealing with fragmentation of markets. If we wonder why Europe has not developed great world champions, big corporations, one of the main reasons is that the markets are simply very divided and it is difficult to spread the wings of European companies. We should therefore remove all these barriers, which is why I wanted to thank Mr Štefanec, who prepared this report, because this report goes in the right direction. We should remove barriers to the movement of goods because this will make European companies more internationally competitive. And he makes this appeal to the Commissioner and the Council of the European Union who are not here, but I hope that this message will reach them too.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the single market also needs rules. We can't let it all go without a rule. We are talking here, in this proposal for a regulation, of a principle: mutual recognition. Obviously, if we have well-established, very clear rules at Member State level and we also have harmonised rules, it is much simpler for the economic operator, for the producer, and it is even safer for the consumer. I am surprised by the position of some colleagues who believe that we should leave everything without any supervision. The proposal for a regulation makes it very clear that both national authorities and economic operators must provide for very clear, non-interpretable technical rules, precisely so that there is no problem when it appears by sampling, perhaps, the verification of a product; because yes, there is a possibility in the Regulation for the economic operator to make a declaration, but this does not exclude the possibility for the Member State to verify whether the declaration of liability and coincides, whether the product coincides with the declaration on its own responsibility.  I do not see a barrier in the fact that we want to harmonise and apply this principle. On the contrary, I see an increase in the movement of goods in the internal market, an increase in safety for the consumer and, we must say, an efficiency of economic activity, with this clarification: the Commission must update the list of products covered by this regulation online because it must be known which products fall under this regulation. Then, of course, we need to have clear rules for the recognition of legally traded goods, because we need to understand that the marketing of illegal products also occurs. We are talking here in this regulation about the legal marketing of products and mutual recognition in the Member States, and there must be these clear rules in order to avoid a national authority, for example, then requiring certain checks on additional products which mean a cost and a bureaucracy, especially for small businesses.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, my thanks to you and to the honourable Members for your interventions and for your cooperation and support to achieve such a good result on this proposal. I very much welcome the agreement between Parliament and the Council, because mutual recognition is at the core of single markets for goods. But it is still one of the most important remaining barriers. With regard to the broader questions as to whether the regulation is impacting Member States’ capacity to protect legitimate public objectives, the answer is no. Mutual recognition is not automatic and therefore cannot jeopardise legitimate public objectives. This is embedded in the principle itself. Protection of legitimate public interests will always remain the exception to the mutual recognition law provided that it’s justified and proportionate. To conclude, with your vote tomorrow you are sending a strong and clear message about delivering on our commitment to help businesses trade in a single market. Our SMEs will benefit and our citizens will benefit.

name: Ivan Štefanec
text: Rapporteur - Madam President, I would like to stress that mutual recognition is essential for the proper functioning of the single market in goods. The integration of the single market in goods has many positive effects. European consumers benefit from a wider choice of products and increased competition in the manufacturing sector leads to price convergence and the promotion of innovation. Business costs for companies are also being reduced and, as we have heard in the debate, there is an increase in trade – an estimated increase of more than EUR 100 billion. I am pleased that it is this regulation that has succeeded, above all, in simplifying the rules, which is particularly useful for small and medium-sized firms and for the creation of new jobs. I am pleased that we are using the current institutions and not creating more, and I am also pleased that we have created a new platform for sharing experience for The Member States in this area. I would like to thank my colleagues very much for their cooperation, the European Commission, the representatives of the European Council as well, because I believe that it is in this form that we have seen a significant shift in the necessary completion of our common market.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, February 14, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Member States, in the absence of specific EU legislation, are free to adopt national rules to establish the requirements that marketed goods must comply with. These national requirements, if divergent between some Member States, may put obstacles in the way of intra-EU trade, leading to companies wishing to market such products in another Member State encountering obstacles, delays in the process and additional costs. The regulation under discussion provides for an intensification of coordination activities between the competent authorities, aiming to reduce market fragmentation for the benefit of businesses, in particular SMEs and consumers, who are indirectly passed on the additional costs to the companies themselves.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mutual recognition of goods lawfully marketed in another Member State will simplify procedures for businesses and national authorities when introducing products to the internal markets of member countries. Mutual recognition of goods on the basis of a voluntary declaration will reduce the administrative burden and simplify the functioning of the internal market in the placing of goods already meeting the requirements of another Member State. This rule will not apply to products that are subject to harmonised EU product safety rules or are only partially covered by them. However, the right of a Member State to refuse access to the market of goods where there is a legitimate and proportionate public interest must be preserved.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on Eva Maydell's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on fees for cross-border payments in the EU and money conversion fees (COM(2018)0163 - C8-0129/2018 - 2018/0076 (COD)) (A8-0360/2018).

name: Ева Майдел
text: Rapporteur – I had the privilege of being rapporteur for a regulation that not only brings our countries and citizens closer together, but also solves a daily practical problem for Europeans from non-euro area countries, saving them money. I thank Vice-President Valdis Dumbrovski, all the shadow rapporteurs and colleagues in the ECON committee with whom we have worked to send a true double standard to Europe. One hundred and fifty million Europeans and six million businesses from non-euro area countries will now be treated on an equal footing with those in the euro area and will pay much lower remittance fees. This will increase competition in the single market, but also a sense of a community to which we all belong. I am happy that the negotiations have taken a record short time and we have shown that the European Union can take quick and effective solutions that solve real problems. We have made great progress in solving another problem – we have provided much greater transparency in paying or withdrawing money with a card abroad. Anyone travelling to another country in the European Union will have much more information about what and how much they pay, and will be able to choose the most advantageous alternative. I use this case to invite the Commission to be ambitious in its report on the impact of the regulation's innovations, which we expect to be in three years' time.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Eva Maydell, on her strong will and ambition, ensuring that Parliament could form its views quickly and effectively, which led to the text you will vote on tomorrow. We welcome Parliament’s strong commitment to deepening the single market for retail financial services and payments, and to making the most of the euro, the EU’s common currency – for the benefit of citizens and businesses outside as well as inside the euro area. Today, only euro-area citizens enjoy the benefits of cheap euro transactions. Around 150 million Europeans who live in EU countries using other currencies do not. In fact, they sometimes have to pay very high and disproportionate fees for such transactions, particularly in cross-border situations. Let me give you an example. Imagine that you live in Italy and you wish to send EUR 50 to Finland. Because these countries are both in the euro area, EU rules prevent banks from charging more for this transaction than they would for sending money, say, from Rome to Milan. Now, imagine instead that you are living in Bulgaria and you want to transfer the same EUR 50 to Finland. Because domestic payments in euro in Bulgaria are generally expensive, the equivalent cross-border transaction is also very expensive. For a Bulgarian citizen this means he or she could end up paying as much as EUR 24 for this kind of transfer. The revised Cross-border Payments Regulation will remove this unequal treatment by extending the benefits of low-cost euro transactions across the whole EU. The regulation will ensure that, by 15 December this year, all European citizens and businesses will have the right to make cross-border payments in euros for the same price as domestic payments in their national currency. The Cross-border Payments Regulation will positively affect the vast majority – around 80% – of cross-border transactions originating from non-euro Member States and made in euros. Putting an end to high fees linked to cross-border euro payments will enable consumers and businesses in non-euro Member States to save around EUR 900 million every year. This will also contribute to our common objective of strengthening the international role of the euro as a payments currency. The revised Cross-border Payments Regulation will also increase the transparency of currency conversion services. This is especially important for several million Europeans who travel within the EU every year, either for business or for pleasure. Often, when paying by card or withdrawing cash at an ATM in a country that uses a different currency from the euro, it is very difficult to know exactly how much it will cost. It is equally difficult for consumers to choose the most convenient option when they are given the choice, on the spot, between paying in their own currency or in the local currency, for example when paying a hotel bill. By harmonising the disclosure of currency conversion costs, the regulation will allow European consumers to check and compare the currency conversion charges applied by their bank or by merchants. Consumers will be able to compare charges when shopping abroad with their cards, when withdrawing cash at an ATM abroad and when sending money, from their own country’s banking platforms, to a Member State using a different EU currency. This will boost competition between providers in such currency conversion services and should thus lower the cost of transactions between Member States in different currencies. Honourable Members, the European project is quite often perceived as distant from the lives of European citizens. This legislative initiative is a good opportunity to demonstrate how Europe can bring tangible benefits to its citizens.

name: Othmar Karas
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, Rapporteur Maydell, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on the work she has said. Following this afternoon's debate on tax justice and fairness, where unanimity in the Council is constantly blocking us in implementing our proposals, the new wire transfer regulation is an example of the European Union's ability to act. It could be said that, just as we have abolished roaming costs for international calls, this regulation is now abolishing roaming charges for money transfers, in and out of Member States that are not yet at home in the euro area. For all euro payments outside the euro area, but within the EU, the same fee must now be charged as for domestic payments. That is a good thing. This strengthens the internal market, creates cheaper transfers, leads to greater transparency, creates more competitiveness for all payment service providers in the European Union and can be implemented by 150 million citizens and six million entrepreneurs in the EU who benefit from it. In doing so, we have shown that we are constantly developing the internal market. Following the abolition of roaming charges for telephone calls, there is now an abolition of roaming charges for money transfers in Europe, but outside the euro area. Thank you very much to the rapporteur, Eva Maydell.

name: Olle Ludvigsson
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It can be said that our deal reduces the cost of cross-border payments in euro for consumers and businesses across europe, and I think that very well indeed. In the long term, however, all EU currencies need to be covered by the regulation. There is no reason in EU legislation to discriminate against countries outside the euro area. New transparency rules are being introduced for cross-border transfers, which I think is positive and also positive for consumers. With regard to rules on currency exchange fees for purchases and withdrawals abroad, it will continue to be very difficult for consumers to compare the costs of the various services. It is almost always cheaper to pay in the local currency of the countries in which you are located. However, the new rules will not allow real-time price comparison between costs for the bank's services and dynamic currency conversion services. Consumers need to be better informed about dynamic currency conversion and how expensive it really is. This could be a surcharge of 8-12%. It is a nuisance that deceives consumers of large sums of money every year. Unfortunately, the Council was not willing to meet Parliament on this issue. I therefore hope that the legislators who come after me will tackle this issue. It is an important issue and I also think that, as far as the EUROPEAN Union is concerned, we should try to find common solutions. I hope, then, as I said, that we will get through legislation that may come after me here, on this issue.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! I must admit that, as rapporteur for the ESC Group, I have mixed feelings about the text of the agreement. The biggest winner of our negotiations is the European Commission. It achieved its objective of equating cross-border charges in euro with domestic transfer fees, thereby further favouring the role of the euro as the default currency for cross-border money transfers across the Union. Another win is the European banking system, which, it can be said, has escaped from a kind of guillotine, i.e. avoided having to apply the same transparency criteria for foreign exchange transactions as providers of so-called dynamic currency conversion. However, the consumer who usually uses a bank transaction for card payments abroad and does not receive information about the fees charged in a transparent manner, as it should be, never wins here. Well, that is the stubbornness of the Council, already mentioned by its predecessor. Perhaps this is not the stage yet. However, at least a gradual improvement in the transparency of transaction fees should be appreciated. It is also difficult to disagree that equating fees for euro transfers with national payments will be a concrete aid for non-euro area companies. The ECC Group will vote in favour of the regulation, although we are far from enthusiastic.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, firstly, let me thank the rapporteur for her excellent work on this proposal, which is a real example of EU regulation working to cut costs and burdens, and putting the consumer first. The regulation ensures that the costs for cross-border payments in euro from one EU country to another are the same as an equivalent domestic payment, regardless of whether the countries are in the eurozone or not. Furthermore, customers in the EU withdrawing money from an ATM in a foreign currency will have much more clarity on the cost of their payment options. Following pressure from Parliament, the charges associated with credit transfers will also be made clear to consumers. From Parliament’s perspective, full comparability is the ultimate goal. That means that customers should always be informed of the cost of their payments in a foreign currency within the EU. The final text of this regulation takes a significant step towards full comparability but, in my view, more can be done. Therefore, I welcome the review that the Commission will undertake three years after the regulation enters into force. The review should explore how costs to consumers can be reduced further and should ensure full comparability of payment options. Nonetheless, customers will soon begin to reap the benefits of the new provisions, and I’m proud of the work we have done here in Parliament to bring this about.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Madam President! The proposal to limit bank charges on cross-border payments is a gift to our small and medium-sized enterprises. It is the roaming charge of the banks that we are now doing. Companies in non-euro area countries have been worse off than their competitors in the euro area. In Denmark, it typically costs a company between 15 and 50 kroner to complete a transfer in euros to another EU country. For countries in the euro zone, it currently costs the same as a domestic transfer. After all, this is not fair to those companies that are outside the euro zone. And in Denmark, it is actually small and medium-sized enterprises that pay the highest price because they have rarely had the resources to negotiate a lower price. I would like to give one example from the real world: a Danish small or medium-sized company producing designer furniture exports 75% of its products to other Member States. It costs 5 euros each time the company makes a foreign transfer. In today's Denmark it runs to 7000 euros a year. 7000 euros that the company can spend on staff, savings or investments. This is something that will benefit the European economy. My hope is that the next Parliament and the next Commission will work to extend the regulation so that it also eliminates unnecessary fees on payments between EU countries outside the euro zone. This is exactly the kind of legislation that the European Union must also focus on. It is legislation that creates growth, good conditions for businesses and thus jobs and security for citizens. Finally, a warm thank you to our rapporteur Eva Maydell. Thanks.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, we understand the concern with cross-border payments, we even understand the advantages of aligning the cost of these transactions with the values in each Member State, but the real problem lies in the very high cost that banks charge for these services which, even internally, reach exorbitant values. The first five banks operating in the national market Portuguese raised 1,876 million euros in commissions in 2018, an increase of almost 100 million euros compared to the previous year. Every day that the financial institutions in Portugal get from their clients 5.14 million euros per day. At the same time, the banking in Portugal fired, in 2017 alone, more than 4,000 workers, closing hundreds of branches, with special emphasis on the most disadvantaged regions. That is, once again, and as always, the bank profiting from both sides, at the expense of workers and their customers.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, when we talk about financial services, that is not that often we talk about consumer law. We are gathered around a text that has been negotiated by our Parliament on a clear position. We all know citizens who have encountered these impossible situations: they are abroad, they pay in the local currency, and are not informed until much later of the conversion rate and fees applied by the bank. Or they choose to pay in their currency, but a provider converts the amount of the transaction, it is called "dynamic currency conversion," and this operation often has a very high cost. When in reality, there is no reason why euro transactions are so expensive. The European Parliament had an additional demand, an additional ambition, that this transparency of fees could be communicated to the consumer at the time of sale or access to the distributor. Because the idea was to be able to compare the two options. Unfortunately, the Council has not followed us and, in the end, we have a text which leads to the that this information will be available, but not in real time, and I want to mark a slight disappointment in the concert of praise that accompanies the adoption of this text. Nevertheless, this is a real step forward: creating the obligation to pass on expense information is essential if consumers' rights are to be better respected. We will have to go further and ensure that equal costs for transactions in euros and foreign currency are also a reality in the internal market, but that will be up to our successors. I believe that today we can, as Othmar Karas said earlier, welcome the 'roaming' of euro transactions within the European Union and this is good news for consumers.

name: Ralph Packet (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, perhaps you know the problem. You are travelling to a European country with a currency other than the euro, and if you put your card in the machine, you will be asked if you want to pay in euro or in the local currency. Later you come home and you will see on your account statements that you have made the wrong, far too expensive choice, due to all kinds of costs. We are now ending that. There will be more transparency about the cost and exchange rate, so that consumers will no longer be surprised and can choose honestly whether they want to pay in euro or in the local currency. In addition, this agreement also ensures that transferring money to a non-euro country in the European Union will cost as much in euro as in the local currency. Usually that's free. Consumers, as well as SMEs, will therefore save money. We are therefore taking two good measures here in the interests of European consumers and in the interests of SMEs.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to welcome the proposal for this regulation, because, as a result, it really makes life very easy not only for consumers, for our citizens – 150 million, as has been emphasised in this debate – but also, of course, for SMEs. This undoubtedly also contributes to greater coherence between Member States, and this is also the main concern. I like the fact that there has been a number of positive messages, as well as the way in which this debate is conducted in a positive spirit. On the other hand, we must say to each other that perhaps more could have been done, so let us take this as a commitment to the next parliamentary term.  Personally, I would like to say with confidence that the Czech Republic will not only benefit from this adjustment, but, for example, will proceed to the common currency of the euro, which is also my fundamental and political objective. I'm glad we'll pay less, maybe we should be more transparent, but I'm glad we managed at least this.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, I think we are discussing an interesting piece of legislation that really touches all the citizens of the European Union. We have all gone to other countries of the European Union, where the euro does not exist, and it is a fact that there is no transparency in the way in which the local currency is converted, either when we pay in a POS or when we pump in cash of the local currency. I think that the measures taken in terms of transparency are very important. Also, remittances within the European Union should have no costs.  I would just like to make a point. In Greece, systematically, a particular bank charges two euros for each withdrawal, as happened in my case, when it comes to a card or account abroad. Obviously, these charges are illegal. Other banks do not impose such a burden and I think we should look at this in detail, Mr Dombrovskis. I will send you the information on this matter.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, once again let me congratulate the rapporteur for her work and her dedication, and also the shadow rapporteurs for their support in the negotiations. Coming back to some of the points which were raised during the debate: we spent quite some time debating whether this regulation should be extended to all currencies of the EU, but the point is that only euro transactions are the same everywhere, on the basis of the Single European Payment Area (SEPA); and only euro transactions benefit from the efficient payment infrastructures and processes that are available to all banks in the EU directly or indirectly. In the case of the euro, we have already created the infrastructure, and what we can do, with the regulation, is basically to make sure that banks are passing on the efficiency of this infrastructure to the consumers. But we do not have it for all currencies in all cross-border situations. Let me stress again that this legislative initiative is a good opportunity to remove fundamental inequality among EU citizens and to unify the single retail payments market. This is of tangible benefit to Europeans in their daily lives, so let’s make it happen.

name: Ева Майдел
text: Rapporteur. – We live in a very competitive and global world where Europe must truly reap the benefits it has. The Single Market is our greatest economic strength and we need to complete it as soon as possible, including by extending the regulation to all European currencies.  I also emphasise the need for an in-depth analysis of how Europeans get full real-time information on card payments and withdrawals of money in foreign currency. Technology is really evolving at a very fast pace. There is no doubt that such information can be provided without particular difficulties and costs by financial institutions.  Finally, when different Europeans are treated differently, this is the easiest recipe for creating anti-European sentiment. And that is why I believe that with this regulation we have concrete results that European citizens will be able to feel from December 2019 and thus we will eliminate a true double standard. Thank you again to all the colleagues in the European Parliament with whom we worked together to make sure that the so-called 'bank roaming' is abolished not for five, six or 10 years, but only for a few months. I also thank my colleagues from the European Commission as well as the Bulgarian and Austrian Presidencies for working together.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, February 14, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 150 million EU citizens and 6 million companies operating in non-euro area countries pay much higher euro transfer fees than people and businesses in the euro area. This is unfair and should be amended so that payment service providers across the EU are required to charge the same fees for cross-border transactions in euro as for domestic payments in local currencies. For non-euro area countries, this will lead to cheaper transactions in euro, with savings for consumers and businesses estimated at around EUR 1 billion per year. This will ensure a level playing field for companies in the euro area and beyond. The new rules will also protect consumers from excessive and arbitrary currency conversion burdens. When making payments in another currency, they are to be informed of the amount to be paid in the local currency and the currency in which the account is held. Consumers will be informed of the amount to be paid in local currency and account currency for each transaction, allowing them to make an informed choice. Consumers will receive an electronic push notification, such as a text message, email or notification via the payer's mobile or web app, of the applicable currency conversion fees. Banks will not be able to charge the customer for the notification service.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Roberts Zule, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No. 1073/2009 establishing common rules for access to the international market for bus and coach services (COM(20 17)0647 - C8-0396/2017 - 2017/0288 (COD)) (A8-0032/2019).

name: Roberts Zīle
text: Rapporteur. – Dear sitting leader! Commissioner, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work. With regard to this proposal, which we will be debing today, I must say that the original Commission proposal was oriented - and still remains in the report of the Committee on Transport - that the market for bus and coach passenger transport in Europe should also be opened within one Member State to a company in another Member State, as it is currently only open to international transport as part of the service. The Commission's original proposal also included eliminating discrimination, creating independent dispute resolution bodies or regulators in each of the Member States in order to have a level playing field for all companies.  In the Committee on Transport, we assessed more than thirty compromises and found a solution that we believe leads to understanding and balancing these views. We partly departed from these good liberalisation objectives and left it to the Member States to allow non-full authorisation of transport operations that are over a hundred kilometres away, making it possible for Member States to justify that a public service contract is affected or that the public interest is affected and to prevent another participant from entering.  We also found a good solution to the independence of the regulatory body, which must be found in each Member State and which also provides additional safeguards in relation to it if a Member State considers that a entrant creates unfair conditions on this market.  On the availability of bus and coach facilities: if there was initially the possibility that access to any new entrant on the market at bus and coach ing facilities could be rejected only because of the capacity criterion, we created additional criteria as a compromise that could allow for actually limiting the availability of bus and coach ing, which was also a step towards those who did not want to open up the market.  Finally, we also created a situation where, even companies which register in the Member State concerned and obtain authorisation, after obtaining this authorisation, all the conditions that exist in that Member State, including the social conditions that exist in that Member State, in order to be able to operate on the passenger market, must be fulfilled.  I would like to switch to English now to make some final remarks on political issues. I would like to thank all my shadow rapporteurs, who worked very constructively. As I described, we did not get 100% of what most of us expected but we got a good balance in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. And I am relying very much on the plenary tomorrow as well. At the same time, I am surprised that some of our colleagues are trying to keep this Coach and Bus Regulation as a hostage for Mobility Package I, with the aim of changing the mobility package in their own policy direction. In my political experience, it's not good politics to try to succeed on one issue by drawing in unrelated issues. I would remind you that all the social issues for drivers and companies working in road transport are in Mobility Package I, not in my report. There was nothing in the initial Commission proposal and there is nothing now about social conditions. So, while I fully understand the political will here, I would ask all my colleagues to be serious – in these final months before the European elections and a new parliamentary term – in seeking to finalise this proposal at first reading and to create a good opportunity for discussing it in the future with the Council, when the Council is ready.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, buses and coaches provide an affordable and clean public transport service. Those services can be complementary and not in competition with rail services, linking regions and cities which are not well connected by railways. In this context, the proposal presented by the Commission as part of its second mobility package aims at improving the mobility of EU citizens within Member States, while increasing the sustainability of national transport systems, offering an attractive collective transport alternative to the use of private cars. The proposal will lead to an increased offer of domestic services that are more responsive to citizens’ needs, in particular for those on lower incomes. It will also bring economic and social benefits, with increased investment and job creation in this sector. Let me recall some key figures and benefits associated with the proposal by 2030: cumulative CO2 emissions savings of EUR 183 million, accumulated administrative savings of EUR 1560 million, an increase of about 11% in coach transport activity and 85 000 new jobs. The Commission generally supports the report by your rapporteur, Mr Zīle. I would like to thank him for his hard work and the quality of his report. I would also like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) as a whole for its support for the compromise amendments.  We believe that many of those compromise amendments add valuable detail and clarity to the Commission’s proposal. This is, in particular, the case regarding the role of the national regulators and for public service contracts granted with an exclusive right. It is indeed very important to have a strong regulator in all Member States to carry out the necessary economic equilibrium tests and to deal with possible appeals. Likewise, it is essential that we find the right articulation between public services and those provided on a commercial basis. I believe that Mr Zīle has managed to get the balance right – to protect public service contracts adequately while at the same time allowing commercial offers to flourish. On certain points, such as on the administrative burden on operators and on the definition of bus terminals, we fully understand the good intentions behind the compromise amendments, but we believe more work is needed. To conclude, I believe you have a very good and promising report in front of you, which will contribute to improving bus and coach services to the benefit of EU citizens. So I’m very much looking forward to the constructive debate tonight.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, indeed, on 22 January, the Committee on Transport gave the go-ahead to a dossier which solves two objectives: the necessary liberalisation of the sector with the existence of models from some States which give pre-eminent importance to the provision of public services. The bus, ladies and gentlemen, is the most social mode of transport. It makes it possible that citizens of any corner are not isolated. This proposal is intended to facilitate non-resident carriers' access to the market in another European Union country to provide intercity coach services there. At the same time, carriers offering domestic intercity routes are guaranteed to benefit from further liberalization of the European bus market. This is a good balance between liberalisation and protection of existing public service contracts. It has allowed, I believe, a clear majority of this House to be encouraged. International liberalization brings us to a more integrated European Union and will also lead us to a fairer and more competitive market. But, in turn, public service contracts that work efficiently in some countries are not ignored, as recognized by fulfilling a degree of satisfaction recognized by all surveys. Interestingly, some who oppose accuse the dossier of excessively liberalizing and of not contemplating public services, and others say it falls short. Ladies and gentlemen, not one thing or another. It is a balanced text that allows systems as different as German, French or Irish to coexist. Markets such as German, which is liberalized, will still be able to be liberalized and even go further, and a market such as Spanish, which is open concessional, which brings cause of the singular orography, is protected and allows the State not to have to deal with its resources, since the concession comprises profitable parts and parties that are strictly inexcusable public service. I therefore believe, ladies and gentlemen, that the rapporteur has done a great job, and I commend him. And I think the shadow rapporteurs have tried to contribute to keep up with them. I hope that tomorrow, in the vote, this work of all will be reflected.

name: Петър Курумбашев
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– We were surprised to welcome this Commission proposal because, on the one hand, in heavy-duty transport, liberalisation had to be stopped and, on the other hand, there had to be liberalisation in the field of buses, which, as my colleagues have stressed before me, is indeed the most social service. I never understood why we had to go in two areas of transport in totally different directions, namely stopping the liberalisation of heavy goods truck transport and liberalisation in transport by buses.  However, let me really congratulate our rapporteur, Mr Zille, who has managed to strike a balance so that we do not apply the German model in Spain, nor the Spanish model in Germany. And so we can really apply this model, which applies both in Spain, for example, and in my country, where too many cities, already large cities, located, for example, on the Black Sea coast, cannot afford to have a transport between cities. Or you can imagine what is happening inside the country and in the increasingly dwindling villages and small towns in countries such as Bulgaria, and in many other countries of Central and Eastern Europe. It is absolutely unworthy of the attempt to link the Mobility 1 package to the Mobility 2 package, because we here in Parliament are elected to do the work. What we have agreed to be voted on, and what we have not agreed on, the majority ask themselves why this is happening and whether it has the right to demand that Mobile Package 1 be adopted in this way.  So let me congratulate the rapporteur and my colleagues. I would also urge you not to work towards delaying and in any case rejecting this report, which is regrettably requested by our group, and to work towards accepting tomorrow the proposals made by the three main major political groups.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Passenger transport by bus and coach is the most common and cheapest means of public transport. In many areas, especially rural areas, it is sometimes the only means of public transport. Opening up this sector to cross-border competition is an important and necessary step that will have a positive impact on the quality, access and prices of such services. Of course, it is necessary to safeguard the public interest by ensuring proper control over public transport for national and local authorities, which will be able to react at a time when the rules of free competition are being infringed to the detriment of passengers. I believe that the Zīle report balances well the potential benefits and risks of opening up the market for coach and bus services. This is also an appropriate step in the context of our discussion on the future of road freight. We need more rules of this kind which, instead of building new barriers, open the door to the movement of services between Member States. I hope that it is in this spirit that our work on the mobility package will also be completed.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for presenting the proposal. We agree on the principle that competition improves the services and prices that users receive, but we also oppose spoiling systems, which are already open to competition and awarded in a transparent manner, function and enable a public service that is impossible to offer under other conditions. That principle applies in my Member State for the granting of bus transport licences. It is a practical embossing of collaboration between the public and the private. Allows a portion of the operating results of the most profitable routes to support the service of routes that are not; enables a public service of high social value. That is why we will support in this report the concessional system of the Spanish State. It allows buses to be the most accessible, if not the only, transport service possible for many Europeans. I would therefore like to thank Mr Zéle for his efforts to understand this reality and to Luis de Grandes and his team for the work done to explain it. I ask you to support this system and also this report, because it supports citizens who, far from the urban sphere, are a hope for the strategy against depopulation that threatens much of the European territory.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal offers no doubt: the aim of this Regulation is to promote further liberalisation of the road transport sector. If, on behalf of the single market, they had already opened the door to concentration in the sector for the benefit of large multinationals, now the Commission and this Parliament want to go further. They opened the doors of national markets by imposing on Member States a set of rules for the operation of their own road passenger transport services. They illuminate restrictions on access to long-distance markets to facilitate multinationals' entry into this market and, as has happened on the railway, to guarantee them access to terminals, in what will eventually be another element of privatisation of the sector. This further liberalisation of national markets will facilitate the assault of large European companies on the transport network in the States, with predictable and verified consequences. Apart from the resulting phenomenon of concentration in the sector is expected the degradation of transport services provided to the population, the degradation of infrastructure and terminals and the degradation of the working conditions of workers in the sector. At the same time, it removes member states' instruments for the defence of their transport strategies, in particular by compromising the safeguarding and development of the public transport sector, and on increasing the supply of public transport to the detriment of the population. We reject this strategy, which is why we have put forward a proposal for rejection, an opportunity to safeguard the interests of the people and to enhance public transport.

name: Michael Cramer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done First of all, I would like to thank Robert Zéle and the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation, even though we had strong differences.  For the Commission, Germany has always been a successful example. After the liberalisation in 2013, many long-distance bus companies were initially on the market there, today virtually only one, a monopoly. That is why Germany is not a model of success.  In addition, working conditions are completely excluded. Drivers often have to stay on their buses, or prepare the bus before and after the trip, check tickets and provide information. None of this has to be counted as travel time, i.e. paid. In this way, unfair competition with environmentally friendly railways becomes even more unfair because no train driver is obliged to do so.  Long-distance buses will also remain exempt from tolls, while every locomotive will have to pay a toll on every kilometre of the route across the EU. A means of transport that is cheap through price dumping must not be subsidised in addition. Unfortunately, our amendments were all rejected in committee. I also believe that a revision of the regulation does not make sense until mobility package 1 has been adopted. The social rules on driving and rest periods have a decisive impact on the long-distance bus market. Clarity must be provided beforehand – in the interests of the workers. That is why the Group of the Greens/European Socialists and European Socialists rejects the Commission's proposal as a whole.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Roberts Zīle, but certainly also to the two Spanish shadow rapporteurs, Louis de Grandes Pascual and Inés Ayala Sender. Because we all know that the opening of the international bus market in Spain is an important hot item. Access to the international bus market is part of the internal market. And we want to open up the internal market, which we are proud of, also to international competition. But that opening must be accompanied by certain safeguards. We must not only opt for flexibility, but also respect so-called public service contracts and, above all, workers' rights. It is particularly wry that Mr Cramer says that we cannot assess this dossier until we have assessed the first mobility package, because at the same time the Greens are blocking that first mobility package. So we have no use for this kind of hypocrisy. I believe that Zīle and his team have now found a good compromise and an adequate conclusion for the internal and therefore international bus market.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Zéle for his work and, above all, for the listening and flexibility he has had with the demands of so many such different bus systems, which are as important to countries as mine, such as Spain, where orography and border blockade of railways make them so socially necessary. And we have come precisely — I believe that Mr van de Camp has not learned well in this , through the work of both Mr Zéle and Mr Kouroumbashev, to whom I pay tribute, to a protection of the Spanish system of concessions, because precisely a system has been achieved that reaches all places, even the most lost places with fewer people. It arrives with quality buses increasingly competitive in emissions issues. It also arrives with affordable prices. It is also capable of accepting and maintaining the work of its drivers. That needs to be improved is clear, but for that we have the first mobility package, which we will also be able to improve. And, therefore, it is a system that is maintained and that protects against any other possibility. For this reason, we are so grateful to Mr. Zéle, and especially... (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker).)

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the liberalisation of bus transport proposed by the Commission jeopardizes an important service of general interest in many Member States. It is a "cut and paste" of French and German laws, which pays the ground to Flixbus-style private monopolies and the uberlization of the bus sector. The Commission should draw inspiration from models that work, such as Spanish, Irish or Austrian; ensure public service status and that less profitable journeys in monetary terms are also covered. It is a matter of social profitability and territorial vertebration. We defend a concurrenced bus sector, managed from the public administration, that prioritizes interest, public interest strategies — connectivity and territorial cohesion; the good frequency of services; affordable prices; good training and working conditions for drivers; maximum security for users and, ultimately, defend the public service, expand its reach, and leave no one in the gutter.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In Germany, domestic bus services have been liberalised since 2013. What did this mean? More and more consumers have been given the opportunity to travel cheaply over longer distances and by safe and environmentally friendly bus. The increasing number of bus passengers, especially from rural areas, speaks for itself. This must finally be possible in cross-border transport. I am glad that this text has succeeded, on the one hand, in making the market a little fairer and opening up throughout Europe, and, on the other, of respecting the subsidiarity of the Member States. Since it must be guaranteed that access to the terminals is non-discriminatory, this means that applications for access should be rejected not only when there is no capacity available, but also if, for example, the bus company continuously refuses to pay or violates the house rules. I am pleased that these points have been included in the text. By the way: cabotage is not a problem in long-distance bus services, as the route is always approved by the host Member State before it can be operated. This means that timetables with specific journey times and routes will be predetermined and approved. In contrast to truck journeys, long-distance bus journeys are therefore really controllable. The criteria and framework conditions for bus transport are therefore different from that of lorry traffic. Bus liberalisation and mobility package 1 have nothing to do with each other. Many thanks to Robert, Louis, and the other shadow rapporteurs.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this proposed regulation on coach and bus service liberalisation has serious flaws and I believe it is premature to vote on our report on this issue now. It is welcome that the Committee on Transport and Tourism is limiting its coverage to inter-urban bus services only. But the duties on terminal operators, under Article 5, to accommodate new services are still potentially too onerous and may well be the subject of litigation if they are imposed in this form. In particular, the environmental objectives faced by terminal operators, in relation to tackling congestion and pollution, should have been specifically acknowledged and protected. Equally, there is significant evidence, from surveys of bus drivers and trade union reports, that, as others have said, the liberalisation already in place in many Member States has impacted negatively on drivers’ terms and conditions of work. Therefore, we should not be liberalising further at this stage. Points similarly made by the European Economic and Social Committee have not been properly accommodated in the report and there is still clearly a risk of profitable routes been exploited to the detriment of good public-service contracts. In Article 8, the definition of public service contracts – while I accept that Mr Zīle and his colleagues have tried hard on this – is not in line with the 2007 regulation. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I will speak in English now. My question to Ms Anderson is the following: what is her view on the future of international bus companies and workers in the next 20 years? Ms Anderson is always blocking every new development and always hiding behind the social rights of the workers. There are no new developments. We have unfair competition from outside the EU. If we don’t change, we have no future. What is her answer?

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – It’s simply not true to say that I always block things. The Port Services Regulation, which we had a very strong debate about, is something I ended up very much supporting because we came to a good result. The point is that we’ve rushed this. I’m not saying that we could never do something in this area, but we’ve gone suddenly from a market that was about international services to talking about a very sensitive area where some Member States are very different from others. I’m absolutely not saying that this is not possible to achieve, but we have definitely rushed this report.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The regulation in its current form, which we are discussing today, provides a balanced response to the needs of the market and enables companies providing passenger transport services to benefit more fully from the potential of the internal market. Further opening up of transport markets can only strengthen the segment of international transport services, which will benefit passengers in particular. This regulation will make it possible to be more competitive and, we know this from experience, when there is competitiveness, companies offer better quality services for less money, so passengers will absolutely benefit from it. However, I cannot fail to mention some dissonance here. And I am very pleased that we are committed to liberalising the internal market for passenger transport. But what about the carriage of goods? Here, my German colleague Mr Koch, whom I respect very much, said that we have no problem with cabotage. Let us not discriminate. So I hope that the same answer will be in the case of the number one mobility package, that we will liberalise the market everywhere and for everyone, not just when one country has a dominant position.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the regulation providing for new rules for buses is very important in order to give a regulatory framework to new realities that are developing throughout Europe. However, the Commission's initial proposal left too much freedom. The risks are still obvious when we talk about public service contracts which, in my opinion, are not yet fully protected, and the failure to exclude suburban areas from the scope of the legislation also puzzles me. In principle, I agree with making the sector more dynamic and competitive, but this must not be at the expense of the protection of those essential transport services which, in my opinion, must continue to be regulated at national level. We must rely on the prospect of a gradual and controlled liberalisation process, but without prejudice to the current profitability of existing services.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I welcome the work of my fellow Member Zīle, who has put a balanced report on the table, which has struck a balance between the liberalisation of the bus-related service market and the protection of public service contracts in the Member States. The freedom to provide services is, we know, a very important EU principle. Opening up markets and increasing competition can result in cheaper and more quality services. At the same time, it was important to prevent harmful phenomena, so the report rightly foresked out protection mechanisms for cases and routes where public service contracts are already in place, or urban or suburban lines. Another element of the report is to prevent raisins between lucrative routes. Such a phenomenon should not be allowed, as it could adversely affect the availability of certain rural settlements. And the whole point of bus services is that, and the great advantage is that they allow easy contact with even the most feared regions. This is also linked to the expectation that the new services will not jeop jeopment the economic equilibrium of existing public service contracts and that national authorities should have the right to include the service licence in all such cases. At the same time, we also see that the debate on the Council side has not yet begun, so we can envelop that the final regulation will be negotiated by the next composition of the European Parliament.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to commend the work of the rapporteur and, at the same time, I would like to stand up for the very rural areas, areas that are already suffering from certain disadvantages. For them, this liberalisation can represent a very fundamental shift. We are certainly following the path of competitiveness, which should lead to improved services. Even in the Czech Republic we have a number of areas that are not networked by the railway network, and for this reason this regulation is quite essential for us. I want to welcome him, of course it fulfills other goals. It is intended to meet the needs of citizens, especially those on lower incomes, to bring new jobs. These are all positives. I also like the fact that it was the suburban lines that I found worthy of the report.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course we have seen different views here. Only those who said they disagreed with the report did not make any credible arguments. How can we not talk about liberalisation? How can we say that privatising services in the field of bus transport would be bad for the internal market? I start with what I should say at the end: I support the report and the delegation Romanian support this report. My country also has problems in rural areas, where transport is done by coach, but not only in rural areas - and between Romania and Hungary, between Romania and Spain, even between Romania and Serbia and other states this transport is done by coach. I support the report, I appreciate the balance that is in this report and, of course, we have not had any perfect regulation and we have not been able - that is why they are compromises - to make a regulation as only a party would like, but I suggest and I invite colleagues to vote on this report tomorrow because, Commissioner, we are stepping on the mobility package, we want to block this one as well. What should we say to our citizens? What are we doing here?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the liberalisation of bus and bus services without conditions will create too many problems and we must bear in mind, as the report says, that public service contracts must be protected, because otherwise, large monopoly companies will be interested in the traffic routes and will abandon the rest. In Greece we also have coaches and buses. We have the bus services, which provide very specific services and even operate in remote areas. The operation of these companies should be protected, because with extreme liberalisation there is the possibility of the bankruptcy of these companies. The same applies to companies providing coach services.  Another issue to watch out for is the fact that the modernisation of the bus fleet cannot be done easily, because these companies do not have capital. If they are forced tomorrow to modernise their buses and coaches, it is obvious that they will be closed down and that will strengthen the large multinational companies. Let us take the issues of the protection of local transport undertakings seriously.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What are we talking about now: about long-distance buses. Many people fit into a bus. We always talk about the fact that, in the context of decarbonisation of transport, we have to see that we have more means of transport, where a collective number of people can travel with us. The bus is clearly such a means. We already have some of the municipal buses that make public transport; that should definitely continue. We have railways, but we do not have them everywhere. That has already been said. I come from Germany, we have a good rail network. But this is far from the case in all countries. That is why we need an opportunity to be transported collectively to several, and buses are a good option, because there are more roads than rail in Europe. That is one thing.  I therefore think that this liberalisation of long-distance buses is really good. Even in Germany, the Greens in the Bundestag welcomed this when it was introduced, because it can bring more people into a mode of transport together. I think it's a great job that Robert Zéle has done here. I thank the Commission for the proposal. We should move in this direction in a harmonised Europe, so that we can transport more people together everywhere – in this case on the bus.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – Gesine, you mentioned that the Greens agreed to the liberalisation of long-distance buses. That is true, but under fair conditions, and one of our conditions was that the bus drivers, the buses, pay a toll in the same way that the railways have to do it. You cannot make the environmentally friendly rail expensive – artificially – and everything about the bus must be cheap. That was the reason why we agreed – but ultimately not because the toll is not fair competition if it applies on the one hand and not on the other. What do you say about that? Are you also for the toll for the buses?

name: La Présidente. –
text: It is not exactly a question, but Ms. Meissner will answer it anyway.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I can say – and I have followed this closely – that the Greens did not say anything about the toll as a condition at the time.
