It did not come either. Nevertheless, you agreed to the buses, because you realized that this can give a better carbon footprint even in relation to the individual passenger than, for example, even the train. I have followed this with great interest and I know that the toll was not the condition, but rather quite different criteria that led to you agreeing; and they were right. That the development is to be observed is another matter.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me, one more time, to thank Mr Zīle and all the Members who have contributed to this proposal. I very much welcome the broad support expressed tonight and I took note of certain concerns that were raised, so allow me to respond to the main points. First, a general comment on public services. Commercial services carrying passengers over distances of 100km or more will concern only a small proportion of public-service contracts throughout the EU because many routes operated as part of public-service contracts are under 100km long, and passenger journeys on them are implicitly shorter. In addition, public services – and not only those with exclusive rights – can remain protected. I hope that clarifies the first point that was raised. Let me also stress again that this proposal does not affect the social conditions applicable to bus and coach drivers. As rightly mentioned by Mr Zīle, those social conditions are regulated in another piece of legislation, which is being revised under Mobility Package I. And, in its proposal on rest and driving time, the Commission does not propose to change the rules which apply specifically to bus drivers. On the environmental requirements, I would like to clarify that the authorisation procedures proposed by the Commission, which are mentioned in Mr Zīle’s report, provide a clear possibility for Member States to impose environmental performance requirements and to control them – provided, of course, that those requirements are imposed on all operators on a non—discriminatory basis. On the fourth point, regarding charging rules applicable to bus transport, Mr Cramer, let me also underline that the Commission has proposed, in Mobility Package I, new rules contributing to a level playing field for different modes of transport. So I’m inviting everyone, please, to support Mobility Package I because it resolves many issues that honourable Members find challenging in the current situation. I hope, Mr Cramer, that your concerns too can be addressed through the mobility package. Allow me also to make one last comment on the proposed motion of rejection that has been tabled. This would be a big missed opportunity for the sector and for citizens. If the proposal were rejected the sector would not be able to benefit from common rules across the EU. And you know what such rules mean: a bigger market, better salaries, more competition, better service. So, it would not be able to benefit from common rules across the EU, and instead would be faced with different national rules, as is the case today, and that is what is preventing the sector from expanding. And I’ll tell you who would lose most: low—income groups and those living in remote areas. We want every single village to be connected. Honourable Members will know that, in the next Commission programme, we have also proposed ‘smart villages’, and mobility is an essential part of that new concept because we do not want any part of the EU to be excluded from development. We want all parts to be connected and fully engaged with modern European Union opportunities. That is what is at stake, and I know that it is pre—election time but please bear in mind the benefits that we are bringing, and let’s deliver as much as we can during this Parliament’s term because European citizens really need this.

name: Roberts Zīle
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank Madam Commissioner for her statement and I think it helps very much. Whatever we think politically about this issue, I still believe that we have a good mood in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and everybody who spoke here – and most of you are from the Transport Committee – is really keeping a good mood in different dossiers, which is very difficult. I think even if we are very close to elections we will not lose our joint aim, which is to create a really pure single market, go step by step, but make transport efficient and environmentally friendly. I think it has united us in the Transport Committee and will do so in the future as well. Of course some of the statements show that liberalisation is like some monster coming from other Member States that would like to do bad things to other Member States and destroy everything, but it’s really not true and we know that in other modes of transport – like aviation – it’s not the case. Why are we speaking today about this new legislation on bus and coach market opening? What is actually the main aim? The main aim is better quality passenger transport for people and the secondary aim is to create social conditions for drivers, which is already regulated and will, in the future, be regulated by Mobility Package I. This is secondary and business is also secondary. Who owns the bus and coach transport market? First and foremost are passengers and their needs in the future. So let’s not lose the main aim tomorrow and – I fully agree with the Commissioner – if we reject the Commission proposal, as proposed in the first part of the amendment tabled for tomorrow, we will lose an opportunity, and for the Council it would be very easy to say ‘Look, we don’t need to do anything. Let’s leave things in our countries as they have been for years.’ So thank you colleagues and let’s keep the more substantial issues for tomorrow and forget the less substantial. Let’s not do everything only for the elections, which are very close.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, February 14, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – This important legislative dossier of the 'clean mobility' package concerns important measures to liberalise road transport of persons in the EU. It is also intended to stimulate the development of long-distance bus links in Europe, but also to offer alternatives to the use of personal cars through additional mobility options of better quality and cheaper, especially for people on low incomes.  As a member of the European Parliament in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, since the beginning of my mandate I have supported the creation of a genuine single market for road passenger transport in the European Union for a single European transport area. This would certainly benefit road passenger companies, and I believe that the liberalisation of road transport of persons provides a natural balance of the European transport market, while ensuring economic and social harmonisation within the EU. I also support the reintroduction of the concept of 'local trip' as part of an international service, so as not to be confused with cabotage operations and subject to the posting regime.  I welcome the legislative initiative to liberalise road passenger transport through this dossier as it offers EU road hauliers new business opportunities and diversification of road passenger transport services at European level.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on NAIADES II - Action Programme for the Promotion of Inland Navigation (2018/2882(RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, an EU policy on inland navigation is crucial, since inland waterways are the most CO2 efficient mode of transport, with an important and untapped potential.  I would like to thank Parliament for its effort to tackle this untapped potential by tabling this resolution on NAIADES II, calling for a follow—up programme for post—2020 and the related financial support to implement the programme. This resolution will support the conclusion of the mid—term progress report of the current NAIADES II programme and the Digital Inland Waterway Area (DINA) report, mapping digital initiatives. These reports emphasise the need to continue working to put inland waterways transport in the place it deserves in terms of a reduction of the overall environmental impact of transport. For the inland waterways transport sector, it is crucial to be part of the fundamental transformation that the big game changers – which are of course digitalisation, decarbonisation, investments, innovation, and people – are bringing to transport and logistics. The EU’s position in relation to inland waterways transport is that of strong support. A key objective of EU transport policy is multimodality, and – as you may recall – I spent a lot of time and energy in 2018 in promoting multimodality. We even called 2018 the ‘Year of Multimodality’. The Commission considers it important to increase the integration of inland waterways transport into the overall transport system. That is why we proposed the revision of the Combined Transport Directive, which would allow further support for the combined transport operations, making use of inland waterways on the non-road leg. In my final year as Transport Commissioner, the smooth implementation of the directive on technical standards and on professional qualification for inland waterways is a priority. We will also continue to look at how best we can bring digitalisation to the sector and link it better into the whole logistic network, especially considering its fragmented character and primarily family-run businesses. Apart from that, we will continue our efforts related to the completion of the Trans-European Transport Networks (TEN-T). A more committed effort aimed at improving European waterways and their connectivity is needed at a governance level. Your call to reinforce financial support for inland waterways through the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) and Horizon Europe was indeed proposed by the Commission for the next financial period. It is now under discussion between Member States and Parliament, and I hope that the outcome of these discussions will be beneficial for the sector. This is why I am pleased that the follow-up programme you propose in your resolution will reinforce the Commission’s activities in this field. The European group of NAIADES, set up by the Commission and to which Member States and the Members of the European Parliament are invited, will already start to reflect and analyse the content of Parliament’s resolution and its proposed follow-up programme from next month. I do, however, have to stress that the adoption and implementation of this programme will, of course, be subject to the orientation of the next Commission. Thank you very much again for your resolution and your support for inland waterways.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Madam President, where are my colleagues? If we are talking about Mr Putin, about distant countries or about sexual issues, the room is full. Now that we are talking about inland navigation, one of the cleanest, forward-looking modes of transport, the turnout is significantly lower. In addition, the Committee on Transport always gets speaking time after 22 hours on Wednesday evenings. Perhaps you can take into account the fact that we also sometimes want to speak on Tuesday or Wednesday mornings. But seriously now. In 2011 we agreed the so-called "modal shift": less road and air transport, and more transport by rail and waterways. Inland navigation is the most underestimated form of transport in the European Union at the moment. I am extremely pleased with the European Commission's action programme, and in particular Mrs Bulc, to re-focus on inland navigation in the broad sense. It's supposedly a boring, technical subject. But when it comes to digitisation, self-sailing ships and sustainability, inland navigation is the most forward-looking form of transport. We need major infrastructure investments. Many locks are too small and too old. The major TEN—T projects, such as the Seine-Scheldt connection, are taking too long. And it is really a challenge, also for the next Parliament, to bring inland navigation more into the political spotlight.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I, who come from a city in Spain that says that it has the most flowing river, the Ebro, the truth is that I still remember the impression that made me flow on the road from Brussels to Cologne, to the Rhine, and to see for real what river highways consist of. I still get goose bumps. I understood that this was truly something extraordinary that had to be preserved and to be supported. And, in fact, after enlargement, we went in delegation from Vienna to the end, to the Black Sea, following the Danube, and we also realized the needs of this great river, that great river highway also European, and the need for precisely that relationship of cross-border capacity, dialogue and improvement. And, as far as it fits, in Spain, in spite of everything, we have an application of the Naiades program in the river port of Seville, which we love very much and we think is very important. Hence our support is central to this Naiades program. We have taken care of it, I believe, in the Connecting Europe Facility, and whatever its improvement, its approach to the environmental side, but by letting the rivers that are managed continue to be managed, is essential. Therefore, Commissioner, you have our support for further strengthening this Naiades programme.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The future of inland waterway transport in the European Union depends primarily on the amount of investment that will be allocated in the coming years. We need modern infrastructure that combines the potential of inland waterway transport and other modes of transport. The future is multimodality, especially ports and transhipment terminals, where goods transported by waterways can be picked up and transported further and in other ways. I would like one of these multimodal terminals to be built in Bydgoszcz, which is located at the crossroads of the E40 and E70 international waterways, as well as in the immediate vicinity of the Baltic-Adriatic and North Sea-Baltic corridors. However, in addition to the cooperation of national authorities and the private sector, such an investment will require appropriate support from the European Union. Precisely in order to carry out such modern and ambitious projects, the Commission should provide adequate funding for the continuation of the NAIADES project. Inland transport deserves more attention on our part. The next budgetary perspective is an excellent opportunity for member states to find more money for this purpose as well. This is the third transport debate today, Commissioner, and I agree with you in all three, but the Commissioner will not convince me of the mobility package.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Thank you to our rapporteurs. It really is. Of course, everyone who is talking today is convinced that inland waterway transport is an important thing. I can go full with Wim van de Camp: it is a particularly nice transport option. He is only from the Netherlands, and I come from Germany. There are many rivers and canals. This is not everywhere in Europe. But where there is – Inés, you were talking about the ebro, for example – you can use the river, and that is necessary. Most people forget that. People are always talking about this: we want to go from road to rail. Nothing is said about road or rail to inland waterway transport. And we cannot build new rails as quickly as we can use rivers more. And that's what we need. NAIADES shows us how we can digitise river shipping, make it more modern, make it more environmentally friendly, even more environmentally friendly with liquefied natural gas, for example, how we can have good qualifications in this area – we have just recently achieved harmonisation for qualification. In other words, this area has a huge future. We can also lift a bridge with much less money, for example, so that double containers can then be transported than we can build rails at the same time. We need both transport routes, or all three, but we certainly need not only rail, but also more inland waterways, compared to road transport. And to focus on it and make money available for it, that's what NAIADES is all about, and that's very important and very good.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I also believe that all those who are still here at the time must have a heart for inland waterway transport. I too welcome the action programme on domestic navigation and waterways. I welcome the fact that we have invested EUR 1.7 billion from the CEF in waterway infrastructure. And the 4 million that we are now investing for safe navigation are certainly well-invested money. All of this makes a lot of ecological sense and also a high level of social acceptance. Unfortunately, however, ladies and gentlemen, this is just a drop in the ocean. The truth is that most channels in Europe are not suitable for the European ship, that we do not have a trace of continuity here. The truth is that we do not need EUR 1.7 billion for locks and bridge extensions, but EUR 100 billion. These are the dimensions of how this differs. So let's fight for at least a strong CEF in the next financial period. I also believe that earmarking cohesion funds for the CEF is simply one of them.  Unfortunately, Parliament voted differently today. I am sure, however, that this short-sightedness will not get through with the Commission and the Council. There are simply more goods on the waterway. Let us fight for it together!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, even my heart has been beating for water transport for several years, and I can see this in some controversial buildings. I would like to stress that inland waterways connect important ports, cities and also agricultural areas, thus contributing significantly to the European Union's objectives of reducing carbon emissions, sustainable growth and territorial cohesion. Inland waterway transport is also essential to further reduce the negative impacts of transport through more efficient use of land, energy, as well as, of course, noise reduction and accidents. Modernising the inland waterway fleet and adapting it to technical progress would give it a competitive advantage in multimodal transport, as the Commissioner has already emphasised here, and I am also joining in this.  However, very limited funding has been allocated to this sector so far and this sector, which is mainly small businesses, still has difficult access to finance. I agree with the rapporteur that water transport options are indeed underestimated and are certainly higher, but require more investment. For this reason, I would like to ask the Commission whether the NAIADES II action programme and, where appropriate, of course, NAIADES III, should receive more adequate funding precisely to achieve its objectives, so that it is well supported by a structured policy strategy with achievable short- and medium-term objectives and a concrete plan setting out, inter alia, the resources for its implementation. I'm sure that's what water transport needs.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome this programme, I would also be keen for more funding and let me make one personal remark. As a representative of the capital city of Prague, the capital of the Czech Republic, a beautiful, historic city through which the Vltava River flows, I know how terribly underrated inland waterway transport is. How old ships are often on European rivers and how big a problem it is in specific cities. For example, we are permanently dealing with this, and if NAIADES II arises and if it has a successor, we will certainly be happy to take advantage of it.  This particular example from the Czech Republic is proof that there is a huge potential that we are absolutely not able to use in Europe. So the more, the better, and I hope that this program will have followers and that we will be able to free up more money than there is in this particular proposal. The money is really insufficient, but I very much welcome this initiative.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the Naiades, according to Greek mythology, were nymphs of fresh water and springs. In fact, Homer mentions that they were daughters of Zeus. I would therefore like to ask the Commissioner, because NAIADES II is linked to the Connecting Europe programme and because many funds have been cut from the Cohesion Fund in order to go to 'Connecting Europe', whether these amounts will also be used to implement the well-known project called 'The Suez of the Balkans', namely the unification of the Axios River, Morava. , the Danube and the Rhine, a EUR 17 billion project for the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Investment Bank (EIB). The United States is seeking to transfer cheap LNG from the mediterranean entrance, from Thessaloniki to Western Europe. The question, then, is whether this project will be financed by NAIADES II, in order to reveal, thus, that there are also narrow economic interests behind the despicable agreement of the Prespas through NAIADES II. We want an answer to these questions, Mrs Bulc. Tell us if this project will be funded by NAIADES II. What are the conditions? This explains that in the despicable agreement of the Prespas there is special regulation for hydronomics, so ....  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would just like to remind you that we should also take into account the Sustainable Development Goals. This is mainly about Objective 6, namely clean water, and no 7, renewable energy. I believe it would be important to focus on the sustainable development objectives, particularly in inland water, and to ensure that we have the highest quality of water – if possible, drinking water – and mobility that travels sustainably on our inland waters.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this debate. I was listening carefully and I heard only positive encouragement. I can assure you that the Commission will, in its work, take actions in the future to promote and further integrate inland navigation into the overall European transport policy. As for the questions by honourable Member Mr Marias, I would invite you to submit to me in writing your question because I really did not understand exactly what you were directly asking me, but I would like to reply. I’m very much looking forward to the adoption of your resolution tomorrow and I think everybody here is convinced, and hopefully many more, that inland waterways are the future for the EU as well.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 February 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – We are today asking the European Commission to urgently work on a new and ambitious action programme for inland navigation, to monitor and improve the Naiades II action programme for the period 2014-2020. In the coming years, we must continue and strengthen the possibilities and strengths of inland navigation. In order to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement, our transport sector needs to decarbonise significantly. Inland navigation can play an important role here through the shift from road transport to water transport. That is why we need to support inland navigation, including CEF II, by eliminating bottlenecks. Thanks to the Directive on technical regulations for inland waterway vessels, a dossier for which I was rapporteur, there is one uniform technical standard for inland vessels in the EU (and no longer as a standard for the EU but with a separate standard for the Rhine). With a unified standard, we naturally facilitate cross-border transport by water.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The potential for inland waterway transport remains largely untapped, even though it is a means of transport that is part of the EU strategy for alternative modes of transport. Inland navigation is an essential element of a multimodal transport system, ensuring the efficient operation of seaports and their hinterland facilities, playing an increasingly important role in the operation of urban centres and industrial centres. The construction of a system of tourist ports, marinas, mooring piers together with a uniform system of information and identification of MDW E70 in Warmia and Mazury will allow to strengthen the economic and social potential of up to eleven cities in parts of my region. These include modernising the fleet of ships, developing digital systems, improving the skills of inland waterway workers and increasing the competitiveness of the inland waterway transport market by investing in new and existing infrastructure to further develop the trans-European network. These activities require securing adequate project funding as well as updating the TEN-T network. Warmia and Mazury is a region with great potential, which could be fully released by the renewal and expansion of waterways, which will not only provide better communication, but will also enhance the tourist values of parts of my region. On the other hand, the excavation of the Vistula Spit is one of the strategic investments, the implementation of which will allow the independence of the port of Elbląg, as well as connect the Gulf of Gdansk with the Vistula Lagoon. The project will also increase security in this part of the country.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on security threats related to China's growing technological presence in the EU and possible measures to reduce them at EU level (2019/2575(RSP)).

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for this opportunity to exchange views on the topical issue of security and technology and the relevant international developments. As you are aware, the European Council also attaches great importance to security and technology. Last year, both in June and October, it addressed questions of internal security, especially regarding cybersecurity.  The Romanian Council Presidency has also made cybersecurity part of a broader package that deals with hybrid threats to the European elections, and one of the main issues that we have to address, as mentioned, is to gather information on this.  Cybersecurity is indeed one of the main challenges we are facing as attacks are capable of causing serious economic damage and of violating privacy and fundamental rights. Recent cybersecurity events in some Member States are not a new trend but just the latest example of the most negative downside of the internet.  However, no economic growth can be achieved without a stable and secure environment. During the last year cybersecurity has become a matter of highest political priority and a constant topic on the agenda. The ambitious cybersecurity package presented by the Commission in September 2017 was followed the by a set of Council conclusions and an action plan for their implementation. These emphasised the need to enhance the EU’s capacity to prevent, deter and respond to cyber—attacks.  The Cyber Security Act – an important part of the package – will be formally adopted in the coming weeks. This will create a strong and permanent mandate for the European Union Cybersecurity Agency (ENISA) and will enhance cybersecurity certification.  The Council is also making progress in the discussions on the proposal for a regulation establishing the European Cybersecurity Industrial Technology and Research Centre and network of coordination centres. It is the Presidency’s intention to reach a general approach on this important file in the coming weeks.  Furthermore, the EU has stepped up its response by adopting a cyber—diplomacy toolbox. This framework offers the full use of measures within the Common Foreign and Security Policy, including, if needed, restrictive measures.  As regards China, the EU is committed to opening trading relations with this country. We should not forget that China is the EU’s second biggest trading partner, after the US. However, access to the Chinese markets for EU companies remains highly restricted and China ranks among the least open economies to foreign direct investment (FDI) inflow, in particular in certain key sectors.  In contrast, the European market is fully open to Chinese investment, despite the lack of reciprocity. China is not only becoming a more prominent international investor but is increasingly focusing on high—tech sectors as targets for its acquisitions. The EU is also addressing forced technology transfers in China. In particular, in June 2018, the EU filed a dispute settlement case in the World Trade Organization, supplemented in December 2018, against Chinese practices that force European companies to give up sensitive technology and know—how as a precondition for investing in China.  We are strengthening our tools for responding to the possible risks that certain investments could pose to our security or essential interests of the Union. In this regard, this House will be voting this week on a very important piece of legislation – the Investment Screening Regulation. The regulation will establish a framework for screening by the Member States and for a mechanism for cooperation in the exchange of information about investments from third countries.  The regulation is country—neutral and is not directed at China. It will be applied towards foreign direct investment from all third countries, without differentiating, and is fully in line with the EU’s and Member States’ international commitments. The framework is strictly focused on security and public order, which the EU interprets in a narrow sense. As such, it is not intended to discourage foreign investments but, on the contrary, to enable such investments in sensitive areas by addressing and mitigating risks relating to security and public order.  We welcome the excellent cooperation of the European Parliament in this file, which will lead to its adoption in the coming months. I look forward to listening to this debate and I want once more to repeat that the Romanian Council Presidency is fully committed towards fighting for cybersecurity and fighting against interference from abroad and, at the same time, for doing more investments but having in mind as well how we protect our fundamental rights and freedoms in Europe.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, securing our critical digital infrastructure is not a question we can leave for some future date. It’s not a question to be left to the next Parliament. It’s not even a question for next week. Cyber and cyber—enabled threats already pose a significant challenge to our European Union. This is not going to change any time soon, and with the emergence of new technologies – which will change our entire connected lives – we need to be thinking right now about our digital security requirements.  It’s no surprise that the resilience of critical digital infrastructures, including in relation to the imminent rollout of 5G technology, has aroused healthy debate in Member States around the role of third-country technology providers, not least in the light of the 2017 Chinese National Intelligence Law. To those who have questioned why we are discussing this, and to those who have tried to warn us off, I want to say this: it’s absolutely right that we should be discussing this. It’s entirely legitimate, and indeed necessary. 5G infrastructure will be the backbone of our digital economy, providing mission-critical services, not only for consumer services, but for a myriad of other sectors – transport, energy, health, defence and the security sector – and it will not be easy to replace once it is installed. Securing this critical digital infrastructure is necessary to protect our government, our industry, our democratic institutions, our personal information, and indeed, our core values, such as the protection of fundamental rights and data protection. Driving this urgent work forward and building stronger coordination among Member States will be essential to our joint efforts to increase our collective digital resilience.  There are, as has already been mentioned, a number of instruments in place which can be used to boost that resilience. For a start, while 5G standards are global, theoretically allowing suppliers from anywhere in the world to do business here in Europe, anyone who wants to access the EU market needs to comply with our rules. Member States have the right to take measures against companies, for reasons of national security. The regulation on screening of foreign direct investments (FDI) into the EU, as has just been underlined, will allow the Commission and Member States to cooperate in their assessment of potential security risks, including cyber—related threats posed by foreign investments. The regulation will establish a mechanism enabling Member States and the Commission to assist each other where a foreign investment in critical technology infrastructure, as in other sectors, could affect the security or public order interests of other Member States or of the Union itself. The Commission will also be able to issue opinions – in particular when Union projects and programmes are potentially at risk. In this way, the regulation will help ensure Member States have the information they need when making key decisions on their critical digital infrastructures. As my colleague Commissioner Malmström said to this Chamber a little earlier today, by concluding the work on the FDI screening regulation, the Union is sending a strong message to its partners. We are open to foreign investment, but a condition of being open is to be able to trust that foreign investors will not threaten our security and our strategic interests.  As well as who is supplying our infrastructure, we also need to consider how cyber-secure it will be once it’s in place, once we’re using it. Again, there are measures in place to boost cybersecurity at EU level. For example, most Member States have already transposed into national law the Security of Network and Information Systems (NIS) Directive. That was the first EU—wide legislation in this area, and for any Member States who have not yet transposed this, I think they would be well advised to do so. The Directive seeks to develop national cybersecurity capabilities, increase EU—level cooperation and ensure that operators of essential services, including certain digital service providers, adopt appropriate risk management measures and report significant incidents to their national authorities.  Again, as has been underlined, the Cybersecurity Act that we reached agreement on last December will soon be adopted and published. It reinforces the mandate of the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA), creating a genuine European cybersecurity agency, better to support Member States in tackling cyber threats and attacks. The Act also establishes an EU framework for cybersecurity certification, boosting the cybersecurity of online services and consumer devices. I think that we can expect 5G infrastructure to be an important element of the Agency’s work. Finally, negotiations are underway on the proposal for a European cybersecurity research and competence centre and network, which will stimulate the development and deployment of cybersecurity technology and complement the capacity-building efforts in this area at EU— and national levels. These various measures create the right kind of incentives to enhance cybersecurity products and services in the EU, both for business and consumers, and along supply chains. But we need to work together – the institutions, our agencies and the Member States – to make use of the various provisions and powers. Together, we need to demonstrate the necessary political will to better assure our digital security, and it’s vital that we remain vigilant to all the cyber and cyber—enabled threats, including those to our digital infrastructure, given that they will continue to evolve and they will continue to be cross-border. For our part, the Commission is committed to continue working with Member States and the other European institutions on these issues. Thank you for organising this debate this evening. I think it’s very important.

name: Jiří Pospíšil
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to say that this issue is extremely important for my faction. I must say, Commissioner, that I have listened with interest to your speech, which was interesting but, in my opinion, very general. The point we are dealing with here relates directly to companies that are linked to China, to a particular country. And we do not address this point here by accident, because in the last few months there have simply been problems in some EU Member States related to the security risks of specific Chinese companies.  I am from the Czech Republic, where this problem concerns two Chinese companies, and I want to say, I do not know if you have this information, that on 17 December 2018 the Czech National Cyber and Information Security Office issued a clear warning about two Chinese companies, namely Huawei and ZTE. The Czech Republic is not the only EU country currently dealing with these problems on its territory. It's a current problem, our government is dealing with it in a certain way, in my opinion, rather alibiically. Regardless of what the Czech President notes, which more or less greatly downplays the warnings of this professional office.  I therefore believe that the European institutions, the European Commission, should respond to these problems at the moment. Possibly within the framework of their legislation, or at least by leading a debate between Member States, that there will be an attempt to coordinate some common action in order to protect European security. I would very much like the Commission's initiative to be here if we were able to make some kind of joint, strong response, as the US did in August last year, or as New Zealand or Australia did, for example. I think this is necessary because espionage and data abuse do not know national borders, and one European response will have to be made.

name: Петър Курумбашев
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Let me stress that I would also be happy to have a common position of the European Union and not to have separate positions of the different Member States, because only in this way will the Union's position be more respected.  I would also like to stress that when there are charges, it is good to have evidence. By the way, there are accusations to Chinese companies that they may be exporting data to their government. I would love to hear the same about American companies and see if American companies have the opportunity to export data to their government. In general, we need to make sure on the territory of the European Union that no one allows themselves to violate European law. Here, for example, gdpr is an excellent example, a pioneer in legislation that many, even American companies, have said they will apply around the world.  We just passed the Cybersecurity Act. There, for example, the possibility of certification schemes was created. Here is an excellent job for ENISA. Let me set up a certification scheme for 5G equipment to be implemented throughout the European Union, and I think such a certification scheme can also be proposed worldwide. Let ENISA use its double budget, which has just been confirmed by the European Parliament, precisely so that European citizens can feel safer in this new 5G technology.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I will exceptionally speak in my mother language, so please do use your headphones. Madam President, first of all, I would like to commend what Commissioner King said. In recent months, I and my fellow information officers have dealt in quite detail with the cybersecurity legislation proposed by the European Commission. I think this is a substantial shift, and it is a pity that this issue has not caused more interest across the political spectrum in this Parliament, but particularly in the Member States.  What we have been referring to is that in the Member States, the thinking of what we call mindset has not yet changed. I remember hearing in the trilogue how difficult it was to persuade the Member States, albeit to make partial shifts. I mean, the legislative infrastructure that we're building right now, I think that's a key step. And what do we need? We have to be able to fill it. We must have the will to transpose it quickly, to build institutional infrastructure. I am glad that we have it in the Czech Republic, it may not yet be at the level of Germany, Britain, France, but it is of high quality. But what really lags behind is awareness at the political level in the Member States, but also the ability to think about the risks that lie here. This is not just a question of espionage, it is a question perhaps more serious in the future. So I think that this is a step that we have to take, and it is a pity, as has already been said here, that the Czech political representation not only torpedoes this, but is practically on the other side of the table.  Last comment, I appreciate what the Minister said. At the moment, we also need to be able to protect our market, but at the same time to penetrate foreign markets, i.e. here in this respect there is an absolute imbalance and reciprocity must be our primary principle.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Anyone who believed that only plastic toys would be produced in China, I believe it is now time to gain new insights. China is a space nation. The country has produced world-class technology and mobility companies. You will probably test the care during processing and assembly on a daily basis with your phone or computer. In the future technologies artificial intelligence and electromobility, Chinese manufacturers are now ahead of their European competitors. This gap also applies between Silicon Valley and, in my view, the Huawei Group when we talk about 5G technology. I believe that we simply need to agree on this once again.  We do not need exclusion or helpless attempts at containment. We need cooperation to deal with issues, including digital security. In the EU, more than 180,000 people are already working for this largest Chinese technology company – a private company, by the way, no matter how loudly the media reports it. However, cooperation also creates prospects for employees, and this is also the case for many other global companies from other countries. We also need cooperation to design the necessary regulation for the new technologies from China with China and multilaterally. Only in this way can we prevent the misuse and cases of data theft – by whomever, this is really a real issue – that technological development will make possible. In this direction, Commissioner, we would like to continue the debate with you.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, Representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The hottest topic in terms of China's technical presence in Europe is certainly the topic of 5G. And the Huawei company, which has just been mentioned by Mr Scholz, plays a special role in this. You, Commissioner, have already referred to the Chinese National Intelligence Act. Let me put it explicitly: we should learn from Australia. It has drawn the conclusion that I think is right for us: we cannot trust a company that is obliged by the laws of its own country to make data of its customers available to the authorities of that country upon request and to conceal this data transfer from customers. Such a company cannot be part of the core of our 5G infrastructure. And we should find a common European solution, because this debate is now taking place in many different European countries. Overall, however, I believe that the issue is much broader. And many keywords have been mentioned, from investment screening to cyber security, technology exports could be called. I agree, Mr Scholz, to say that we want cooperation. But we cannot pursue cooperation on the blue-eyed assumption that this will be mutually beneficial anyway. We must protect our interests and values in this process.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I must admit that I feel a certain irony about tonight’s debate as a British MEP speaking to a British Commissioner in the European Parliament, 44 days before Brexit, about security threats affecting the UK. But post-Brexit neighbourly cooperation remains important. We know that the Chinese Government is particularly sensitive about suggestions that there could be any security risks regarding the introduction of 5G technology, and indeed they even went so far as to take out a full-page advertisement in the Daily Telegraph to attempt to assuage those concerns. And perhaps one of the biggest difficulties for me – or indeed for anyone watching this debate – is to assess the nature of evidence which isn’t in the public domain. For example, the director of the FBI claims that Huawei smartphones can conduct undetected espionage and maliciously modify or steal information, but to what extent can this be done? What the hard evidence is remains something of a mystery.  Likewise, the arrest of Meng Wanzhou in Canada at the request of the American Government raises concerns. And if it were just the United States, then it would be tempting to impute an ulterior motive – to suggest that it could simply be a US response to a free market challenge to the US’s decades of tech dominance. But it’s not just the USA; there are concerns from Australia, from Japan, from a number of other European nations closer to home. The British Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson has said that he has very deep concerns about Chinese involvement in 5G networks. And if there is a risk, then it must be a very big one. Why? Because every government – every government – has an interest in raising billions through 5G auctions, and the Chinese companies are bound to be the leading competitors in those auctions. And it’s a big risk for another reason: because security matters; because, ultimately, it’s a matter of national protection, national defence and national sovereignty.  Our response to this kind of situation demands the careful consideration of all the evidence, and I believe that the UK’s response needs to be dependent on three fundamental questions. Firstly, what is the level of risk of back-door routes being installed, potentially at the direction of the Chinese Government, which would enable industrial espionage to take place? Secondly, what is the level of risk that the Chinese Government could mandate the disclosure of information held by Chinese tech companies in the UK, potentially even putting Chinese citizens at risk? Thirdly, to what extent will countries become over-reliant on the 5G networks; a situation which, bluntly – if we find out later that we’ve made a mistake –would be difficult to correct.  Any response at all bears the danger of being overly cautious, overly protectionist, to the extent that we ultimately find ourselves excluding technology from overseas, but that has to be balanced against broader security questions, and to me the question of risk management is essentially very similar to the question of the precautionary principle. What is the level of evidence needed for us to act? I don’t see this is a question of proof beyond reasonable doubt – maybe not a question of proof at all, but a question of protection. If we have a lack of absolute scientific certainty, on which side should we bear the risk? It’s a philosophical question as much as a practical one, but I believe that to make practical judgments we need  a little bit better information as to the level and nature of the risk.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, it is dangerous to use the mobile phones of the Chinese company Huawei. They are, most likely, a huge source of intelligence for the Chinese government's spy services. The capture of this information seems to have already enabled China to steal Western technologies. Several democratic states have already expressed concern about this issue, such as Canada, Australia, Poland and Belgium. And on January 28, the U.S. Justice Department officially accused Huawei of stealing U.S. technology. As for the Czech Republic, it has just excluded it from a tender. The European Union can no longer remain inert: a European Commissioner, Andrus Ansip, has already warned against this Chinese company. Now we have to act. I expect the European Parliament to launch an investigation and the European Council to recommend that the Member States of the Union take immediate precautions.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that protectionism is the wrong answer. There is an international competition. And backdoors are available in software, in hardware, they are often offered on all continents. That is why I believe it is important to concentrate on confidence-building measures and, in particular, to redesign the tenders accordingly, that a company and institution design the architecture of the system accordingly, that a second company then installs the production for the hardware and software and that a third company ensures maintenance and operation. Then you have three different companies or institutions that need to know in detail how the system works. Then you also have security. And if one of these companies still has its headquarters in Europe, then we have two international suppliers on which we can also rely, who are certified and where you can reliably see how this works. We have the Cyber Security Act, and we also have the Cyber Security Competence Centres, which we now want to set up. With the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and, ultimately, with the Copyright Directive, where an agreement was reached today, Europe has already come up with a great deal of agreement here. We have ENISA, we have the NIS directive – so there is already a great deal here and we need to continue working in this area.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, First of all, I would like to highlight minister Ciamba's speech, because I really liked his speech, he highlighted the risks, he followed the precautionary principle, especially on security issues that cannot be underestimated. Cybersecurity is becoming one of the key aspects. Above all, we have a problem with 5G technology, which is linked to a Chinese company that is a truly unreliable partner. And we need a European response and to own this key European infrastructure in European hands. I am almost 100 in the desire to send a transcript of Minister Ciamba's speech to the Czech Government, which relativises this issue, and also to the Czech President, who is directly a trade representative of Chinese interests in the European Union.  I think it is good not to underestimate this topic. We're talking about risks that can really compromise data theft. I also welcome the Commissioner's words with regard to direct investment screening, but in this case we are talking about legislation that is not yet ready, we need a response now, a common, European one, such as Australia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, competition between the European Union, the USA, Russia and China is, of course, intensifying and is, of course, causing a number of problems for European companies and the European economy, because at this stage Chinese companies are appearing very strong, which are trying to buy strategic companies in the European Union. Therefore, the European Union, for its own reasons, imposes restrictions on investment, however much it does not want to admit it. These restrictions may be imposed on grounds of public policy and public security. The United States has already done so for its part. So that is something that we discussed in the previous debate. It is a given that there are reasons for technological security, they have been developed, and — therefore — the European Union is forming a system to defend itself against China's interventions.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I agree with everyone who said that this is a very important subject, a very important debate. I would even have welcomed this debate slightly earlier in the day, with the opportunity to have slightly more people in the Chamber, because while we may be discussing technology that is not yet part of our everyday lives, it soon will be. And the fact that it will form the backbone infrastructure connecting everything means that we now have to think very seriously about how to get security right from the outset, from the start. Although 5G has, for understandable reasons, attracted the most attention in recent weeks, it’s not the only thing we need to be thinking about. Storing data in the cloud and artificial intelligence open up huge opportunities to make use of, or to abuse, huge volumes of personal data, to give just one other example. These issues raise challenges around national and EU—level decision—making, which won’t – let’s be frank – necessarily be easy to resolve.  Trying to protect everything won’t work. We need to decide what really matters, what is core in terms of the digital ecosystem, and whether greater transparency around suppliers, supply chains and foreign investment is enough to offset the security risks. It may be that some pieces of backbone digital infrastructure are simply too critical for us to risk. These issues are also inherently geopolitical. So I think the solutions need to reflect our – Europe’s – particular perspective based around keeping markets open and trade fair. Security concerns are not an excuse for arbitrary protectionism but, equally, we can’t ignore those concerns. We need to think strategically around these issues of security. As far as the Commission is concerned, we take these issues very seriously. We will be working on them, and I look forward to continuing our cooperative work with you on this whole range of issues.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I think this has been a very useful debate, and I would like to assure everyone that the Presidency of Romania of the Council will keep this issue in mind in future debates in the Council. We also took note, in particular, of what the Commission has said here, and let me also assure you once again that the Presidency and the Council as a whole attaches great importance to preserving cybersecurity, a matter of the highest political priority and a constant topic of attention.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. (The motions for resolutions to be submitted in accordance with Article 123(2) of the CRP will be announced at a later date.) The vote will take place during the next part-session.
